questions.text: During an outbreak of dengue, the health team carries out source reduction of mosquitoes by eliminating breeding sites through appropriate methods. Which method of mosquito control does this describe?
questions.solution:
The control measure described is an environmental control method.

Various methods of mosquito control:

  • Environmental control - source reduction
  • Chemical control - Use of insecticides, pesticides, etc.
  • Biological control - Use of larvivorous fish like Gambusia
  • Genetic control - Sex distortion
  • Newer methods -
    • Chemosterilants
    • Insect growth regulators
    • Sex attractants
  • Integrated approach - Involves the usage of more than one modality of arthropod control

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female patient presents to the casualty with complaints of sudden onset of pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is a palpable tympanic swelling in the left side of the abdomen. X-ray abdomen of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the X-ray are suggestive of cecal volvulus. It is differentiated from sigmoid volvulus as there is only a single air-fluid level and the lower end of the dilatation is not pointed to the pelvis.

Cecal volvulus can only occur when the cecum and ascending colon arc on a mesentery. This is often associated with a degree of malrotation. It is commonly seen in females of 4th and 5th decade. They present with features of acute intestinal obstruction. Initially, the obstruction may be partial and the patient can pass feces and flatus.

A palpable tympanic swelling in the midline or the left side may be seen in 25% of the cases.

Radiological findings include cecal dilatation, single air-fluid level, and absence of gas in the distal colon. CT shows a whirl sign, which is also seen in the midgut volvulus.

If there are no concerns of ischemia, a barium enema can be used to confirm the diagnosis. The characteristic findings include the absence of barium in the cecum and bird beak deformity.

Other options:

Sigmoid volvulus- It is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Sigmoid volvulus is differentiated from a cecal volvulus by its ahaustral wall and the lower end pointing to the pelvis. Abdominal radiographs will show a large, inverted U-shaped dilated loop of the colon, often with two air-fluid levels one in each limb of the loop.

Specific radiographic signs:

  • Coffee bean sign
  • Frimann-Dahl's sign - three dense lines converge towards the site of obstruction
  • Bird of prey sign
  • Absent rectal gas

The radiograph given below is that of sigmoid volvulus.

Differences between small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

  Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No. of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present

An erect radiograph of small bowel obstruction with multiple air-fluid levels is shown below.

The dilated proximal small bowel is predominantly gas filled with a few air fluid levels.

More distally, the small bowel is fluid-filled and bubbles of gas are trapped between the valvulae conniventes, producing a chain of bubbles. This is known as a "string of beads" appearance.

Intussusception - It occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The characteristic clinical triad is pain, red-currant jelly stools, and palpable sausage-shaped mass.

Radiological findings:

  • Target sign, pseudokidney sign, and crescent in a doughnut sign in USG
  • Coiled spring appearance on double contrast barium enema

The image given below shows the coiled spring appearance-

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A radiological assessment of a pregnant woman reveals an anteroposteriorly oval-shaped pelvic inlet. According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification, this shape of pelvic inlet is described as ______.
questions.solution:
According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification, an anteroposteriorly oval-shaped pelvic inlet is an anthropoid pelvis.

  Gynecoid  Anthropoid  Android  Platypelloid 
Shape  Round 

Anteroposteriorly oval 

 Triangular  Transversely oval /Flat bowl 
Sacral Angle   More than 90°  More than 90° Less than 90° More than 90°
Sidewalls  Straight or slightly divergent  Straight or divergent  Convergent  Divergent 
Ischial spines  Not prominent  Not prominent  Prominent  Not prominent 
Subpubic angle   Wide (85°)  Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (>90°) 
Position  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoanterior  Direct occipitoanterior or posterior  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoposterior  Occipitolateral 
Diameter of engagement  Transverse or oblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse or oblique  Transverse 
Delivery  No difficulty   Higher incidence of face-to-pubis delivery  Difficult delivery, with an increased chance of perineal injuries  No difficulty

questions.text: A patient with narcolepsy has been prescribed tiprolisant. How does this drug act?
questions.solution:
Tiprolisant is a selective H3 receptor - inverse agonist.

Tiprolisant promotes wakefulness, improves cognitive functions (e.g., enhances memory, learning, and attention), and reduces food intake. It is also known as pitolisant, and it reduces excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy in adults with narcolepsy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman on HRT presented with abdominal pain for the past 6 months. On examination, a non-tender, right adnexal mass was palpable. USG showed a 3 x 3 cm smooth ovarian cyst. What is the next best step in her case?

choices.text: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirmation of USG findings by CT scan
Exploratory laparotomy for evaluation of cyst
CA- 125 level estimation; if normal, advise regular follow-up

questions.solution:
CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for post-menopausal ovarian cysts.

Management includes the following:

  • Calculation of Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) = U x  M  x  Ca-125, where
    • U = ultrasound score
    • M = menopausal status
    • Ca 125 = serum levels
  • Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size >5 cm or RMI >200.

Option B - CT scan is not recommended for initial evaluation. It is done only for further evaluation and when RMI > 200.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with a pink, scaly, non-firm patch on his trunk that he observed about a month ago. It has increased in size since then. Histopathology shows ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests. You prescribe a 5-fluorouracil cream. Where does this drug act in the image given below?
questions.solution:
A pink, scaly, non-firm patch that is gradually increasing in size showing ovoid cells in nests with palisading peripheral cells suggests a diagnosis of superficial basal cell carcinoma. The antimetabolite that is used for topical treatment of this condition is 5-fluorouracil, an S-phase inhibitor. DNA synthesis occurs in the S-phase of the mitosis cycle. 

5-FU acts via two different pathways depending on its dose: G1- S-phase cell cycle arrest and apoptosis at a higher dose and G2-M-phase cell cycle arrest at a low dose.

5-FU:

  • Converted in the body to the corresponding nucleotide 5-deoxyuridine monophosphate, which forms a covalent ternary complex with methyl-THFA and thymidylate synthase, resulting in the irreversible inhibition of thymidylate synthase.
  • Failure of DNA synthesis occurs due to the non-availability of thymidylate.
  • Inhibition of TS by 5-FU depends on THFA, infusion of leucovorin will enhance the efficacy of this drug. Cisplatin and oxaliplatin also synergize with this drug.
  • Rapidly dividing cells are most commonly affected, but resting cells are also affected.
  • Used as an anticancer drug for many solid cancers such as the colon, rectum, stomach, pancreas, liver, urinary bladder, head, and neck. Topical preparations are used in BCC and actinic keratosis.
  • Toxicity includes myelosuppression, mucositis, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. Peripheral neuropathy may also occur.

Basal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis.

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore, it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face.

BCC can be divided into localized and generalized.

Localized BCC can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic - accounts for the majority of BCC
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented
  • Nevoid

Generalized BCC can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative.

Nodular BCC presents a small, slowly growing pearly nodule, often with tortuous telangiectatic vessels on its surface, rolled borders, and a central crust.

The characteristic finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests, which are shown in the image below.

 

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery, topical imiquimod, topical 5-FU, photodynamic therapy, cryotherapy, radiation, or intralesional therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin?
questions.solution:
Cloxacillin is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.

Penicillinase is a beta-lactamase enzyme that inactivates penicillin by destroying the beta-lactam ring. This enzyme is produced by most staphylococci, some gonococci strains, Bacillus subtilis, Escherichia coli, Haemophilus influenzae, etc.

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are not inactivated by penicillinase. But, they are less efficient than penicillin G against penicillin-sensitive pathogens. They are used to treat staphylococcal infections that are sensitive to methicillin. 

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins:

  • Cloxacillin
  • Dicloxacillin
  • Flucloxacillin
  • Methicillin
  • Nafcillin

Other options:

Option A: Penicillin V is an acid-resistant penicillin preparation that is administered orally. But it has limited use against penicillinase-producing organisms.

Option C: Benzathine penicillin G and procaine penicillin G are repository preparations of penicillin G and are long-acting. They are given as deep I.M. injections. Benzathine penicillin has the longest half-life and is administered every 2-4 weeks. It is sensitive to penicillinase. 

Option D: Ampicillin is an extended-spectrum penicillin but is not resistant to beta-lactamases.

questions.text: During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text:
A patient presents with erythematous streak-like lesions on the trunk, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely etiology for his presenting complaints?

IKBKG - Inhibitor of nuclear factor kappa B kinase regulatory subunit gamma

NEMO - Nuclear factor-kappa B essential modulator

choices.text: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO

questions.solution:
The image in the clinical scenario above shows flagellate erythema. It is seen as a side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy. 

Flagellate erythema is characterized by multiple red, macular streaks of erythema on the trunk and limbs. The streaks are aligned in a criss‐cross pattern, giving a whip-like or flagellate appearance. They may be sore or pruritic. 

Flagellate erythema is seen in

  • A side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy
  • The toxic effect after consumption of shitake mushrooms
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Adult-onset Still’s disease
  • Docetaxel therapy

It is self-limiting and usually resolves within a few days to weeks. Topical steroids and oral antihistamines can be given to relieve the associated pruritis.

Other options:

Option A: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin causes hyperpigmentation. Although erythematous streaks may occur at the site of infusion, generalized flagellate erythema is usually not seen. Cardiotoxicity is the most significant side effect of doxorubicin chemotherapy.

Option C: Burrowing of hookworm larvae in the skin causes a creeping eruption characterized by linear twisting and winding lesions mainly on the feet and hands as shown in the image given below.

Option D: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO is responsible for incontinentia pigmenti. It follows 4 stages of cutaneous lesions—erythematous vesicular rash, verrucous lesions, hyperpigmented whorls, and atrophic streaks. Lesions are seen along the lines of Blaschko. 

The image given below shows the hyperpigmented whorl stage (stage 3).

questions.text: A patient presenting with the features of heart burn and indigestion is suspected to be suffering from gastritis. With respect to type A and type B gastritis, choose the correct option.

choices.text: Type A- Associated with Helicobacter pylori

questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option C-: Type A-Antrum spared.

Type B gastritis usually affects the antrum. It is associated with Helicobacter pylori. Intestinal metaplasia associated with chronic pan-gastritis and atrophy is seen. It has greater potential for malignancy as compared to Type A gastritis. 

Type A gastritis affects the fundus with antral sparing. Its features can be easily remembered by 4 ‘A’s:

  • Autoimmune condition - has circulating antibodies to parietal cells
  • Atrophy of parietal cell mass
  • Achlorhydria - causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
  • Anemia - leads to pernicious anemia, due to malabsorption of vitamin B12 (as the intrinsic factor is also produced by parietal cells)

Related Pearl: Types of Chronic gastritis

Type A and Type B

  Type B (90% cases) Type A (10% cases)

Autoimmune disease
Site Antral Predominant Fundus and body with antral sparing
Acid Production Normal to increased Decreased (achlorhydria)
Gastrin Normal to increased Increased (hypergastrinemia)
HLA No association HLA DR3, HLA B8
Serology Antibodies to H. pylori

Sensitive: Anti-parietal antibodies

Specific: Anti-IF antibodies
Cytokines involved

IL-1, IL-8

Long term sequelae

questions.text: A young woman presented with a history of discharge from the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo syndrome. 

Patients with petrositis may present with Gradenigo syndrome. Gradenigo syndrome is a triad with the following symptoms:

  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve VI  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve V involvement
  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger sign is edema over the mastoid, which is secondary to the thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint dislocation. Patient presents with neck pain and torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text:
A neonate was brought by his mother with complaints of non-passage of stools and abdominal distension. After a detailed examination, he was suspected to have an inherited autosomal recessive disorder resulting from a CFTR gene mutation. Identify the surgery performed in this case, as shown in the image given below.

CFTR - Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator
questions.solution:
The image given above shows Bishop-Koop anastomosis and Mikulicz enterostomy done for meconium ileus (as seen in the cystic fibrosis case described here).

Meconium ileus, also known as distal intestinal obstructive syndrome (DIOS), is defined as intestinal obstruction due to inspissated meconium within the terminal ileum. 

In the Bishop-Koop procedure, the proximal distended limb is joined to the side of the distal small bowel. This is vented by a chimney to the abdominal wall. The Bishop-Koop operation with its irrigating stoma is now only rarely used.

Other options:

Option B: Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard operation for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Option C: The Kasai procedure is done for biliary atresia.

Option D: The Duhamel, Soave, and Swenson procedures are done for Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding monkey pox is false?

choices.text: Patient needs to wear a triple layer mask during isolation.
Contact monitoring must be done for a period of 21 days from day of contact.
During ambulance transfer, the accompanying personnel should wear long-sleeved gowns, N95 Mask, gloves, and goggles.
It is caused by an enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.solution:
All the statements mentioned above are true about monkeypox, except that it is caused by an enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus.

Monkeypox is caused by an enveloped double-stranded DNA virus, which belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus of the Poxviridae family.

The natural reservoir is unknown. The incubation period can range from 5 to 21 days. The period of communicability is 1–2 days prior to the onset of the rash until all scabs fall off/ subside. Both human-to-human and animal-to-human transmission is known to occur.

People with monkeypox get a rash that may be located on or near the genitals (penis, testicles, labia, and vagina) or anus and could be on other areas like the hands, feet, chest, face, or mouth.

At first, the rash may resemble acne or blister and may be painful or itchy. Before the rash heals, it will go through a number of stages, including scabs.

The image given below shows the stages of the monkeypox lesion.

Other signs and symptoms of monkeypox include fever with chills, enlarged lymph nodes, back, and muscle aches, headache, and respiration symptoms like sore throat, nasal congestion, or cough.

Management includes patient isolation, protection of compromised skin and mucous membranes, rehydration therapy, and nutritional support.

Patient Isolation

  • Isolate the patient in a room with separate ventilation.
  • The patient should wear a triple-layer mask.
  • Cover skin lesions as much as possible, with measures such as using long sleeves and long pants, to minimize the risk of contact.
  • Continue isolation until all lesions resolve and scabs completely fall off.

Contact monitoring

  • Contact monitoring must be done for a period of 21 days from the day of contact.
  • Asymptomatic exposed health workers do not need to be excluded from work but should be under active surveillance for 21 days.

During ambulance transfer, accompanying personnel should wear long-sleeved gowns, N95 masks, gloves, and goggles.

questions.text: A 30-year-old electrician was brought to the casualty after getting electrocuted. You examine him and find no signs of life but still try to resuscitate him with cardiac massage and artificial respiration, as you suspect suspended animation. Which of the following conditions would you least expect suspended animation to be associated with?
questions.solution:
Suspended animation is least likely to be associated with garroting. Suspended animation is a condition where signs of life are absent as functions are interrupted for some time or are reduced to a minimum. In such cases, however, life continues and resuscitation is successful. Because the metabolic rate is so low, individual cell oxygen requirements are met by using oxygen dissolved in body fluids.

It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Severe syncopal attack
  • After anesthesia
  • Cholera
  • Concussion
  • Drowning
  • Electrocution
  • Hypothermia
  • Insanity
  • Newborn infants
  • Narcotic Poisoning
  • Shock
  • Sunstroke

The patient can be resuscitated with a cardiac massage or electric stimulator and artificial respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the ear develops from all the three germ layers?
questions.solution:
The tympanic membrane is derived from all three germ layers.

The tympanic membrane is formed by the apposition of the tubotympanic recess of the 1st pharyngeal pouch with the 1st pharyngeal cleft.

  • The outer layer of the tympanic membrane is derived from the ectoderm at the bottom of the external auditory meatus (1st pharyngeal cleft).
  • The inner layer of the tympanic membrane is derived from the endoderm lining the tympanic cavity (1st pharyngeal pouch).
  • The middle layer of the tympanic membrane is connective tissue derived from the mesoderm.

Related Pearl: Embryology of the ear

Structures of the ear Embryological origin
Auricle or pinna 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch
External auditory meatus 1st pharyngeal arch
Tympanic membrane All 3 germ layers
Malleus and incus 1st pharyngeal arch
Stapes suprastructure 2nd pharyngeal arch
Stapes footplate and annular ligament Otic capsule
Tympanic cavity 1st pharyngeal pouch
Eustachian tube 1st pharyngeal pouch
Membranous labyrinth Otic vesicle
Semicircular canals and utricle Pars superior
Saccule and cochlea Pars inferior

questions.text: A neonatology study was conducted between 2 groups of newborns by measuring their weights. Assigning the neonates to 2 groups was based on whether their mothers did or did not receive food supplements during the antenatal period. Which of the following statistical tests can be used to correlate the means obtained?
questions.solution:
The above study tests the difference between the sample means of 2 independent groups (weights of newborns of mothers who did or did not receive food supplements in the antenatal period). Student’s t-test (unpaired t-test) can be used to compare the means of 2 groups that are independent of each other.

Means can only be calculated for quantitative variables; hence, we use the parametric tests here. The type of parametric test to be used depends on the number of groups being tested.

Other options:

Option A- Paired t-test is used for a single sample to test the difference between two paired results. 

Option C- ANOVA method is used to assess the relative size of variance among the group means compared to the average variance within the groups. ANOVA is used to compare means among three or more groups.

Option D- Chi-square test is a non-parametric test used to analyze the differences when two dependable variables are measured at a nominal level.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision. The patient's fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a diabetic patient with the blurring of vision and an FFA image showing a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region.

CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop. Treatment includes topical anti-prostaglandins (ketorolac), steroids, systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral acetazolamide), and managing the causative factor. Given below is an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. Patients complain of sudden onset painless loss of vision, micropsia, and metamorphopsia. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stick pattern. OCT image of central serous retinopathy is seen below which neurosensory retinal detachment and accompanying small detachments of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Option B: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. Causes include trauma, CME, or idiopathic. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. OCT image of the macular hole is seen below which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina.

Option D: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a bilateral disease affecting people who are above 50 years of age. It can be exudative or non-exudative types. There can be a gradual or sudden loss of vision depending on the type of AMD. Drusens (yellowish-white elevated spots caused by extracellular deposits in the macular region) of various types can be noted. FFA shows punctate hyperfluorescence due to the drusen. OCT and FFA image of drusens is shown below:

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presents with anemia. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. His peripheral blood smear is similar to that shown in the illustration below. Which of the following additional abnormalities is expected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows spherocytes on the peripheral blood smear. A history of anemia along with a family history of splenectomy strongly suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies is an additional abnormality that can be expected here.

Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to defects in ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2 proteins, leading to a defect in the red cell membrane that causes red cells to transform into spherocytes.

The patients usually present with anemia, gallstones, splenomegaly, and jaundice. Aplastic crisis might occur due to parvovirus infection. 

Spherocytosis is the common finding, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. Other features are increased reticulocyte count, Howell-Jolly bodies which are dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs, marrow erythroid hyperplasia, and hemosiderosis. 

Laboratory findings are increased normal or slight decrease in mean corpuscular volume (MCV), increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC >34), and increased red cell distribution width (RDW >14%).

Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. 

Heinz bodies are denatured precipitates that cause damage to the RBC membrane. These cells passing through splenic cords get the characteristic appearance of bite cells. They are seen in cases of chemical poisoning, drug toxicity, and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. 

The image below shows Heinz bodies and bite cells.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic man takes a low-dose aspirin daily due to cardiovascular risk. The absorption of aspirin in the stomach is an example of which type of transport?
questions.solution:
The absorption of salicylates like aspirin in the stomach is an example of nonionic diffusion.

  • Some weak acids and bases are quite soluble in cell membranes in the undissociated form, but they cannot cross membranes in the charged (i.e. dissociated) form. Consequently, molecules of the undissociated substance diffuse from one side of the membrane to the other and then dissociate. This phenomenon is called nonionic diffusion.

Examples

  • Ammonia excretion in collecting ducts
  • Excretion of weak acids and bases in the kidney
  • Absorption of salicylates in the stomach
  • Absorption of bile acids in the distal ileum

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with painful lesions as shown below. On examination, he has multiple deep ulcers over the shaft of the penis, which are non-indurated with soft ragged margins, as shown in the image given below. He also had unilateral tender lymphadenopathy. He has no history of fever or allergy to any medication. Which kit will you use to treat him?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of unilateral tender lymphadenopathy along with the image showing multiple non-indurated soft painful ulcers with ragged edges are suggestive of chancroid due to Hemophilus ducreyi. It is treated with a white kit.

The white kit or kit number 3 is for non-herpetic genital ulcers. It contains:

  • 1 vial of injection benzathine penicillin (2.4 MU) and
  • A tablet of azithromycin 1 gm single dose 

If the patient is allergic to penicillin, we have to give him a blue kit or kit number 4 which contains a tab. doxycycline 100 mg bid for 15 days and azithromycin 1 gm single dose. 

All sexual partners should be treated. Abstinence during treatment is preferred, or condoms should be used. 

Chancroid is predominantly seen in sexually active young individuals in the age group of 21–30 years. Its incubation period is 4–10 days.

Initially, erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation. It will suddenly become a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins. This is termed a soft chancre. 

Due to the direct contact between adjacent areas, multiple ulcers occur and are termed kissing ulcers. These ulcers have a size of 1–2 cm and have a friable base with yellow-grey exudate that bleeds when abraded. The lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months if left untreated.

Unilateral tender regional lymphadenopathy develops in most patients with chancroid. Within 1 to 2 weeks of the presenting papules will progress to manifest suppurative buboes that rupture spontaneously.

Note: Herpetic genital ulcers are often severe. They are multiple grouped vesicles that rupture easily leaving painful erosions and ulcers. They are associated with systemic symptoms such as fever and myalgia. A red kit containing 400 mg acyclovir tablets given 3 times daily for 7 days is provided for herpetic genital ulcers.

Other options: 

Option A: Green kit is used when there is abnormal vaginal discharge, burning while passing urine, increased frequency of micturition, or lower backache. 

Option C: Blue kit is also used for non-herpetic genital ulcers but is for those who are allergic to penicillin. It has doxycycline 100 mg instead. 

Option D: Black kit is used for inguinal bubo which presents as swelling in the inguinal region with preceding history of genital ulcer or discharge, fever, and malaise.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the type of receptor shown in the image?

choices.text: It responds to a change in the strength of a stimulus.

questions.solution:
The sensory receptor shown in the above image is a Pacinian corpuscle. The Pacinian corpuscle is a rapidly adapting receptor.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of a nerve ending that is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving them an onion-like appearance. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly. They respond to a change in the strength of the stimulus. 

When a stimulus of the same strength is continuously given to a sensory receptor, the frequency of the action potentials generated by the receptor gradually decreases. This phenomenon is known as receptor adaptation. Depending on whether the receptor stops responding to a stimulus rapidly or slowly, they are classified as rapidly adapting (phasic) or slow-adapting receptors (tonic).

The image below shows the histological appearance of a Pacinian corpuscle.

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: A schizophrenia patient is being delivered olanzapine by a Z-track technique. From the given images, identify the route of injection in which the Z-track technique is used.
questions.solution:
Route A shows the intramuscular administration of medication and the Z track technique is used for this route of administration.

Procedure:

  • Stretch the skin by pulling it laterally away from the intended point of injection.
  • Insert the needle into the site at a 90˚angle, aspirate by pulling back to see if the needle has a penetrated vessel.
  • If blood is aspirated withdraw the needle, and repeat the procedure at another site with new equipment and medication.
  • If no blood is aspirated administer the injection.
  • Wait for 10 seconds and then withdraw the needle, and release the skin allowing the displaced tissue to seal the needle track.


Other options:

1. Intravenous injection (Figure C) e.g. injection ferric carboxymaltose

2. Subcutaneous injection (Figure B) e.g. injection insulin glargine

3. Intra-dermal route (Figure D) e.g. injection platelet-activating factor


Angle to be maintained between skin and needle for various injection techniques:

INJECTION TECHNIQUE ANGLE BETWEEN NEEDLE AND SKIN REMARKS
Intra-muscular 90 degrees Darting movement
Intra-dermal 15 degrees  
Sub-cutaneous

Long needles - 45 degrees

Short needle - 90 degrees

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is diagnosed with epilepsy and is started on phenytoin for management. She presented to the emergency with abdominal pain, dysuria, and hypertension. She was confused and disoriented. A provisional diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria was made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

ALA - δ-aminolevulinic acid

PBG - porphobilinogen

choices.text: ALA and PBG increased in urine and plasma

questions.solution:
Blistering skin lesions are not seen in acute intermittent porphyria. They are characteristic features of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). 

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a hepatic porphyria inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It occurs due to a deficiency of HMB-synthase/uroporphyrinogen I synthase enzyme in heme synthesis. AIP is generally latent before puberty and is more common in women. 

Reduced carbohydrate intake during fasting or illness can precipitate acute attacks of AIP. This occurs due to the upregulation of ALA synthase 1 (ALAS1) by hepatic peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ coactivator 1α (PGC-1α), thus increasing heme biosynthesis. Attacks can also be provoked by infections, surgery, and ethanol. A large number of drugs are classically known to precipitate AIP.

AIP presents with neurovisceral symptoms and no cutaneous manifestations are seen. The clinical features of AIP include:

  • Abdominal pain is the most common symptom.
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Tachycardia, restlessness, tremors, and excess sweating are due to sympathetic overactivity
  • Psychiatric symptoms like anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation, hallucinations, and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures
  • Proximal muscle weakness and sensory loss
  • Dysuria and urinary retention
  • Persistant hypertension

Diagnosis can be made with the appearance of classic symptomology after exposure to an underlying precipitating factor. Plasma and urine ALA and PBG levels are significantly raised during an acute attack and remain high even after symptoms resolve.

Management of AIP:

  • Intravenous hematin as first-line treatment
  • Narcotic analgesia for abdominal pain
  • Phenothiazine for nausea, vomiting, restlessness, and anxiety
  • Carbohydrate loading with intravenous glucose
  • Removal of precipitating factors
  • Orthoptic liver transplant is curative in patients refractory to hemin therapy.

Blistering skin lesions are characteristic features of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). PCT is a cutaneous porphyria caused due to deficient uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase enzyme. It predominantly presents with cutaneous features like blisters, milia, hypertrichosis, and hyperpigmentation over sun-exposed areas. Neurologic features are absent.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:

questions.text: A patient presents with muscle cramps after exercise. His routine investigations revealed a hemolytic anemia type of picture. Which of the following glycogen storage disease is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features, the patient is most likely to be suffering from Tarui's disease.

It is characterized by a deficiency of muscle and erythrocyte phosphofructokinase 1. This results in abnormal glycogen metabolism and hence muscle cannot generate energy after exercise using glycogen reserves which leads to exercise intolerance. The process of glycolysis is not complete and hence glucose is not available for anaerobic catabolism. Hence there is no rise in lactate after exercise.

Since the same type of enzyme is deficient in erythrocytes their metabolism is also affected, leading to hemolytic anemia.

A similar muscle picture is seen in McArdle's disease (Option A), but in this disease, hemolytic anemia type of picture is not seen.

Other relevant glycogen storage diseases are described in the pearl below.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with breathing difficulty, poor feeding, and constipation. Upon examination, the physician notes a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. The mother gives a recent history of feeding honey. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of infant botulism. The toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine.

Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins. These are required for the exocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles. Thus, it leads to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal transmission.

The image given below shows the site of action of botulinum toxin.

Botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, and is of three types:

  • Foodborne botulism
  • Infant botulism
  • Wound botulism

Infant botulism is also called floppy baby syndrome. It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months. It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxins.

Affected children usually present with paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weak, altered cry, and loss of head control.

Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxins or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

The image given below shows Gram staining of Clostridium botulinum.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child being evaluated in a primary health center is found to have disfigured lips due to constant biting, inability to walk, dystonia, spasticity, and choreoathetosis. He has been diagnosed with a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to have Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is an X-linked disorder characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). 

Developmental delays with hyperuricemia are typical of this syndrome. Symptoms are predominantly neurological and these include hypotonia and developmental delay which become apparent before the child is 4 months old. Dystonia appears before the child is 1 year old and progresses to a point where the child cannot attain milestones like crawling and walking. Involuntary movements such as choreoathetosis develop within the first few years of life. Pyramidal signs like spasticity and hyperreflexia can also be observed by then.

Self-injurious behavior is the hallmark of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. The most commonly noted ones include biting of lips, fingers, and cheeks, causing profound disfigurement. There might also be a history of aggressive behavior like pinching, spitting, grabbing, hitting, or verbally abusing. Nephrolithiasis and gouty arthritis occur due to hyperuricemia.

Increased serum uric acid (>8 mg/dL) is found. Blood investigations generally show features of megaloblastic anemia.

Allopurinol, a drug that blocks the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme, is the mainstay of treatment for hyperuricemia and its complications. Pyramidal signs such as spasticity can be managed with the use of benzodiazepines or baclofen. Physical rehabilitation with walking aids, and devices to maintain posture, help prevent deformities.

Behavioral symptoms are managed with psychiatric, and medical interventions.

Other options: 

Option B: Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome is characterized by a partial deficiency of HGPRT. It is also associated with hyperuricemia but there are no neurological complications associated with it.

Option C: Orotic aciduria type I is characterized by a deficiency of the enzymes orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidylic acid decarboxylase.

Option D: Orotic aciduria type II is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme orotidylic acid decarboxylase.

questions.text: A patient with a phobic disorder is undergoing systematic desensitization therapy. This therapy includes all the following steps, except ____.
questions.solution:
Flooding is not a part of systematic desensitization.

Systematic desensitization is based on the behavioral principle of counterconditioning and was developed by Joseph Wolpe. Counterconditioning involves a gradual approach to a feared situation, in a psychophysiological state that inhibits anxiety, to overcome the maladaptive anxiety elicited by that situation. It works best in cases of a clearly identifiable anxiety-provoking stimulus. It has been successfully used in the treatment of phobias, obsessions, compulsions, and certain sexual disorders.

It consists of three steps:

  • Relaxation training - Patients attain a state of complete relaxation and are then exposed to the stimulus that elicits the anxiety response. Relaxation methods like yoga, progressive relaxation, hypnosis, and mental imagery can be used. The physiological changes during the relaxation process; slow heart rate, increased peripheral blood flow, and neuromuscular stability; are opposite to that of the adrenergic response invoked during anxiety. The relaxed state inhibits the negative reaction of anxiety associated with the phobia and this is known as reciprocal inhibition. 
  • Hierarchy construction - The therapist determines all the conditions that elicit anxiety and the patients prepare a graded list or hierarchy of 10-12 fear-provoking scenes in the order of increasing anxiety.
  • Desensitization of the stimulus - Patients proceed systematically through the list from the least to the most anxiety-provoking scene while in a deeply relaxed state.

Flooding involves repeated and prolonged exposure to fear cues of high intensity without a hierarchy. It is based on the premise that anxiety gets reinforced by conditioning when the patient escapes from the anxiety-provoking situation. Patients are encouraged to face the feared situations directly and are prevented from escaping. There is no gradual build-up or use of relaxation techniques.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. Exposure or anticipation of contact with the situation/object triggers an anxiety reaction. This inadvertently leads to panic attacks in people who are susceptible. The person goes to great lengths to avoid this situation or object. According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5th edition (DSM-5),  phobias are classified under Anxiety disorders.

Behavior therapy is considered the most effective treatment for phobias. Systemic desensitization is the most common behavior therapy used for phobias. Other modes of treatment of phobias include insight-oriented psychotherapy, virtual therapy, hypnosis, and family therapy.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone
 

Related Pearl: Specific phobia

Present in 10% of the population.

Clinical features:

  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for > 6 months
  • Usually develops in childhood, can develop after a traumatic event
  • Avoidance behavior

Treatment:

  • Behavioral therapy (exposure-based, systematic desensitization) is the treatment of choice
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines may help acutely

questions.text:
A 27-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever with chills, headache, fatigue, and weakness for the past 6 days. Laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin level, reticulocytosis, and increased unconjugated bilirubin level. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this disease?

1. It is transmitted by ixodid tick.

2. Sporozoites are the infective form for humans.

3. Man is the definitive host.

4. The ring forms are rarely seen.

5. Schizonts and gametocytes are absent.
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the microscopic image showing tetrads arranged in Maltese cross formation, which is pathognomonic of babesiosis. The correct statements regarding babesiosis are 1, 2, and 5.

Babesia:

Babesia, a genus of protozoan organisms that includes Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, are responsible for babesiosis. Ixodid ticks are the definitive host. Man is an intermediate host. Sporozoites are the infective form for humans.

The mode of infection is through a tick bite. Occasionally it can also be through blood transfusion.

The majority of the clinical symptoms are predominantly caused by hemolysis of the infected erythrocytes. The illness develops 1-6 weeks after the tick bite. It might be a mild, self-limiting, asymptomatic, or severe sickness that resembles malaria.
Malaise, exhaustion, high-grade fever (38°C to 40.6°C) with chills and sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, a dry cough, and anorexia are symptoms of acute illness.

Complications of acute babesiosis include renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and congestive cardiac failure (CCF).

Diagnosis is made by the examination of blood films stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain.

  • Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic pyriform, or ring form simulating Plasmodium falciparum
  • The ring forms are the most common and lack the central hemozoin deposit.
  • Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads (Maltese crosses), which are pathognomonic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment of B. microti infection

  • Mild infection is treated with atovaquone along with azithromycin
  • Severe infections are treated with azithromycin along with atovaquone or clindamycin along with quinine
  • Exchange transfusion is required in patients with high-grade parasitemia (≥10%), severe anemia, and pulmonary, hepatic, or renal compromise.

Other Babesia infections are treated with a combination of clindamycin and quinine.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
