questions.text: A patient suffering from a dermatological condition undergoes a skin biopsy. The histological section of the skin taken from a patient is shown in the image given below. What is the patient most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows papillary tip microabscesses, which are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis.

Papillary tip microabscesses are mixed microabscesses that contain neutrophils and some eosinophils in the tips of the dermal papillae. They are seen in dermatitis herpetiformis and bullous eruptions like epidermolysis bullosa and the bullous form of lupus erythematosus.

The image given below shows papillary tip microabscesses.

Other options:

Option B: Psoriasis is characterized by Munro's microabscesses, which are neutrophilic microabscesses that are found in the stratum corneum. They are seen along with features of irregular epidermal thickening and parakeratosis.

The image given below shows epidermal hyperplasia with loss of the granular cell layer, parakeratosis, and Munro’s microabscesses suggestive of psoriasis.

Option C: Histology of pemphigus vulgaris shows a suprabasal split of the epidermis with a characteristic row of tombstone appearance as seen below.

Option D: Mycosis fungoides is characterized by Pautrier's microabscesses, which are intraepidermal lymphocytic microabscesses in the absence of marked spongiosis. The cells within the epidermis may show nuclear hyperchromatism or atypia.

The image given below shows histological markers seen in mycosis fungoides.

Remember:  M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis) and P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease was diagnosed with high-grade dysplasia after upper GI endoscopy and biopsy. What will be your next step in management according to the Seattle protocol?
questions.solution:
According to the Seattle protocol, in a patient with high-grade dysplasia, radiofrequency ablation/argon photocoagulation/endoscopic mucosal resection is performed first, and then, the patient is followed up after 3 months.

Barrett's esophagus is a metaplastic change (squamous to columnar epithelium change) in the lower end of the esophagus as a result of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease. It increases the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma. 

 Barrett’s esophagus can be

  • Classical Barrett's esophagus - >3 cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.
  • Short segment  Barrett's esophagus - <3 cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.
  • Cardia metaplasia - microscopic Barrett’s in the GE junction. In cardia metaplasia, due to a lack of macroscopic changes, an endoscopic biopsy is difficult. So, chromoendoscopy is the ideal investigation. Here, mucosa is first stained by methylene blue to highlight abnormal mucosa.

On endoscopy, Barrett's is recognized as areas of red, velvety mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction. Such areas alternate with normal pale squamous esophageal mucosa. Diagnostic confirmation is by endoscopic biopsy. Biopsy reveals intestinal metaplasia characterized by the presence of goblet cells. Goblet cells are seen as cells with pale mucous vacuoles that stain blue.

The Seattle protocol is ideally followed to detect early dysplastic changes in Barrett's esophagus. Here, a 4 quadrant biopsy specimen is taken 1-2 cm apart throughout the area of intestinal metaplasia.

  • No signs of dysplasia - continue 2 yearly surveillance. 
  • Low-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 6 monthly surveillance
  • High-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 3 monthly surveillance

APC - Argon photocoagulation

RFA - Radiofrequency ablation

EMR - Endoscopic mucosal resection

Lugol’s iodine is used for squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 1.5 kg male baby was delivered vaginally at 32 weeks of gestation. The infant was cyanotic and required CPAP immediately after delivery. His chest radiograph is shown below. A deficiency of which of the following is the likely cause for the condition?
questions.solution:
A preterm infant requiring resuscitation at birth with cyanosis and diffuse bilateral opacities on chest radiography is suggestive of infant respiratory distress syndrome. It is caused by a deficiency of dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine. 

Dipalmitoyl lecithin or dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is a major component of lung surfactant. In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus and increases compliance.

Mature levels of surfactant are present after 35 weeks of gestation. Thus, preterm babies are at risk of surfactant deficiency, leading to infant respiratory distress syndrome. Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.

Other options -

Option 1: Phosphatidylethanolamine, also called cephalin, is found in the cell membranes of nervous tissue, particularly in the brain.

Option 3: Diphosphatidyl glycerol, also called cardiolipin, is found in the inner membrane of mitochondria and plays a key role in apoptosis.

Option 4: Phosphatidylinositol present in the cell membrane acts as a precursor of hormone secondary messengers and platelet-activating factor.

Related Pearl: Pulmonary Surfactant Composition

Constituents

Percentage

Phospholipids, mainly dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)

70% to 80%

Proteins

10%

Neutral lipids

10%

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of eye ache and decreasing vision in his left eye. He underwent phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation in the same eye 2 days back. Examination of his left eye appears as shown in the image given below. A slit lamp examination revealed cells and flares in the anterior chamber. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing inflammation of the eyeball and hypopyon, in a patient 2 days after cataract surgery is suggestive of acute postoperative endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation, which predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e., the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common organism involved in pathogenesis.

Clinically, patients present with symptoms of pain, swelling of the eyelid, decrease in vision 48 to 72 hours after surgery.

Signs include conjunctival chemosis, corneal edema and haziness, and hypopyon due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Slit-lamp examination usually reveals white blood cells (cells) and protein (flare) within the anterior chamber. The diagnosis is confirmed by positive aqueous or vitreous culture.

Intravitreal injections of antibiotics like ceftazidime and vancomycin should be administered immediately after culture specimens have been obtained. Other treatments include:

  • Topical antibiotic
  • Topical mydriatics and cycloplegics
  • Oral steroids
  • Pars plana vitrectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Toxic anterior segment syndrome (TASS) is a sterile postoperative inflammation of the anterior segment caused by either the ethylene gas used for sterilizing intraocular lens (in early cases) or by the lens material (in late cases). It is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, no hypopyon, and no vitreal inflammation. It responds well to steroids.

Option B: Anterior scleritis is characterized by edema and inflammation of the sclera and is more commonly associated with autoimmune conditions.

Option C: Posterior capsular opacification also called after cataract, is the opacification that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens particles left over from surgery.

The illustration given below shows different types of after-cataract.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A victim of a road traffic accident is brought to the casualty department. Which of the following is a part of step 'D' under A-B-C-D-E of trauma care?

choices.text: GCS scoring for basic neurologic evaluation

questions.solution:
GCS scoring for basic neurologic evaluation is a part of step D-Disability assessment of trauma care.

Steps in the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS):

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood - FBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done in pregnant women.

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: A young woman complains of excessive thirst, polyuria, and nocturia following a head injury. There is no glucosuria. Her urine osmolarity is found to be 290 mOsm/L, and her 24-hour urine output is 2.75 L. The patient was asked not to consume any fluids. After 4 hours, the urine osmolality was measured to be 600 mOsm/L. MRI showed a bright spot in the posterior pituitary.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is primary polydipsia.

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has polyuria, nocturia, and polydipsia without glucosuria. Her urine osmolality is initially low (<300 mosm/L) but increases after the fluid restriction (400–800 mosmol/L). The MRI showed a bright spot in the posterior pituitary. These findings favor the diagnosis.

Primary polydipsia means excessive intake of fluids. It can occur as a result of

  • inappropriate thirst mechanism - dipsogenic diabetes insipidus
  • as a part of psychosis - psychogenic polydipsia
  • due to increased water intake owing to its health benefits - iatrogenic polydipsia

Excessive water intake results in decreased plasma osmolality and sodium levels, decreasing the antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion. There is a compensatory increase in urine volume and a decrease in urine osmolality.

In patients with primary polydipsia, fluid restriction increases and brings back the plasma osmolality and sodium to normal. This increases the levels of ADH, which results in increased urinary osmolality.

In most healthy adults, the posterior pituitary emits a hyperintense signal visible in the MRI as a bright spot. This is visualized in patients with primary polydipsia and is abnormal or absent in patients with central diabetes insipidus.

Other options:

Option A: Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused due to deficiency of ADH secretion. In this condition, the levels of ADH do not increase even after fluid restriction and therefore the urine osmolality will not increase. 

Option B: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs due to decreased action of ADH. Mutations occur in the V2 receptor or the aquaporin channels and ADH cannot act on them. Therefore, in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, even if the ADH levels are normal, it cannot act on the receptors, and the urine osmolality does not increase after fluid restriction. A simpler way to differentiate between central DI and nephrogenic DI is to measure basal ADH levels and urine osmolality under unrestricted fluid intake conditions. A low urine osmolality with a concurrent elevated ADH level (>1 ng/mL) indicates nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. A low ADH level is suggestive of central DI or primary polydipsia, which can be differentiated on MRI brain.

Option C: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion results in increased secretions of ADH. Therefore, the patients will have decreased urine output and increased urine concentration. If the water intake is not restricted, patients also develop hyponatremia.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. There is no history of trauma or fall. He gives a history of unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma commonly arising from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here, the tumor grows into the

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

Diagnosis is based on the clinical picture. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (antral sign/Holman-Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.

MRI can also be done that reveals soft tissue extensions. Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system also. Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

Given below is a CT image showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

 

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with an erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in the glomus tumor when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

questions.text: A statistician is working with a gynecologist on a study about “Awareness regarding Pap smear.” They administer a questionnaire with 50 questions to 200 women, and each correct response gets 1 point. They find that the data are positively skewed. Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively, of the same?
questions.solution:
In a positively skewed data set, mean>median>mode. Hence, here, the mean, median, and mode must be 25, 23, and 20, respectively. None of the other options is consistent with mean > median > mode.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there is an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is demonstrated in the graph below:

 

Other options:

Option A: In a negatively skewed distribution, mean<median<mode.

Option C: In a normal distribution, mean=median=mode.

Option D: The set of values is not representative of either a normal or a skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has moderate hypertension for the past few years. The given image shows a section of a small blood vessel of this patient. What is the finding seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyaline arteriolosclerosis. Homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with narrowing of the lumen is seen in the above slide.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis, which is the thickening of the vessel wall with loss of its elasticity. It has two variants:

  • Hyaline arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in chronic hypertension. Chronic changes in blood pressure damage the vessel wall leading to the deposition of plasma proteins and matrix. On microscopy, it appears as a homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with the narrowing of the lumen. It is also seen in elderly patients (normotensive or hypertensive) and diabetes mellitus.
  • Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in severe hypertension. Microscopy shows a characteristic concentric, laminated (onion peel appearance) thickening of the vessel wall with luminal narrowing. It is the characteristic vascular lesion of severe hypertension.

In medium and large vessels it can lead to degenerative changes and can cause aortic dissection and cerebrovascular hemorrhage.

The image below shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

Monckeberg medial sclerosis is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically involving the internal elastic lamina. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is usually an incidental finding. 

The following image shows Monckeberg medial sclerosis of an artery.

Atherosclerotic plaque is yellow-tan that is raised above the vessel wall. It occurs due to intimal thickening and lipid accumulation. The lumen appears irregular. The given image shows atherosclerosis:

Related Pearl: Revised 2017 ACC guidelines on Hypertension:

  Systolic BP (mm Hg) Diastolic BP (mm Hg) Management
Normal  < 120 < 80 Lifestyle modification
Elevated BP 120 -129 < 80 Lifestyle modification
Stage 1 HT 130 -139 (or) 80 -89

Lifestyle modification(Antihypertensive medication only if

  • Previous stroke / CAD / Heart attack
  • Diabetic
  • CKD
Stage 2 HT > 140 (or)  > 90 Anti-hypertensive medication + Lifestyle modification
Hypertensive crisis > 180 (or) >120 Patients needing prompt changes in medication if there are no other indications of problems, or immediate hospitalization if there are signs of organ damage.

Related Pearl: Onion Skin Appearance in Pathology

Onion skin appearance:

A pattern characterised by concentric laminations of differing radiologic or histologic densities. It is seen in:

  1. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: Onion skin fibrosis
  2. Castleman disease: Onion skin appearance of Mantle zone lymphocytes
  3. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Onion skin lesions in spleen
  4. Thrombotic thrombocytopenia purpura (TTP): Onion skinning of renal arteries and arterioles
  5. Ewing sarcoma: Laminated periosteal reaction (onion skin)
  6. Malignant hypertension: Onion skin lesion/ Hyperplastic arteriolitis
  7. Tay–Sach's disease: Whorled arrangement (onion skin) of cytoplasmic inclusions within lysosomes of ganglion cells under electron microscopy
  8. Lyme arthritis: Onion skin thickening of the arterial wall
  9. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) and Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease: Onion bulb formation of proliferated Schwann cells around the axon due to recurrent demyelination and remyelination

questions.text: An autopsy conducted on a patient who died of pulmonary embolism showed thrombosis of deep veins of the legs. Which finding suggests an antemortem venous thrombosis?

choices.text: Red thrombus with lines of Zahn
White thrombus with lines of Zahn
Red thrombus with "chicken fat" upper portion
White thrombus with "chicken fat" upper portion

questions.solution:
Red thrombus with lines of Zahn is suggestive of antemortem venous thrombosis.

Antemortem clots: They have microscopic laminations called lines of Zahn, which have pale layers (platelet and fibrin) alternating with dark (RBC-rich) layers signifying their formation in flowing blood.

The images given below show the lines of Zahn:

 

Postmortem clots: They are bland and nonlaminated. They are gelatinous and have a dark red lower portion, where RBCs settle down by gravity, and a yellow "chicken fat" upper portion.

Related Pearl: Arterial and Venous Thrombi

Feature Arterial thrombus Venous thrombus
Pathogenesis Endothelial injury or site of turbulence Stasis of blood
Blood flow Associated with active blood flow Associated with sluggish blood flow
Sites Coronary, cerebral and femoral arteries Superficial and deep leg veins, ovarian periuterine veins
Propagation Grows in a retrograde manner from point of attachment Grows in an antegrade manner from point of attachment
Line of Zahn Present Present
Microscopic

Friable meshwork of platelets, fibrin, red cells, and degenerating leukocytes (White thrombi).

 Red cells mixed with relatively less platelets, so also called as red thrombi
Occlusion Incomplete lumen occlusion Complete vessel occlusion
Complications Ischemia and infarction of organs Embolism, edema and ulceration

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions are also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease:

It is a mild exanthematous fever that usually occurs in children, but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles.

The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the feco-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

Coxsackieviruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types, and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include -

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) 
  • Herpangina - It is febrile vesicular pharyngitis. It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, palate, or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Aseptic meningitis

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include -

  • Pleurodynia or Bornholm disease- It is viral myalgia defined by sudden severe lancinating pain, typically on one side of the chest. It is commonly associated with fever, malaise, and headaches. 
  • Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn.
  • Orchitis, juvenile diabetes

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet: 

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus causes impetigo. It is characterized by sores around the mouth and the nose and typically forms a honey-colored scab. It is more commonly seen in children. It is not associated with lesions on palms and soles.

The image given below shows impetigo.

Option C: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) is a T-lymphotropic human herpes virus transmitted via saliva. It may cause roseola infantum/ sixth disease/ exanthem subitum in infants and young children. Roseola infantum is primarily caused by HHV-6.

The image given below shows typical rashes in an infant with exanthem subitum.

Option D: Poxvirus causes molluscum contagiosum in children and young adults. It is characterized by pink or pearly white wart-like nodules with central umbilication on the skin. 

The image given below shows molluscum contagiosum lesions.

questions.text: A female patient underwent surgery under general anesthesia 2 days ago. On the first postoperative day, her liver enzymes were elevated, and she developed jaundice. It was diagnosed that she developed hepatitis due to halothane, which was used during surgery. What type of hepatic damage is usually seen in this type of halothane hepatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common type of hepatic damage that occurs in halothane hepatitis is centrilobular necrosis.

Halothane is commonly known to be associated with complications such as hepatotoxicity and massive hepatic necrosis. Other volatile anesthetics, including enflurane, isoflurane, and desflurane, have also been associated with fulminant hepatic necrosis, but compared with toxicity due to halothane, potentially fatal toxicity from the administration of these newer volatile anesthetics is rare.

Clinical types: Clinical exposure to halothane is associated with two distinct types of hepatic injury:

  • Subclinical hepatotoxicity: It is characterized by mild postoperative elevations in alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase, but is reversible and innocuous.
  • Halothane hepatitis: It is a fulminant form of hepatotoxicity, characterized by elevated alanine aminotransferase, aspartate aminotransferase, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels, and massive hepatic necrosis following the administration of halothane.

Mechanism of injury:

Halothane-induced hepatitis is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction associated with the oxidative metabolism of halothane. This causes the release of a highly reactive trifluoroacetyl (TFA) chloride metabolite that cross-reacts with nearby liver proteins resulting in the formation of TFA-modified proteins. The TFA-modified proteins serve as neoantigens and the antibodies against them are attributed to liver injury.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane 
Most epileptogenic   Enflurane
Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the cylinder shown below, attached to an anesthetic machine present in the operation theater.  All of the following are the adverse effects of exposure to this inhalational agent, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a blue color cylinder, and these cylinders are used to store nitrous oxide. Iron-deficiency anemia is not a side effect of nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide inhibits vitamin B12-dependent enzymes like thymidylate synthase, which is necessary for DNA synthesis. This leads to megaloblastic bone marrow changes.

Megaloblastic anemia is seen with nitrous oxide, especially when exposure is greater than 2–6 hours (in healthy patients prolonged periods of exposure >12 hours are required whereas, in critically ill patients, much shorter periods of exposure can lead to megaloblastic changes in the bone marrow).

Other side effects of nitrous oxide:

  • Bone marrow depression
  • Subacute combined degeneration of the cord (myelinopathy)
  • Teratogenicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Contraindications of nitrous oxide:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Pneumothorax
  • Acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention
  • Intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography)
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane

8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought by his parents with complaints of profuse bloody diarrhea and rectal pain. Stool examination revealed bile-stained eggs with mucous plugs at both ends. Which of the following is false about the causative organism?

choices.text: It causes rectal prolapse in children
Albendazole is used in the treatment
The egg has a terminal spine
Adult worms are found in cecum and ascending colon

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with stool examination showing bile-stained eggs with mucous plugs at both ends is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura infection. All the statements mentioned above are true about Trichuris trichiura, except that the eggs do not have a terminal spine. 

The eggs of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. They are bile-stained and float in a saturated solution.

The infection is acquired by the ingestion of foods contaminated with infected eggs. Adult whipworm colonizes the cecum and colon of humans where a male and female mate and the female worm lays the eggs. They are passed in feces and become infective after 3 months.

The illustration given below shows the life cycle of Trichuris trichiura.

Clinical features can vary from asymptomatic infection in mild cases to lower abdominal pain and diarrhea in moderate infection. In severe cases, it can cause profuse diarrhea and rectal prolapse.

Diagnosis involves stool examination of eggs. 

Mebendazole, albendazole, and ivermectin can be used for treatment.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A patient had a painless episode of profuse per rectal bleeding. After initial stabilization, a colonoscopy was performed and the below finding was noted. Later on, this patient was diagnosed with Heyde's syndrome. Which cardiac valvular abnormality would be most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given endoscopic image is suggestive of angiodysplasia seen in Heyde's syndrome. The cardiac valvular abnormality most likely to be seen in this condition is aortic stenosis.

Heyde’s syndrome is a rare multisystem disorder characterized by the clinical triad of:

  • Aortic stenosis 
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia
  • Acquired type 2 vWD (secondary to valvular stenosis, returns to normal once the valve is replaced)

Angiodysplasia is a vascular malformation that commonly causes hemorrhage from the colon in patients over the age of 60 years. The cecum is the most common site of angiodysplasia followed by the colon. In the colon angiodysplasia can occur anywhere, however, it is more commonly found in the right colon than the transverse and the left colon. The malformations consist of dilated tortuous submucosal veins.

Investigations include colonoscopy which identifies small reddish, raised areas sizing a few millimetres. Selective superior and inferior mesenteric angiography shows the site and extent of the lesion by a 'blush' of contrast.

Treatment options rest on the principles of stabilizing the patient and localizing the bleeding with colonoscopy and argon laser. In severe uncontrolled bleeding, surgery is necessary.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He states that he has been having 4-5 non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. He denies any family history of colon cancer. A biopsy of the small bowel showed findings as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most commonly associated cancer?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the biopsy image showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and lamina propria infiltrates, indicates a case of celiac disease. The most common celiac disease-associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

Celiac disease/celiac sprue/gluten-sensitive enteropathy:

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). The gliadin peptide activates the epithelial cells to express IL-15, which in turn triggers activation and proliferation of CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes. This damages the epithelium and increases the passage of gliadin into the lamina propria, where gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation and worsen tissue damage.

Microscopic findings on biopsy of the proximal small intestine will show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes.

Clinically, patients with celiac disease present with malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, chronic refractory anemia, and marked unintentional weight loss. Some patients may also present with dermatitis herpetiformis characterized by herpes-like vesicles that are caused due to the deposition of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Antiendomysial and anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are found in serological studies. Symptoms can be reversed by a gluten-free diet.

In refractory cases of celiac disease, patients should be started on oral steroids (prednisolone). After induction of clinical remission, azathioprine can be added.

The below image shows a patient with dermatitis herpetiformis.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about CADASIL?

choices.text: It is characterized by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene.
Recurrent strokes and dementia are seen.

questions.solution:
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene. 

This leads to the misfolding of the extracellular domain of the NOTCH3 receptor that is preferentially expressed in vascular smooth muscle. It is clinically characterized by recurrent strokes (usually ischemic, less often hemorrhages) and dementia.

Arteries in the CNS and in other tissues such as skin show concentric thickening of the media and adventitia, loss of smooth muscle cells, and the presence of basophilic, periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive deposits. Deposits contain the misfolded NOTCH3 protein. These appear as osmiophilic compact granular material on electron microscopy and are consistently detected in the walls of affected vessels.

questions.text: You are a first-year student who has been asked to identify the hybrid muscle during dissection of the femoral triangle. Which of the following muscles could it be?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as 1 in the given image is the pectineus, which is a hybrid muscle. 

Muscles marked in the image:

1- Pectineus

2- Adductor longus

3- Vastus lateralis

4- Sartorius 

Muscles supplied by two different motor nerves with different root values are called hybrid or composite muscles.

The pectineus muscle is a hybrid or composite muscle because of its dual nerve supply. Its anterior fibers are innervated by the femoral nerve while posterior fibers are innervated by the anterior division of the obturator nerve. Other features of this nerve are:

  • Origin: Pecten pubis, the upper half of the pectineal surface of the superior ramus of the pubis and fascia covering the pectineus
  • Insertion: Line extending from lesser trochanter to linea Aspera
  • Function: It is a flexor and adductor of the thigh

Other hybrid muscles are:

  • Adductor Magnus: Supplied by the obturator nerve and tibial part of the sciatic nerve
  • Flexor digitorum profundus: Supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve and the ulnar nerve
  • Pectoralis major: Supplied by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Flexor pollicis brevis: Supplied by the recurrent motor branch of median nerve and the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Brachialis: Supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve and the radial nerve
  • Biceps femoris: The long head is supplied by the tibial part of the sciatic nerve, and the short head by the common fibular nerve
  • Digastric: The anterior belly is supplied by the mylohyoid branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and the posterior belly is supplied by the facial nerve

Other options:

Option B: Adductor longus is supplied by anterior division of the obturator nerve

Option C: Vastus lateralis is supplied by the femoral nerve

Option D: Sartorius is supplied by the femoral nerve

 

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient came with complaints of exertional breathlessness and fatigue for a few months. She gives a history of radiotherapy for carcinoma breast 6 months back. On examination,  bilateral lower limb pitting edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign were present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman presenting post-irradiation with progressive exertional dyspnea, bilateral lower extremity oedema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign is suggestive of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterised by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction.

Most of the cases are due to the infiltration of abnormal substances between myocytes like amyloidosis, abnormal metabolic products within myocytes as seen in hemochromatosis/Fabry's disease, or fibrotic injury like radiation/scleroderma.  

They often present with right-sided heart symptoms like oedema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration.

Kussmaul's sign 

Kussmaul's sign is a paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration. It is an indication of restrictive cardiomyopathy and is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Normally, during inspiration, the JVP falls due to negative intrathoracic pressure. When there is an impairment in the expansion of the right ventricle or a rise in the right atrial pressure, there is a back pressure of blood in the jugular veins. This causes a paradoxical rise in the JVP during inspiration instead of a fall.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy presents with symptoms and signs of left heart failure or biventricular heart failure. Patients show cardiomegaly, and a third heart sound can be auscultated. The most frequent causes are alcoholism, myocarditis, chemotherapy, and endocrinopathies. Echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. Examination reveals bisferiens carotid pulse. A fourth heart sound and variable systolic murmur can be auscultated. It is an inherited autosomal disease with variable penetrance. They are caused by mutation of the gene encoding for myosin heavy chains or proteins regulating calcium handling. The echocardiogram is the diagnostic tool. Any area of left ventricle thickness more than 1.5 cm confirms the disease.

Option D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy presents as acute anterior myocardial infarction, with acute chest pain or shortness of breath. It occurs soon after a high catecholamine surge and is seen predominantly in postmenopausal women.  Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronaries. The LV appears as a round ampulla, resembling the Japanese octopus pot called the takotsubo pot. Imaging reveals apical left ventricular ballooning due to myocardial stunning. 

The image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

questions.text: A car driver hit his right knee on the dashboard on the sudden application of the brake during a motor vehicle collision. He complains of pain and swelling in the right knee. On examination, there is an excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur on gently pulling the upper end of the tibia. However, the forward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur appears normal. What is the structure most likely to be injured?

choices.text: Both anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a direct anterior blow to the knees such as dashboard injury and excessive backward movement in the posterior drawer test is suggestive of posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury.

The initial symptoms are very similar to an ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) injury like the immediate swelling. On performing the posterior drawer test, there would be excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. The majority of patients with an isolated PCL injury will return to a high level of function with just appropriate quadriceps rehabilitation, without the need for surgical intervention.

On performing the anterior drawer test, the normal forward gliding movement of the tibia in relation to femoral condyles is suggestive of apparently normal anterior cruciate ligaments. 

Dashboard injury can also lead to

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture of neck of the femur
  • The shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

The image below is an MRI of the knee joint, and the arrow shows the posterior cruciate ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the sterilization device used in the image shown below?

choices.text: It has a failure rate of 40%.
It blocks the fallopian tube permanently.
It is inserted only under general anesthesia.

questions.solution:
The above image shows the hysteroscopic insertion of Essure into the fallopian tube. The true statement about Essure is that it blocks the fallopian tube permanently.

The Essure permanent birth-control device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It is a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol).

It is not effective immediately, and an alternate method of contraception has to be used for the first 3 months after this procedure. A hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is performed after 3 months of insertion to ensure the proper placement and total occlusion. A failure rate of 1–5% is seen with the Essure device. 

Disadvantages:

  • Requires hysteroscopy 
  • Need expertise and is expensive
  • Permanent method
  • Hysterosalpingogram required to confirm blockage
  • 3 months waiting period and needs temporary contraception
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube

Advantage:

  • No abdominal scar and can be done under local anesthesia

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a menstrual abnormality is prescribed tranexamic acid. Which class does this drug belong to?
questions.solution:
Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent. It is approved for treating heavy menstrual bleeding.  

It is a lysine analogue that binds to the active site of plasmin and prevents the interaction of fibrin with plasmin. This prevents the dissolution of clots (fibrinolysis) and decreases bleeding. It can also be used to reverse excessive fibrinolysis.

Other options:

Anticoagulants (option C) are drugs that inhibit the formation of clots, given to patients at risk of developing serious consequences due to clot formation. It can be done by inhibiting various levels of clot formation. It broadly includes agents that stimulate antithrombin activity, Vitamin K antagonists, thrombin inhibitors and Factor Xa inhibitors.

Drugs that inhibit platelet aggregation and platelet function in the formation of a clot are called antiplatelet drugs (option D). These drugs can be classified as thromboxane inhibitors, agents that block adenosine uptake, P2y12 antagonists, and glycoprotein 2b/3a inhibitors.

Drugs that stimulate the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin for fibrin metabolism are called fibrinolytics (option A). It consists of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator and its variants like urokinase and streptokinase.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is implicated in the causation of Reye syndrome?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is implicated in the causation of Reye syndrome.

Children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever (e.g. influenza) have a risk of developing Reye syndrome on taking aspirin or other salicylates.

Features of Reye syndrome:

  • Acute onset of encephalopathy
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Fatty infiltration of the liver 

Option A - Acetaminophen is considered the antipyretic of choice in children with viral infections.

Options C and D - Oseltamivir and baloxavir are antiviral drugs used in influenza.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the pediatrician for the general assessment. During the examination, it is observed that the baby can stand holding support. On giving a small pebble to the baby, the baby tries to hold it between the index and the thumb finger. She also waves bye-bye and can say mama. Which of the following vaccines can be given to this baby if the development is appropriate for her age and if she has not missed any prior immunization?

choices.text: Measles and Rubella-1, Japanese encephalitis vaccine, Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine booster, Vitamin A 1 lakh IU
Measles and Rubella-1, Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine booster, Vitmain A 2 Lakhs IU

questions.solution:
According to the developmental assessment, the child has attained 9 months of age.

A 9-month-old baby can stand with support; has a pincer grasp; waves bye-bye; and can say bisyllabic words like mama, baba, dada. 

Vaccines given at this age:

questions.text: The GOBI-FFF strategy, which is aimed at revolutionizing child health care, was given by _______.
questions.solution:
The GOBI-FFF strategy was given by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF).

The GOBI-FFF strategy is aimed at child health revolution and survival. It was initially called the GOBI strategy, and the FFF aspect was later added to it.

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: A 58-year-old female was diagnosed with a large pituitary mass on MRI scanning. The presence of high circulating levels of which of the following hormones avoids the need for surgical resection of the pituitary gland?
questions.solution:
Circulating prolactin levels should always be assessed in cases of pituitary adenomas, as the presence of high prolactin levels indicates prolactinoma, which can be treated with dopamine agonists, thereby avoiding unnecessary surgical resection.

Dopamine agonists are first-line therapy in most patients with prolactinoma. Commonly used dopamine agonists include bromocriptine, cabergoline, and quinagolide.

Dopamine agonists reduce serum prolactin concentration and cause a significant reduction in the tumor size after several months of therapy. If the patient has any visual defects due to tumor suppression effects, they tend to improve within a few days after the administration of dopamine agonists.

Prolonged use of ergot-derived dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline may cause fibrotic reactions in the heart due to interaction with 5-HT2B receptors. These effects are mostly seen in patients with Parkinson's disease. Hence, if prolonged treatment is required, then non-ergot agents such as quinagolide are indicated.

In patients who achieve normoprolactinemia and significant reduction of the tumor mass, the dopamine agonist can be withdrawn after two years of therapy.

Note that surgical decompression is usually necessary only when a macroprolactinoma does not respond adequately to dopamine agonist therapy.

questions.text: A patient with the hearing aid shown in the image below was brought to you in ENT OPD for follow-up. All of the following options represent the indications for this type of hearing aid, except _____.

choices.text: A 7-year-old patient with single-sided hearing loss
A 13-year-old patient with bilateral ear discharge unresponsive to treatment
A 10-year-old patient with bilateral canal atresia
A 20-year-old patient with bilateral acoustic neuroma

questions.solution:
The above image shows bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA), and all the given options are indications for BAHA, except for patients with bilateral acoustic neuroma, as they have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

Bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) is based on the principle of bone conduction. They are used in the following conditions:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal associated with discharge and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids
    • Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia
  • Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis, where surgery is contraindicated
  • Single-sided deafness

BAHA combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear and allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear—a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

  • An innermost titanium fixture in the bone
  • A middle abutment 
  • An outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment

Usually, BAHA is placed posterosuperior to the external auditory canal in the temporal bone.

 

Related Pearl: BAHA (Bone Anchored Hearing Aid)

It replaces the external auditory canal and middle ear and directly stimulates cochlea.

Indications:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment
    • Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment
    • Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid
  • Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated
  • Single-sided hearing loss

Eligibility:

  • Cochlea and nerve should be functional
  • BC threshold should be better than or equal to 45 dB on PTA

Components:

Mechanism of action:

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of events during electrical conduction in the heart after the impulse is generated in the SA node.
  1. Depolarization of endocardium
  2. Depolarization of epicardium
  3. Repolarization of epicardium
  4. Repolarization of endocardium
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1→2→3→4.

Depolarization proceeds from the endocardium to the epicardium in an intact cardiac muscle.

Repolarization of cardiac muscle proceeds from the epicardium to the endocardium.

The sequence of the spread of cardiac excitation is as follows:

After depolarization of the sinoatrial node (SA node), the impulse created travels through both the atria and converges at the atrioventricular node (AV node). The AV node is in the inter-atrial septum. Since the AV nodal conduction is slow, there is a delay before the impulse spreads to the ventricles.

The impulse from the AV node then spreads to the Purkinje fibers, which conduct rapidly to the ventricles. The depolarization of the ventricles starts at the interventricular septum and spreads to the cardiac apex. Thus, depolarization starts from the endocardium and then extends to the epicardium.

In normal conditions, repolarization retraces the path of depolarization and proceeds in the direction opposite to that of depolarization. So, repolarization first takes place in the epicardium and moves towards the endocardium.


 

Related Pearl: Duration of cardiac Cycle

Total (s)

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided hemiparesis and hemisensory loss of the leg and foot. He is unable to correctly identify objects, is apathetic, and has significant personality changes. The occlusion of which of the following arteries could be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery is likely to be responsible for these symptoms. The anterior cerebral artery supplies most of the superior-medial parietal lobes and portions of the frontal lobes. 

Anterior cerebral arteries arise from the internal carotid artery and are part of the circle of Willis. The left and right anterior cerebral arteries are connected by the anterior communicating artery.

Anterior cerebral artery occlusion distal to the anterior communicating artery manifests as:

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss that mainly affects the leg and foot, due to the involvement of the paracentral lobule
  • Inability to identify objects correctly, apathy, and personality changes due to the involvement of frontal and parietal lobes

Other options:

Option B: Middle cerebral artery occlusion produces

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss mainly involve the face and arm as it supplies the precentral and postcentral gyri 
  • Aphasia if the left hemisphere is affected 
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia due to involvement of the optic radiation
  • Anosognosia if the right hemisphere is affected 

Option C: Posterior cerebral artery occlusion produces contralateral homonymous hemianopia with some macular sparing (due to collateral blood supply to occipital pole. It also produces visual agnosia and memory impairment. 

Option D: Vertebrobasilar artery occlusion produces

  • Ipsilateral pain and temperature loss of the face
  • Contralateral pain and temperature loss of the body
  • Attacks of hemianopia or complete cortical blindness
  • Ipsilateral loss of gag reflex, dysphagia, hoarseness
  • Vertigo, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and other cerebellar signs
  • Unilateral or bilateral hemiparesis
  • Coma

The given cadaveric image below is of the vascular structures (circle of Willis) at the base of the brain.

questions.text: A dermatology resident performing Wood's lamp examination on a patient notes a milky-white fluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ivory or milky-white fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination is seen in vitiligo.

In vitiligo, the affected patches have less or no epidermal melanin. As the normal function of melanin is to absorb light, the vitiligo-affected patches cannot block the light emitted from deeper layers of the skin. They appear as bluish, milky, or ivory-white patches with sharp margins. Woods lamp is helpful in diagnosing vitiligo, especially in fair-skinned people whose lesions may not be evident to the naked eye.

The image given below shows milky-white fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

Vitiligo is a localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes in the basal layer of the skin. 

According to a recent Vitiligo Global Issue Consensus Conference, the term ‘vitiligo’ can be used as an umbrella term for all non‐segmental forms of vitiligo (including several variants: acrofacial, mucosal, generalized, universal, mixed, and rare variants of vitiligo). The classification is shown below:


Vitiligo (Non segmental)
  • Acrofacial
  • Mucosal (>1 one mucosal site)
  • Generalized
  • Universal
  • Mixed (associated with SV)
  • Rare variants
Segmental vitiligo
  • Uni-, bi-, or pleuri-segmental

Undetermined/

unclassified vitiligo
  • Focal
  • Mucosal (one site in isolation)

One of the theories for the etiology of vitiligo is based on the clinical association of vitiligo with a number of autoimmune disorders: 

  • Thyroid disease - strongest association
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Alopecia areata

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Koebner phenomenon is seen, which is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Treatment depends upon the percentage of body surface area (BSA) involved:

  • <20% BSA involved: The topical application of corticosteroids, Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus.
  • >20% BSA involved: Systemic steroids, azathioprine, psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, and narrowband ultraviolet B therapy (NB-UVB) at 311±2 nm wavelength.

Surgical grafting techniques can be used in patients who do not respond to this treatment, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non-pigmented area. Depigmentation can be done in patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left.

Poor prognostic factors for vitiligo:

  • Positive family history 
  • Mucosal vitiligo 
  • Lesions over bony prominences
  • Isomorphic Koebner's phenomenon 
  • Non-segmental vitiligo

Leucotrichia, longer duration, and higher age at onset do not correlate significantly with progression.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).
