questions.text: Identify the dural fold shown by white arrows in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The structure labeled with white arrows in the given image is tentorium cerebelli. It separates the occipital and temporal cerebral hemispheres from the cerebellum and infratentorial brainstem.

The four septa that divide the cranial cavity into freely communicating spaces are as follows:

  • Falx cerebri
  • Tentorium cerebelli
  • Falx cerebelli
  • Diaphragma sellae

 

The dura mater is made of 2 layers:

  • Endosteal layer: It is actually the periosteum of the skull bones. It contains fibroblasts and osteoblasts. It is not continuous with the dura mater of the spinal cord.
  • Meningeal layer: It is the dura mater proper. It has only fibroblasts (no osteoblasts). It is continuous with the dura mater of the spinal cord. It forms 4 septa that divide the cranial cavity into spaces, restricting the displacement of the brain. 

The dural venous sinuses are present between the meningeal and the endosteal layer of the dura mater.

questions.text:
A woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and fever. On examination, cervical motion tenderness and mucopurulent vaginal discharge are noted. Which of the following investigations will you undertake to definitively establish the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), according to the CDC criteria?
  1. Laboratory tests for Neisseria gonorrhoeae/Chlamydia
  2. Laparoscopy 
  3. MRI
  4. Biopsy and histopathological examination
  5. Blood tests for ESR and CRP
questions.solution:
Laparoscopy, MRI, and biopsy with histopathological examination should be undertaken to establish the definitive diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), according to the CDC criteria.

CDC criteria for the diagnosis of PID:

Definitive criteria:

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
  • Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess)
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID

Minimum criteria:

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness

Additional criteria:

  • Oral temperature of >38.3C
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying changes in the population of a country with time. This process is called the demographic cycle. Which of the following options best defines the correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: High expanding→ Early stationary → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining
High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the phases of the demographic cycle is High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining.

The demographic cycle is comprised of five stages and is as described below:

Stage 1: High stationary population - There is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

Stage 2: Early expanding population - There is a decline in the death rate that begins but the birth rate stays constant. Ex: Many countries in South Asia, and Africa are in this phase. 

Stage 3: Late expanding population - There is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase.

Stage 4: Low stationary population - There is a low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It can also result in zero population growth like in Austria (1980-85). Other examples: the UK, Denmark, Sweden, Belgium recorded a growth rate of 0.1 in 1980-85. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

Stage 5: Contracting population - The birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Ex: East European countries like Germany, and Hungary.

India is currently in the "late expanding" stage which is the third stage in the demographic cycle where declining death rates and declining birth rates are seen.

Another important concept of the demographic cycle is the demographic gap which is the difference between birth rate and death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both birth rate and death rate falls causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

UN Data (2021)

  • India’s population was 1,393,409,000 (1.39 Billion) 
  • In 2021, India ranked 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2020)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 28 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.5
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosis of cervical pleura is a cause of right recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.

Causes of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy are thyroid surgery, carcinoma thyroid, cervical lymphadenopathy, and carcinoma cervical esophagus

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury is often acute. All the intrinsic muscles are paralyzed in this condition. The vocal cords lie in the median or paramedian position due to the unopposed action of the cricothyroid muscles. This leads to dyspnea and stridor, but the voice is good.

Treatment options for bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis include tracheostomy, transverse cordotomy (Kashima's operation), partial arytenoidectomy, and reinnervation procedures.

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing
Paramedian 1 mm Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Intermediate/ Cadaveric 3 mm Complete paralysis
Slight abduction 7 mm Normal respiration
Full abduction 9 mm Strained respiration

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

questions.text: A young boy was brought by his parents with complaints of nausea, abdominal cramps, and watery diarrhea for 2 days. The parents mentioned that the family was away on a cruise ship, where they consumed raw oysters. The boy's younger brother also had watery diarrhea and had one episode of vomiting the same morning. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of acute gastroenteritis following the consumption of raw oysters on a cruise ship is most likely suggestive of infection with the Norwalk virus.

Norwalk virus is a small, rounded, non-enveloped single-stranded, positive RNA virus that accounts for more than half of nonbacterial acute gastroenteritis for all age groups in developed and underdeveloped countries. 

They occur in group settings such as banquet halls, cruise ships, dormitories, and campgrounds, where outbreak sources are usually contaminated food and/or water. Potential sources of contaminated food include shellfish such as clams and oysters, which are contaminated by water at the source.

Factors contributing to the rapid spread include feco-oral transmission, low infective dose, and high environmental stability of the virus.

Clinical features include nausea, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea after 1-2 days of incubation period and continue for approximately 1-3 days. Vomiting is more common in children. Viral shedding can occur up to 2-3 weeks after cessation of clinical symptoms.

RT-PCR is widely used to identify infection. RT-PCR can also be used to detect the virus in environmental specimens such as drinking water or contaminated food or both. Treatment is supportive.

The image given below is of norovirus under electron microscopy.

Other options:

Option A: Orthomyxoviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, and have a negative-sense, segmented RNA. This group of viruses includes the influenza virus. It is a respiratory virus.

Option B: Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded, DNA virus. Although adenovirus can cause gastroenteritis in children, however, the history of consumption of raw oysters on a cruise ship is most likely suggestive of infection with the Norwalk virus. Adenoviruses can also cause pharyngitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, keratoconjunctivitis, pneumonia, hemorrhagic cystitis, and disseminated disease.

Option D: Reovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded, segmented RNA virus. Reoviruses have not been proven to cause any human disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/ Valsalva maneuver, and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele:

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

Other options:

Option A: Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It presents as a swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate. The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). It usually occurs due to the uncoordinated contraction or the spasm of the cricopharyngeal sphincter during deglutition. Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing.

The below image shows Zenker's diverticulum on barium swallow:

Option D: Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. It is partially compressible and brilliantly transilluminant.

The below image shows cystic hygroma in a child:

questions.text: A newborn developed tachypnea and grunting immediately after birth. On examination, the baby was cyanotic, with a scaphoid abdomen. A chest radiograph was taken, which is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest and absence of bowel loops in the abdomen are suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided in the management of this baby.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia and in most cases involving the left side. CDH is a life-threatening pathology in infants and a major cause of morbidity and mortality due to two complications: pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

Babies with CDH present with respiratory distress characterized by tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, and cyanosis. They may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter. Auscultation of the chest may reveal bowel sounds with reduced breath sounds.

Diagnosis: A chest radiograph and nasogastric tube passage can confirm the diagnosis of CDH. Prenatal diagnosis can be made using ultrasonography between 16 to 24 weeks of gestation.

Treatment:

The immediate step in the management is the naso- or orogastric tube placement for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation (option B) and respiratory distress is stabilised. Bag and mask ventilation may increase the abdominal distension and limit the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs. Hence, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided.

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) (option A) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option D) have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy to support respiratory failure. The main goal is to maintain oxygenation to the lungs and carbon dioxide washout without causing volutrauma.

Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text:
A screening test for an infectious disease is being applied to the population. What criteria must this disease fulfill so that the screening test can prove to be useful in its prevention?
  1. Early diagnosis should not affect the course of the disease.
  2. The disease should have an asymptomatic stage.
  3. A diagnostic test and treatment for the disease should be available.  
  4. The natural history of the disease should be unknown.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D- 2 and 3.

Screening tests are recommended under the following conditions:

  • Early diagnosis changes the disease's course
  • In a disease with an asymptomatic stage
  • In a disease with a test for diagnosis and treatment
  • The natural history of the disease is well known

The difference between screening and diagnostic tests is given below:

Screening test Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy

Done on patients with signs and symptoms

Applied to groups

Applied to single patients

Based on one criterion or cut-off point

Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings

Less accurate

More accurate

Less expensive

More expensive

Not a basis for treatment

Used as a basis for treatment

The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care

The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida delivers a child by cesarean section. The mother's blood group is O negative, and the newborn's blood group is A positive. All the following complications are more likely to occur in her second pregnancy, except __________.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Rh alloimmunization. Potter's syndrome is not a complication of this condition. 

Potter's syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the changes in physical appearances of neonates due to oligohydramnios caused by renal agenesis. It is characterized by limb deformities, pulmonary hypoplasia, and a flattened face. 

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. It occurs in two stages. First, sensitization occurs during the first pregnancy, and then immunization occurs. Sensitization occurs during situations of fetomaternal bleeds.

Examples of these situations:

  • Miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, hydatidiform mole, intrauterine fetal demise
  • Amniocentesis, embryoreduction, cordocentesis
  • Placenta previa with bleeding, abruption of the placenta
  • Delivery of an Rh-positive infant to an Rh-negative mother

It can also occur during the third stage of labor, manual removal of the placenta, and after a cesarean section. 

The antibodies formed as a result of immunization are IgM and IgG. However, only IgG antibodies are small enough to cross the placenta and cause hemolytic disease in the fetus. The three manifestations of the hemolytic disease include hydrops fetalis, icterus gravis neonatorum, and congenital anemia of the newborn. 

Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of Rh hemolytic disease in the fetus. There is widespread erythrocyte destruction leading to anemia, anoxemia, and metabolic acidosis. This leads to hepatic injury, causing hypoproteinemia and subsequently generalized edema, ascites, and hydrothorax. 

The following image shows a stillborn baby with hydrops fetalis. 

Icterus gravis neonatorum is a condition in which a baby is born without jaundice but develops it within 24 hours of life. In this condition, hemolysis occurs while the fetus is in utero, and the bilirubin is excreted in amniotic fluid. Once the cord is clamped, the hemolysis continues and icterus becomes apparent. 

Congenital anemia of the newborn is the mild version of Rh incompatibility. Here, there is mild hemolysis without clinically evident jaundice. 

Rh immunization can be prevented by the administration of Rh anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) intramuscularly after childbirth. It should ideally be administered within 72 hours or preferably earlier after delivery or abortion. The dose can be calculated using the Kleihauer-Betke test.

questions.text: An immunologist orders a nitroblue tetrazolium test on a child suspected to have a primary immunodeficiency disease. What condition is she screening the child for?
questions.solution:
The Nitroblue Tetrazolium Test (NBT) is used as a screening test for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) by assessing the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in phagocytes.

This principle relies on the color change of nitroblue tetrazolium, which transforms from colorless/yellow to deep blue when it encounters ROS. A higher nitroblue test score indicates that the cell is more efficient in producing ROS.

In chronic granulomatous disease, there is an NADPH oxidase defect. Hence, the phagocyte cannot produce reactive oxygen species or radicals required for bacterial killing, which results in recurrent infections. Here, the leukocytes fail to reduce nitroblue tetrazolium during phagocytosis. Hence, a negative test (NBT remains colourless to yellow) is seen in CGD.

A positive test result means neutrophils turn blue, as shown below: 

A negative test means nitroblue tetrazolium remains colourless/yellow, as shown below: 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. He is a known case of COPD and has had similar episodes in the past, which required hospitalization. The classification according to Gold's criteria was moderate COPD. What are the likely PFT values of the patient considering this classification?
questions.solution:
The expected pulmonary function test (PFT) values in this patient are FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 50% to 80%.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

Note: FEV1/FVC is measured after the administration of atleast one short acting inhaled bronchodilator.

questions.text: A young girl presented with bilateral visual loss, peripheral neuropathy, and postural tremors. The fundus examination showed optic atrophy. Pedigree chart of the disease is given below. What is the pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial inheritance.

The clinical features and inheritance pattern is suggestive of Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy, which is characterized by bilateral visual loss, severe optic atrophy, psychiatric symptoms, peripheral neuropathy, cardiac conduction abnormalities, and sometimes white matter lesions. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy is a prototype of mitochondrial inheritance. It occurs due to a mitochondrial DNA mutation. This results in impaired mitochondrial adenosine triphosphate production, which affects the highly energy-dependent optic nerve.

Mitochondrial inheritance is caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome. Inheritance is exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization. Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease. 

Features of mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Mutation in the mitochondrial gene is either due to deletion or point mutation.
  • Mitochondrial defect in the mother can affect both the male and female gender but a father with a mitochondrial defect cannot pass it to the next generation. 
  • A cell can have both normal and abnormal mitochondrial genomes, and this phenomenon is referred to as heteroplasmy.

Related Pearl: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother
  • These diseases include: (mnemonic: KLMNOP)

Disease

Features

K: Kearn- Sayre Syndrome (KSS)

Ophthalmoplegia

Pigmentary retinopathy

Cardiomyopathy

L: Leigh disease

Subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy

L: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy

Acute or subacute vision loss due to B/L optic atrophy

Cerebellar ataxia

Hyperreflexia

Babinski sign

Cardiac conduction abnormalities

Some have white matter lesions

M: MELAS

Mitochondrial myopathy

(MERRF) Myoclonic epilepsy, ragged red fibers in muscle, ataxia, sensorineural deafness

N: NARP (2 clinical patterns)

1. Neuropathy, ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, dementia

2. Severe infantile encephalopathy with lesions in basal ganglia

O: Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her child with the lesions shown in the image. What are these lesions known as?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are Epstein pearls.

Epstein pearls

  • Are nests of epithelial cells
  • Appear as whitish/yellowish spots on the hard palate.
  • May also occur over the tip of the prepuce at 6 o'clock position
  • Usually, resolve by 3 months

As it resolves spontaneously and is a benign condition, no intervention is necessary.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A young boy is posted for tonsillectomy. During the preoperative evaluation, it was found that he had increased activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). However, the platelet counts and prothrombin time (PT) are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has an elevation of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) with normal prothrombin time (PT) and normal platelet count. This is likely to be due to hemophilia.

Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive hemorrhagic disease due to mutations in the F8 gene (hemophilia A or classic hemophilia) or F9 gene (hemophilia B). It typically affects men, and women are usually asymptomatic. Depending on the residual activity of factor VIII or IX, the manifestations can be mild, moderate, or severe. 

Early in life, the patient may have prolonged bleeding after circumcision, or as intracranial hemorrhages. When the child begins to walk, bleeding into the joint, hemarthrosis is seen. They present as painful swelling and reddening of the knee, elbow, ankle, shoulder, or hips. 

Laboratory investigations will show elevated aPTT, with normal PT and platelet count. It is treated with the administration of factor VIII or factor IX concentrates.

Prothrombin time- measures the integrity of extrinsic and common pathways. It measures factors VII, fibrinogen, II (prothrombin), V, and X.

Activated partial thromboplastin time, aPTT, measures intrinsic pathways. It measures factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII, I (fibrinogen), II (prothrombin), V, and X.

Elevated aPTT with normal PT and platelet count is seen in factor XI and factor XII deficiency, hemophilia, von Willebrand disease, an inhibitor to factor VIII, lupus anticoagulant, presence of heparin, etc.

Elevated PT with normal aPTT and platelet count is seen in factor VII deficiency and oral anticoagulant therapy.

Elevated PT and aPTT with normal platelet count are seen if there is any defect in the common pathway. It is seen in afibrinogenemia; deficiencies of factors II, V, and X; and deficiency of vitamin K–dependant factors. 

Elevated PT and aPTT with low platelet counts are seen in disseminated intravascular coagulation, liver disease, and lupus anticoagulant.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist performs the swinging flashlight test, which reveals the findings as shown in the image given below. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows Marcus Gunn pupil, which is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve/cranial nerve II disease.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a RAPD or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

The image given below shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

Other abnormal pupillary reactions:

  1. Amaurotic light reflex - On flashing light to the affected eye, there is no direct light reflex in the affected eye, and there is no consensual light reflex in the normal eye. This occurs due to a lesion in the optic nerve or retina.
  2. Efferent pathway defect - Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. It occurs due to a defect in the efferent pathway.
  3. Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil -In this condition, light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the normal side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the normal side. It occurs due to a lesion in the optic tract.
  4. Adie’s tonic pupil - In this condition, the light reflex is absent and the response to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger than normal (anisocoria). It is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with HELLP syndrome. The treating obstetrician grades the severity of this condition using the Mississippi classification. This classification includes all of the following parameters, except _______.
questions.solution:
The Mississippi classification includes all the following parameters, except bilirubin. 

The parameters included in the Mississippi classification are: 

  • Platelet count
  • Serum LDH
  • Alanine transaminase

HELLP is an acronym for hemolysis (H), elevated liver enzymes (EL), and low platelet count (LP). It usually occurs in patients with severe preeclampsia. The patients typically present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Hypertension and proteinuria are seen but may be absent in some cases.

In this condition, there is periportal necrosis of the liver, causing an elevation in  the levels of liver enzymes (AST, ALT, and LDH) and bilirubin. Microangiopathic hemolysis manifests as

  • Elevated serum LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) levels
  • Reduced haptoglobin levels
  • Presence of schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis on peripheral blood smear

Tennessee criteria are used for the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome, while the Mississippi classification system is used to grade the condition. 

  • Tennessee criteria for diagnosis of true/complete HELLP
    • Platelet count <1 lakh/mm3
    • AST >70 IU/L, 
    • LDH >600 IU/L
  • Mississippi classification divides HELLP into 3 grades based on the platelet count, serum LDH, and ALT levels.

Prompt delivery is indicated for ≥34 weeks of gestational age. Cesarean section is the common mode of delivery. Platelet transfusion is required if counts are less than 50,000/mm3. Magnesium sulfate is given as antiseizure prophylaxis, and anti-hypertensives are given for severe hypertension.

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the infertility clinic with complaints of chronic pelvic pain and irregular menstruation. An endometrial biopsy was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing caseating granulomas suggest a diagnosis of endometrial tuberculosis. 

The endometrium is involved in 50–60% of all cases of genital tuberculosis. It can appear grossly normal due to cyclical shedding. The diagnosis is made by histopathological examination, which shows the above findings. 

It occurs as a descending infection from the fallopian tubes due to anatomical proximity and continuity. Hematogenous spread is thought to be the process by which the tubercle bacilli implant into the mucosa of the fallopian tubes and subsequently affect the endometrium by direct extension. There is a reinfection every month due to shedding off of the endometrium during menstruation 

Findings:

  • Ulcerative, granular, or fungating lesions may be seen occasionally
  • Shrunken cavity due to fibrosis
  • Golf-ball ostia of fallopian tubes 
  • Extensive fibrosis can also close the internal os causing pyometra 
  • Intrauterine adhesions - Asherman syndrome 

Genital tract tuberculosis is among the commonest causes of infertility. They often present with a history of infertility, irregular menstruation, and vaginal discharge.

Treatment includes standard anti-tubercular therapy based on drug sensitivity patterns.

The below histology image of endometrial tuberculosis shows Langhans cells, caseating granulomas, and epithelioid cells in the background of endometrial glands and an image of hysterosalpingogram showing endometrial tuberculosis. 

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chromotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes
  • Clomiphene and letrozole
  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt  
Other causes   Ultrasound, MRI, SSG, hysteroscopy   Treat the cause  

 

 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)

  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV

  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:

questions.text: Which of the following organisms show beta-hemolysis on blood agar, resistance to bacitracin, and a positive CAMP test?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B streptococci that shows β-hemolysis on blood agar, is resistant to bacitracin, and gives a positive CAMP test.

S. agalactiae is a capsulated Gram-positive coccus occurring in chains. It causes meningitis in the neonatal period. Infection is commonly acquired from the maternal vagina during birth. There are two clinical types seen in neonates:
  • Early-onset type (more common) presents within a week of birth as meningitis or septicemia and is often fatal.
  • Late-onset type presents between the second to twelfth week of life commonly as septicemia.

The CAMP test (Christie, Atkins and Munch-Peterson) is used to identify group B β-hemolytic-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor. This factor causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed by Staphylococcus aureus, when Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a streak of Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar. This produces the characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis.

The image given below shows a positive CAMP test.

The following table provides important laboratory characteristics which differentiate Streptococcus pyogenes from Streptococcus agalactiae.

Species Lancefield Group Typical Hemolysis Important Lab Characteristics
S. pyogenes A β Bacitracin sensitive, PYR test positive
S. agalactiae B β Bacitracin resistant, PYR test negative, Hippurate hydrolysis positive, CAMP test positive

The illustration given below shows the classification of Streptococci.

The classification of gram-positive organisms is summarized in the flow chart below.

questions.text: During histology class, you are asked to identify the various epithelia and their locations in the body. Which of the following parts of the urethra is lined by the epithelium shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium, which is identified by the variations in the cell layers: the deepest cell layer is columnar, the middle is made of polyhedral cells, and, lastly, the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped. Transitional epithelium lines the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra (not the membranous urethra).  

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium.  

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched, it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: The given emblem represents an organization related to which organism?
questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP). Leprosy is caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

Characteristics of the NLEP emblem:

  • The lotus in the NLEP emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb, a normal forefinger, and the shape of a house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and that a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of leprosy.

NLEP is a centrally sponsored health scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India.

Other options:

Option A- The program dealing with Mycobacterium tuberculosis is National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP).

Options C and D - Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis, and Leishmania donovani causes Kala-azar, which are vector-borne diseases. National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not reveal apple jelly sign on performing the following test?
questions.solution:
The image shown above demonstrates a diascopy. All the options mentioned above reveal apple jelly sign on diascopy except nevus anemicus.

Diascopy is a bedside maneuver performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions.

It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, to allow evaluation of other colors. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

The purpose of this procedure is to empty blood from the superficial vessels to determine if skin redness is due to blood present within the vessels or extravasated onto the skin.

Diascopy is of particular value in the following conditions:

  • Granulomatous conditions: A translucent brownish color is seen on the diascopy, known as apple jelly nodules (apple jelly sign). They are seen in sarcoidosis, granuloma annulare, and lupus vulgaris.
  • To distinguish nevus anemicus from nevus depigmentosus: On diascopy, nevus anemicus (congenital white patch of vasoconstriction) becomes indistinguishable with the merging of the lesion into the surrounding skin. However, the border of nevus depigmentosus remains unaltered after diascopy.
  • Spider nevi - The application of medium pressure to a spider nevus can compress radiating arterioles and allow visualization of pulsatile flow in the feeding vessel.
  • Differentiation of erythema (vasodilation) - disappears and purpura (extravasated blood) - remains unaltered on diascopy.

Related Pearl: Classification of cutaneous tuberculosis

The classification of cutaneous tuberculosis is based on the mode of acquisition.

Type Pathophysiology AFB

Exogenous

Through broken skin or mucosa
Tuberculous chancre Occurs in individuals with no previous sensitization to TB Multibacillary
Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity Paucibacillary

Endogenous

Direct spread from a focus of infection
Scrofuloderma Contiguous spread from affected parts like lymph nodes, joints Multibacillary
Periorificial tuberculosis Autoinoculation at mucocutaneous borders from infected secretions Multibacillary

Hematogenous

Spread from a distant primary focus of TB
Acute cutaneous miliary tuberculosis Occurs in severe disseminated TB Multibacillary
Lupus vulgaris Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity. Mostly hematogenous spread, sometimes exogenous. Paucibacillary
Tuberculous gumma/ abscess Occurs in immunocompromised patients Multibacillary

Tuberculids

Hypersensitivity reaction
Lichen scrofulosorum (micropapular) Hematogenous spread of M. tuberculosis antigens to the skin causes type III hypersensitivity which triggers type IV reaction with granuloma formation Very rarely seen
Papulonecrotic tuberculid
Erythema induratum of Bazin (nodular)

questions.text: When the surgeon operates on a patient with an inguinal hernia, he comes across the following zone. What is the intraoperative surgical significance of this particular zone?

choices.text: Inguinal hernia always lies in this zone.
Surgeon should avoid the staples in this zone.
Surgeon should cover this zone by mesh during hernioplasty.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the triangle of doom. During hernia repair, the surgeon should avoid the staples in this zone. 

The triangle of doom is one of the important surgical landmarks in preperitoneal laparoscopic hernia repair. Staples and sutures in mesh hernioplasty should be avoided in this area to prevent injury to important structures such as the external iliac vessels and the femoral nerve.

The triangle of doom is bounded:

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

The apex of the triangle of doom is oriented superiorly at the internal ring.

Contents of the space:

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
 

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was catheterized for a surgical procedure, and an intern noticed the following finding when he removed the catheter.  A manual reduction was attempted and was not successful.  What will be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis. If manual reduction of the skin is unsuccessful, a dorsal slit procedure should be performed.

Paraphimosis is the inability to place back the retracted preputial skin. This creates a ring-like constriction, and the glans tend to be swollen, and edematous, with severe pain and tenderness. Paraphimosis is precipitated after sexual intercourse or iatrogenically after urethral catheterization.

The first line of treatment includes manual reduction of the skin by applying lignocaine jelly. Ice bags and injection of a solution of hyaluronidase in normal saline may help to reduce the swelling.

If this fails, an initial dorsal slit is made to relieve the edema and compression. Antibiotics and analgesics are also given. Circumcision is performed after 3 weeks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in a drowsy state with difficulty in breathing. The consultant suspects transection of the brainstem at the level indicated in the image given below, with intact vagal innervation. What will be the type of respiration expected in this patient?

choices.text: Regular breathing continues but with deep inspiration

questions.solution:
Transection of the brain stem midway between the pons and the medulla with intact vagal innervation causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.

The pre-Botzinger complex in the medulla consists of synaptically coupled pacemaker cells. These neurons help in initiating the process of respiration. They also help in producing rhythmic and automatic respiration.

The pneumotaxic center in the pons modifies this rhythmic discharge and regularizes it. This center mainly controls the rate and depth of breathing. The apneustic center excites the inspiratory center and causes prolongation of the action potential. This helps in maintaining the period of respiration. 

So a complete transection midway between the pons and medulla causes irregular respiration. 

Respiratory centers of the brain:

  • Pre-Botzinger complex - This produces rhythmic and automatic respiration. Therefore damage to the medulla results in loss of spontaneous respiration.
  • Pneumotaxic center - The rhythmic discharge produced by the pre-Botziger complex is further modified by the pneumotaxic centers. Stimulation of the pneumotaxic center results in an increase in the respiratory rate and a decrease in the tidal volume. There will also be prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding (apneusis).
  • Vagus nerve - Stretching of the lung initiates impulses in the pulmonary vagal fibers. These signals inhibit further inspiration. Therefore in vagotomy, there is an increased depth of inspiration. 
  • Therefore, damage to pons causes respiration to become slower and tidal volume to become greater.  

 

Other options:

Option A- Apneusis occurs in transection through the mid-pontine level with a vagotomy.

Option B- Spontaneous respiration ceases in a complete transection through the medulla.

Option C- Regular breathing with deep inspiration occurs in complete transection above the pons.

Related Pearl: Effects of Various Lesions and Brainstem Transections

Label

Level of transection

Vagi intact

Vagi cut

A

Complete transection above pons

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

B

Mid-pontine level section

Regular breathing continues

Apneusis develops

C

Transection midway between pons and medulla

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below medulla

Spontaneous respiration ceases

Spontaneous respiration ceases

CP - middle cerebellar peduncle

DRG - Dorsal group of respiratory neurons

questions.text: A 45-year-old man had severe hypothyroidism.  His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels.  Which of the following types of respiratory failure is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of severe hypothyroidism with hypoxemia and hypercapnia is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure. 

Type II respiratory failure occurs as a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. The mechanism of type II respiratory failure in severe hypothyroidism can be due to poor response of the central nervous system to hypoxia and hypercapnia, as well as reduced strength of the respiratory muscles.

Other causes for diminished CNS drive to breathe:

  • Drug overdose
  • Brainstem injury
  • Sleep-disordered breathing 

Reduced strength for respiration can be due to

  • Impaired neuromuscular transmission (e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis)
  • Respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue)

The overall load on the respiratory system that can facilitate type 2 respiratory failure can be classified as follows:

  • Resistive loads, as in bronchospasm
  • Loads due to reduced lung compliance as in alveolar oedema, atelectasis, intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure
  • Loads due to reduced chest wall compliance as in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, abdominal distention
  • Loads due to increased minute ventilation requirements as in pulmonary embolus with increased dead-space fraction, sepsis

Treatment:

Reversing the underlying causes of ventilatory failure remains the mainstay treatment for type 2 respiratory failure. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask and avoiding endotracheal intubation often stabilise patients with type 2 respiratory failure. This approach is beneficial in treating patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

questions.text: An 18-year-old student presents to the clinic with symptoms suggestive of anxiety. She wants to make friends in her new class but is afraid to approach people for fear of being rejected or criticized and usually avoids any such interactions. What is the most likely personality disorder?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, as the patient has the desire to be in relationships and have social interaction but avoids these interactions due to fear of being rejected.

It is characterized by low self-esteem, and reluctance to engage in new activities. The patients are typically timid and avoid social activities and interpersonal interactions due to fear of criticism, disapproval, or rejection. It is colloquially known as having an inferiority complex. It is equally prevalent in men and women. 

Alfred Adler, the founder of individual psychology, coined the term inferiority complex.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient came with complaints of backache. On radiography, the following image is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hemangioma. The radiograph shows the vertebral body depicting vertical striations, giving a corduroy appearance.

Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. The atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion. Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.

Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance. On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas. 

The below CT image shows characteristic polka dot appearance (left) and corduroy appearance (right):

 

Other options:

Option A: Eosinophilic granuloma is a benign lesion of the vertebral body with a classic radiographic finding of vertebra plana, as shown below.

 

Option C: Paget disease is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by an increase in bone turnover at localized sites that is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. A radiograph of the vertebra gives a diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity that is referred to as the ivory vertebra appearance, as shown below.

 

Option D: Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disorder that is characterized by a low bone mass and defects in bone structure, thus rendering the bone unusually fragile and at greater risk of fracture compared to a person of the same age, sex, and race. On a vertebral radiograph, there is a biconcave appearance of the vertebra known as the codfish vertebra, as shown below.

questions.text: A pharmacologist is conducting a study on non-microsomal phase 2 reactions involved in drug metabolism. His experiments are not likely to include which of the following conjugation reactions?
questions.solution:
All of the above conjugation reactions are catalyzed by non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronide conjugation.

Glucuronide conjugation is the only phase II metabolic reaction that is carried out by microsomal enzymes. 

Drug metabolizing enzymes are primarily of two types:

  1. Microsomal enzymes are located in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum in the liver, kidney, intestinal mucosa, and lungs. They include the cytochrome P450 system, monooxygenases, etc. These enzymes can be induced by drugs and certain nutrients. These enzymes are involved in oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis, and glucuronide conjugation reactions.
  2. Non-microsomal enzymes are located in the cytoplasm and mitochondria of hepatic cells, plasma and other tissues. They include esterases, amidases and most conjugases. These enzymes catalyze all conjugation reactions except glucuronidation. Phase II reactions carried out by non-microsomal enzymes are:
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Methylation
  • Acetylation

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a deficiency of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a glycine deficiency.

Primary hyperoxalurias are a group of inborn errors of metabolism characterized by oxalate overproduction, with an autosomal recessive inheritance. There are 3 types of primary hyperoxalurias, of which primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1) is the most common form.

The defect in PH1 is the deficiency of the alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase in liver peroxisomes. This causes failure to catabolize glyoxylate to glycine. Glyoxylate is instead converted to oxalate, with consequent calcium oxalate stone formation and crystal deposition in various organs like the kidney. 

Age at onset of symptoms ranges from infancy to the sixth decade, with the median age being 4–6 years. Presenting symptoms include hematuria, dysuria, pain, urinary tract infection, or stone passage. In severe, early-onset disease, there is nephrocalcinosis with or without nephrolithiasis and failure to thrive related to renal failure.

A urinalysis shows elevated urinary oxalate and elevated urinary glycolic acid. There is also an elevated level of plasma oxalate. Renal ultrasound may show multiple bilateral radiopaque calculi. 

The FDA recently approved lumasiran, an RNA interference therapeutic agent targeting glycolate oxidase, as the first treatment option for PH1, a rare genetic disorder.

questions.text: A young man presents with diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal pain. He also reports greasy and foul-smelling stools. The test depicted in the image below is performed. Which of the following is the drug used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows the string test/entero test, which is used for the diagnosis of giardiasis. Tinidazole is used to treat this condition.
Tinidazole (2g once orally) may be more effective than metronidazole. Cure rates with metronidazole (250 mg thrice daily for 5 days) are usually >90%. 

Tinidazole is a nitroimidazole that acts by producing free radicals. It is used to treat trichomoniasis, amebiasis and giardiasis. It also has anti-bacterial properties against all anaerobic cocci, anaerobic gram-negative and spore-forming, gram-positive bacilli.

Common adverse effects include headache, nausea, and a metallic taste. Tinidazole must be stopped in patients who develop neurotoxic effects like dizziness, vertigo, ataxia, etc. It can also cause urticaria, flushing, and pruritus. It has a disulfiram-like effect and hence is contraindicated to be used with alcohol or other drugs that have a disulfiram-like effect.

Enterotest (String test):

  • It is a useful method for obtaining a duodenal specimen.
  • A coiled thread inside a small weighted gelatin capsule is swallowed by the patient, after attaching the free end of the thread to the cheek.
  • The capsule passes through the stomach to the duodenum.
  • After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and mechanically shaken.
  • The centrifuged deposit of the saline is examined for Giardia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother of a newborn is brought to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal cramps, and massive desquamation of the skin. The patient presents with a red skin rash,  affecting mainly the soles, palms, and buttocks. Further probing reveals that she had consumed the substance shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest boiled lobster syndrome seen in poisoning with boric acid, a common household poison commonly seen in baby powders, lotions, and antiseptics used in the treatment of diaper dermatitis.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, and buttocks, can be seen. The characteristic appearance is known as "boiled lobster appearance," which is marked by intense erythema, followed by extensive exfoliation.

Other options:

Option A- Pink disease or acrodynia is caused due to hypersensitivity reaction resulting from repeated ingestion or contact with mercury. There are pinkish morbilliform/ acral rashes, desquamation of palms and soles, pain in the extremities, excessive salivation or perspiration, photophobia, anorexia, insomnia, constipation or diarrhea, etc.

Option B- Blackfoot disease is caused due to chronic arsenic poisoning. Chronic arsenic poisoning causes peripheral vascular insufficiency, leading to dry gangrene.

Option D- Erethism refers to psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is commonly seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.

Eponymous features associated with mercury poisoning:

  • Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.
  • Acrodynia (Pink disease)
  • Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury.
  • Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.
  • Mercuria lentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapor. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

Eponymous features associated with arsenic poisoning:

  • Raindrop pigmentation - seen on temples, eyelids, and neck
  • Aldrich-Mee’s lines - white lines on finger and toe nails
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: In the process of gluconeogenesis, which of the following amino acids does not enter the Krebs cycle via succinyl CoA?
questions.solution:
In the process of gluconeogenesis, phenylalanine is the only amino acid that does not enter Krebs cycle via succinyl CoA. Phenylalanine enters this cycle as fumarate. 

Muscles constitute almost half of our body mass, and hence, amino acids derived from these muscles are a major source of substrate for gluconeogenesis during starvation.

The figure below shows the various points of entry of amino acids into Krebs cycle (tricarboxylic acid cycle). Valine, methionine, and isoleucine all enter in the form of succinyl CoA. 

All gluconeogenic substrates will ultimately form oxaloacetate, as shown below. Oxaloacetate will then undergo the reverse process of glycolysis, resulting in the formation of glucose.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Enzymes Reaction and site Cofactors
Pyruvate carboxylase

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Biotin, ATP

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum
