questions.text: A 2-month pregnant woman undergoes a sonographic evaluation of fetal parameters. The parameter marked in the USG shown below best measures ____________.
questions.solution:
The parameter shown in the ultrasonography image is crown-rump length (CRL), which is the most accurate parameter used for the sonographic estimation of gestational age in the first trimester. It has an accuracy range of ± 5 days.

Parameters for estimation of fetal age

Trimester

Parameter

First

     Crown-rump length (CRL)

Second
  • Biparietal diameter (BPD)
  • Abdominal circumference (AC)
  • Head circumference (HC)
  • Femur length (FL) 

Third

      Femur length

Other options:

Fetal aneuploidy is assessed by measuring the nuchal translucency (NT) on ultrasound. It represents the maximum thickness of the subcuta­neous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overly­ing the fetal spine at the back of the neck. NT is measured in the sagittal plane between 11 and 14 weeks.

Fetal growth profile can be assessed by the ratio of head circumference (HC) to abdominal circumference (AC). In asymmetric intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR), HC/AC ratio is elevated. In symmetric IUGR, HC/AC ratio remains normal. Abdominal circumference is the most sensitive in detecting IUGR.

Fetal weight is estimated ultrasonographically by combining a number of biometric data like BPD, HC, AC, and FL using Hadlock and Shepard formulae.

It can also be calculated using Johnson’s formula which is the height of the uterus above the symphysis pubis in centimeters minus 12, if the vertex is at or above the level of ischial spines or minus 11, if the vertex is below the level of ischial spines — multiplied by 155, in either case, gives the weight of the fetus in grams.

questions.text: The puerperium is a phase that lasts for _____ after childbirth.
questions.solution:
Puerperium begins as soon as the placenta is expelled and lasts for approximately 6 weeks.

It is the period following childbirth during which body tissues revert back approximately to the pre-pregnant state, both anatomically and physiologically.

Puerperium can be divided as follows:

  • Immediate puerperium: within 24 hours
  • Early puerperium: up to 7 days
  • Remote/late puerperium: up to 6 weeks or 42 days

questions.text: You were posted for an autopsy of a 34-year-old man who was under police custody for interrogation. On external examination, signs of third-degree torture were present. Which of the following incisions is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of custodial death. The incision that is preferred to detect and evaluate the hidden subcutaneous hemorrhage is the elongated X- shaped incision.

An elongated X-shaped incision is used to dissect subcutaneous structures in the back of the body. It helps identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries when superficial imprints are faint. This type of incision is helpful in the reconstruction of events before death and is practiced in custodial death.

The image below shows the 'elongated X- shaped' incision:


Option A: I-shaped incision is a simple, convenient, and most commonly practiced incision. It extends from the symphysis mentii to the symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left or right around the umbilicus. The umbilicus has dense fibrous tissue and is difficult to penetrate with the needle for suturing after autopsy.

The image below shows the 'I- shaped' incision:


Option C: Y-shaped incision commences at anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards to the symphysis pubis, as in the I-shaped incision. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision, and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

The image below shows the 'Y-shaped' incision:


Option D: In the modified Y-shaped incision, an incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from the suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. It is indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck.

The image below shows the 'modified Y-shaped' incision:

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text:
Match the lupus nephritis lesions with their treatments.
1. Focal Lupus Nephritis a. Only supportive treatment, no specific therapy
2. Membranous Lupus Nephritis b. A short course of high-dose corticosteroids
3. Mesangial Proliferative Lupus Nephritis c. Hemodialysis
4. Advanced Sclerosing Lupus Nephritis d. Corticosteroids+ Immunosuppressants +/- ACEs/ARBs
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c.

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of systemic lupus erythematosus, seen in about 30-50% of patients with SLE. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Management of lupus nephritis:

  • Class I (minimal mesangial) and II lesions (mesangial proliferative): They are associated with minimal or no symptoms and have an excellent prognosis. They do not require any therapy. 
  • Class III lesions (focal lupus nephritis): They are associated with few symptoms and a good prognosis. Management includes the administration of a short course of high-dose corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents.
  • Class IV lesions (diffuse lupus nephritis): Manifestations include hematuria, nephrotic-range proteinuria, and renal casts. Treatment includes the administration of high-dose steroids combined with either cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil for 2–6 months. It is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine.
  • Class V lesions (membranous lupus nephritis): They are associated with severe manifestations and a poor prognosis. Management includes the administration of steroids in combination with other immunosuppressive agents. Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system may be administered to attenuate proteinuria.
  • Class VI lesions (advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis): They present with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and require hemodialysis.

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 
  • Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli
  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus
  • Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight woman presents with complaints of irregular periods for the last year. Physical examination revealed a BMI of 32 kg/m2 with signs of hirsutism. Pelvic sonographic findings show multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). Centrochroman is not used in the treatment of PCOD. 

PCOD is attributed to obesity, smoking, and poor diet. The affected ovary or ovaries have cysts (12 or more) that are composed of atretic follicles, coupled with theca and stromal cell hyperplasia.  

Symptoms of PCOD include hirsutism and acne (due to hyperandrogenism), anovulation followed by amenorrhea, or heavy menstrual or intermenstrual bleeding.

Diagnosis is made by pelvic ultrasound which shows "necklace" appearance. Endomtrial hyperplasia may also be present. 

Treatment of PCOD includes lifestyle modification such as smoking cessation, diet, and exercise with a focus on weight reduction, combined oral contraceptives to regularize menstrual cycles and decrease androgen levels. 

To treat hirsutism, 5α-reductase inhibitors like finasteride are effective; eflornithine hydrochloride cream prevents hair growth.
 
Clomiphene is the first line of treatment for women with infertility. It may be combined with dexamethasone to improve the fertility rate.

Metformin treats the root cause of PCOS, rectifies endocrine and metabolic functions, and improves the fertility rate. It is used as an insulin sensitizer and induces spontaneous ovulation.

Surgery is indicated when medical therapy fails, when there is a history of previous pregnancy losses, when there is infertility, or when hyperstimulation occurs. Surgery comprises of laparoscopic ovarian drilling of not more than 4 cysts in each ovary by laser or unipolar electric cautery. It improves fertility for a period of one year. 

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child has a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents typically with fixed wide split S2, a classic finding of the atrial septal defect (ASD), a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease.

ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration. This leads to a fixed wide split S2.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations.

A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard. Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum.

Other options:

Option A: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is typically associated with a pan-systolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is typically associated with a harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border (pulmonic area) with a single 2nd heart sound (S2)

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is characteristically associated with a machinery murmur.

Related Pearl: Locations of Congenital Heart Disease

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Obstructive lesions:

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

Persistent Truncus arteriosus

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

Tetrology of Fallot

Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication

Ebstein anomaly

Eisenmenger's syndrome

VSD with pulmonic stenosis

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation

questions.text: A young butcher presents with headache, vomiting, dizziness, visual impairment, and altered mental status. On performing a CT scan, ring-enhancing lesions are found, along with some nodular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a butcher with the given symptoms, along with the CT scan showing ring-enhancing lesions with some nodular calcifications, is suggestive of neurocysticercosis. This condition is caused by Taenia solium.

T. solium is also known as the pork tapeworm. Humans are the only definitive hosts for T. solium, whereas pigs are the usual intermediate host. When humans consume undercooked pork containing cysticerci, they acquire the infection leading to intestinal tapeworms.

Cysticerci can be found anywhere in the body but are most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or the eye. Neurocysticercosis usually presents with neurological manifestations like seizures and hydrocephalus. Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure are often seen.

Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs or proglottids in the stool. More sensitive methods like ELISA and PCR may also be used. Clinical diagnosis can only be made with the help of neuroimaging findings and exposure history.

Major neuroimaging findings include cystic lesions with or without enhancement, nodular calcifications, focal enhancing lesions, or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Brain parenchymal cysticerci are treated with a combination of praziquantel and albendazole. These drugs cause inflammatory responses around the deadly parasite, and therefore glucocorticoids should also be started along with antihelminthic.

The image given below shows an MRI of the brain that shows multiple cysts containing scolices in a patient with neurocysticercosis.

Other options:

Option B: Only the adult forms of T. saginata develop in humans and not the cysticerci. Therefore, it cannot cause cysticercosis in humans.

Option C: Bacteroides spp. is a causative organism for brain abscesses which are seen on a contrast-enhanced CT as ring-enhancing lesions. However, such a brain abscess is usually secondary to otitis media, mastoiditis, or paranasal sinusitis. This patient does not have any other disease, which makes brain abscess less likely.

The image given below shows a brain abscess.

Option D: Toxoplasma gondi causes toxoplasmosis. It is one of the most common causes of secondary CNS infection in AIDS patients. It usually occurs as a late complication when CD4+ T-cell counts <200/μL. It presents with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI shows ring enhancement lesions in the brain due to inflammation and central necrosis in the lesions.

The image given below shows ring-enhancing lesions seen in cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Differential diagnoses for ring-enhancing lesions include:

  • Brain abscess
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Central nervous system lymphoma
  • Tuberculoma

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He has difficulty in speaking.  Angiography findings are shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the angiography showing a puff of smoke appearance is suggestive of Moyamoya disease.

Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving the large intracranial arteries.

It has a bimodal age distribution in the first and fourth decades. Childhood moyamoya disease is characterized by ischemic manifestations, whereas adult moyamoya disease is marked by hemorrhagic manifestations.

Vascular inflammation is absent. Since it is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a puff of smoke (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography.

The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA.

Treatment: Surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral artery may prevent stroke and hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections is not related to grievous injury?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt) that includes bodily pain, infirmity, or disease caused to any individual.

Grievous hurt or injury is defined to include injuries such as emasculation, permanent damage to eyesight (either eye), permanent damage to hearing (either ear), damage to any member or joint, destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfigurement of the head or face, fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth, and any hurt that endangers the victim's life or causes them severe bodily pain, thereby impairing their ability to follow their daily routine for a period of 20 days. 

Other options:

  • Section 320 - Defines grievous hurt
  • Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by a dangerous weapon (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Section 331: Causing grievous hurt to extort confession (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine) or to compel restoration of property.

Other IPC sections related to grievous hurt:

  • Sec 322: Voluntary causation of grievous hurt.
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment up to 7 years with fine)
  • Sec 329: Causing grievous hurt to extort property (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 333: Causing hurt to deter public servant from the duty (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 335: Causing grievous hurt on grave or sudden provocations (imprisonment with 4 years + or –fine)
  • Sec 338: Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life/safety of others (imprisonment with 2 years + or –fine)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with a sensation of rapid heartbeat, increased sweating, and dizziness. The ECG obtained is shown below. His BP is 126/82 mm of Hg. After failed attempts of maintenance with vagal maneuvers, what would be your treatment option?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ECG showing narrow QRS complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Intravenous adenosine is preferred for the termination of arrhythmia in stable patients (blood pressure is normal) with regular, narrow complex PSVT. It is given rapidly in a dosage of 6-12 mg. It successfully terminates the arrhythmia (within 1 minute) in more than 90% of the cases.

Adverse effects of adenosine:

  • Transient chest pain
  • Dyspnea
  • Anxiety
  • Precipitates atrial fibrillation (AF)
  • May aggravate bronchospasm

Contraindications of the use of adenosine include patients with prior cardiac transplants since they have potential hypersensitivity due to surgical sympathetic denervation.

It should be cautiously used in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome due to the precipitation of atrial fibrillation leading to hemodynamic instability.

When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e. when the patient has hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress, QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with sudden-onset bilateral lower extremity weakness, back pain, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, and loss of bowel function. Cranial nerve functions and upper-limb neurological functions are normal. Motor strength in the lower limbs is grade 4 on both sides. Sensation was diminished to light touch in the T12-S3 dermatome bilaterally. There is no loss of pain or temperature sensation. Ankle reflex is lost, but knee reflex is intact. Bilateral Babinski's reflex and diminished rectal tone were present. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and history are suggestive of conus medullaris syndrome secondary to a compressive tumor (spinal metastasis from lung cancer).

The conus medullaris is the tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord, comprising the sacral and single coccygeal segments.
The conus medullaris syndrome consists of
  • Symmetrical loss of sensation in the perianal region (bilateral saddle anesthesia) (S3-S5)
  • Prominent bladder and bowel dysfunction (early onset urinary retention and incontinence with lax anal tone)
  • Impotence
  • Absent bulbocavernosus (S2-S4) and anal (S4-S5) reflexes 
  • Largely preserved muscle strength
  • Loss of ankle reflex (S1)
  • Knee reflex usually preserved (L3-L4)  

Conus medullaris syndrome presents more acutely than cauda equina syndrome. 

Other options:

Option A- Central cord syndrome results due to damage to the gray matter nerve cells and crossing the spinothalamic tract around the central canal. Involvement of the spinothalamic tract results in loss of pain and temperature sensation which is not seen in this patient. It presents as arm and leg weakness, and dissociated sensory loss i.e. pain and temperature are lost whereas light touch, joint position, and vibration sense are intact. Important causes are spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors.

Option B- Compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the level of termination of the spinal cord that is L1-L2 results in cauda-equina syndrome. Common causes of cauda equina syndrome include ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disc, epidural hematoma, vertebral fracture, and compressive tumor. Low back pain, asymmetrical loss of sensation, asymmetrical weakness, variable areflexia, saddle anesthesia (loss of sensation in the buttocks and perineal region) are common presenting symptoms. Relative sparing of bowel and bladder functions with late-onset retention symptoms is seen.

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome is a hemi-transection of the spinal cord. It presents with ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract), ipsilateral loss of position, and vibration sense (posterior column), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature one or two levels below the lesion.

Note: Mass lesions in the lower spinal canal often produce a mixed clinical picture with elements of both cauda equina and conus medullaris syndromes.

Related Pearl: Conus medullaris syndrome vs Cauda equina syndrome

 

Conus medullaris syndrome

Cauda equina syndrome
Injury

Vertebral column injuries between T12 and L2

 Vertebral column injuries distal to L2
Pathophysiology

Upper and lower motor neuron involvement

 Lower motor neuron involvement
Motor strength 

Symmetrical motor impairment 

 Asymmetrical motor impairment
Reflexes Knee jerk preserved, ankle jerk affected Both knee and ankle jerk affected
Sphincter dysfunction Urinary retention presents early in the disease course Urinary retention presents late in the disease course
 

Absent bulbocavernosus reflex
 

Radicular pain and low back pain

 

Related Pearl: The Medical Research Council scale for grading the muscle strength is :

Grade Description
Grade 0 No contraction
Grade 1 Flicker or trace of contraction
Grade 2 Active movement with gravity eliminated
Grade 3 Active movement against gravity
Grade 4  Active movement against gravity and resistance
Grade 5 Normal Power

questions.text: A child with a fever and rash was brought to your OPD. Oral findings as shown in the image were observed. During which period is the disease communicable to others?

choices.text: Before the appearance of the rash
After the appearance of the rash
Before as well as after the appearance of the rash

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing Koplik spots are suggestive of measles. It is communicable before as well as after the appearance of the rash.

Measles, otherwise known as rubeola, is caused by the paramyxovirus, which is an RNA virus. The virus has an incubation period of 10 to 14 days. It is a droplet nuclei infection and the period of communicability ranges from 4 days before to 4 days after the appearance of the rash. 

The prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomonic Koplik spots. Koplik spots are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa at the level of the premolars.

This is followed by the appearance of a characteristic dusky red maculopapular rash that begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.

The diagnosis of measles infection is mainly clinical but may be confirmed by serological demonstration of serum IgM antibodies. 

The management is mainly supportive in form of relieving common symptoms such as fever, cough, and nasal congestion and providing adequate nutritional support.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

 

Disease

Duration of Isolation

Chickenpox

Until all lesions are crusted – usually about 6 days after onset of rash.

Measles

From the onset of symptoms (catarrhal stage) to 5 days after the appearance of the rash

Cholera

Until 3 days of tetracycline therapy.

Diphtheria 

Until 48 hours of antibiotics.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

3 weeks.

Influenza

3 days after onset.

Polio

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

Until the swelling subsides.

Pertussis

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease. 

Meningococcal meningitis

Until the first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.

Streptococcal pharyngitis

Until the first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old traffic policeman came to the surgical outpatient department with tortuous swellings on his lower limb. He then presents 3 months later with physical examination findings as shown in the image given below. Choose the option that correctly represents his findings under the 2020 revised CEAP classification.

CEAP - Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of atrophie blanche, which is classified as C4B under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as follows:

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes,

  • C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  • C4c for corona phlebectatica
  • C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

C0

C1

C2

to chronic venous disease

C6

Ec

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A person suffering from malabsorption is found to have decreased secretions in the digestive tract. A pathology involving Meissner's plexus is suspected. Where in the intestinal wall is this neuronal plexus located?
questions.solution:
Meissner’s plexus is present in the submucosa. 

The enteric nervous system consists of 2 neuronal plexuses:         
        • Myenteric or Auerbach's plexus and 
        • Submucosal or Meissner's plexus

The myenteric plexus (Auerbach plexus) is present between the inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layers. It controls gastrointestinal movements of peristalsis. On stimulation, these nerve fibres increase the tonicity, intensity, rhythm and velocity of the intestinal contractions. But they also have inhibitory effects through inhibitory transmitters like vasoactive intestinal polypeptide. It inhibits the pyloric sphincter and the sphincter of the ileocecal valve.

The Meissner's plexus leads to increased intestinal secretions, absorption and contraction of the submucosal muscle.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency department with a fever and persistent cough. On examination, chest retractions and tachypnea were noted and expiratory wheezes were heard over both lungs. The culture of the nasopharyngeal swab showed characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Which of the following is most likely to have caused this infection?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture, along with the culture showing characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation, is characteristic of bronchiolitis, which is most likely to be caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

RSV is responsible for more than half of the cases of bronchiolitis in infants less than 1 year of age. Viral transmission is by close contact, droplet transmission, and through contaminated fingers and fomites.

The disease may begin as febrile illness, with cough and wheezing. RSV causes a broad range of respiratory illnesses. Outbreaks are commonly seen in pediatric wards, nurseries, and daycare centers. RSV also causes otitis media in children. 

Samples are collected by nasopharyngeal swabs and nasal washings. They are inoculated in cell culture (HeLa or Hep-2) immediately after collection. In cultured cells, RSV shows characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Cytopathic effects usually appear after 10 days of culture.   

The image given below shows giant cells and syncytial formation seen in RSV infection.

Continuous administration of ribavirin is found beneficial for hospitalized patients.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinovirus attaches to receptors on nasal ciliated epithelial cells, enters and replicates within them, spreading to other cells and causing local inflammation and the common cold.

Option B: Adenovirus types 3 and 7 cause pneumonia in adults. In infants and young children, type 7 causes serious and fatal pneumonia.

Option C: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) causes cytomegalic inclusion disease that occurs in infants born to mothers who develop primary CMV infection during pregnancy.

questions.text: The combination of dal and rice is considered complementary food because they complement the amino acids deficient in each other. Dal and rice, respectively, lack _____.
questions.solution:
Dal lacks methionine, while rice lacks lysine.

 Principal Food   Amino acid deficient
Cereals (in general)
(e.g. rice)		 Lysine 
Maize   Lysine and tryptophan 
Wheat  Lysine and threonine 
Pulses (Poor man’s meat)
(e.g. Dal)		 Methionine and cysteine 


Lysine, methionine, threonine, and tryptophan are known as limiting amino acids as they are the ones most commonly deficient in food items. Thus, a combination of two or more food items would form a proper vegetarian diet, in absence of meat proteins.

National Nutrition Week is celebrated from September 1st to 7th every year, to promote the importance of a well-balanced diet. The theme for this year is "Celebrate A World Of Flavours." The aim is to ensure that people have adequate nutrition in food, while also enjoying different flavors and cuisine.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male is diagnosed with chronic congestive heart failure and is started on beta-blockers. His symptoms fail to improve, and he is started on a new drug. His BP is 132/80 mmHg, and his heart rate is 84 beats/minute. He now complains of visual disturbances characterized by a transiently enhanced brightness in particular areas of the visual field. What is the drug he was likely to have been started on?
questions.solution:
The patient was likely started on ivabradine. 

Ivabradine may be used in chronic heart failure patients who do not tolerate β blockers or have a heart rate of >75 beats/min even with β blocker administration. One of its common side effects includes the development of phosphenes. Phosphenes are transiently enhanced brightness in specific areas of the visual field.

Ivabradine selectively blocks the hyperpolarization-activated sodium channels (HCN) in the SA node to reduce the pacemaker current If (Na+ funny current channel) and decreases heart rate. It reduces heart rate without affecting myocardial contractility, ventricular repolarization, or intracardiac conduction. The antianginal effect is mainly by reducing heart rate and thereby decreasing the O2 demand of the myocardium.

Other side effects include bradycardia, QT prolongation, and atrial fibrillation.

The hyperpolarization cyclic nucleotide (HCN) channels are also present on the retina. These channels on continuous blockade by ivabradine are hyperpolarized and lead to increased brightness in restricted areas of the visual field. These phenomena are known as phosphenes. 

Normally, the signal transduction pathway in the retina involves the opening of HCN channels. This leads to the influx of calcium to activate cGMP and causes recovery from light to dark. In cases where HCN channels are blocked, this pathway is affected and recovery from light to dark takes time resulting in increased brightness. The image attached below shows a normal transduction pathway.

Ivabradine is contraindicated for use in combination with diltiazem or verapamil.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with jerky movements of her extremities for 1 week. She has typical hand movements, which are shown in the image below. She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals jaundice. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with jaundice along with the clip showing a wing beating tremor is suggestive of Wilson's disease with decompensation. The gold standard for diagnosis is liver biopsy.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing-beating tremor 
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens, resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease, but not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state; therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of KF rings
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
  • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy - Gold standard
  • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

Treatment: Recommended anti copper Drugs for Wilson's Disease

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial    

Hepatitis or Cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and Zinc Penicillamine and Zinc
Moderate Trientine and Zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic Transplantation Trientine and Zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and Zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the POP-Q staging system?

choices.text: Stage 4 involves complete eversion of the vagina.
In stage 3, the leading point is 1 cm above hymen.
Five reference points are present in the vagina.
The points above the hymen are described as plus.

questions.solution:
The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system was described by the Interna­tional Continence Society and has the following features:

  • The hymen is taken as a fixed point. 
  • Six reference points are measured, using a scaled spatula:
    • Two on the anterior vaginal wall 
    • Two on the apical vagina
    • Two on the posterior vaginal wall 
  • Three measurements: The genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length.
  • The points above the hymen are described as minus and points below as plus.

Staging of pelvic organ prolapse according to the POP-Q system:

Stage Description
Stage 0 No descent of pelvic organs
Stage 1 The leading edge of the prolapse is >1 cm above the level of the hymen.
Stage 2 The leading edge of the prolapse is <1 cm proximal or distal to the hymen.
Stage 3 The leading point of prolapse is >1 cm below the hymen but protrudes no further than 2 cm less than the total length of the vagina.
Stage 4 Complete eversion of the vagina

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a long history of hypertension presents for a follow-up. He has tried hydrochlorothiazide but his hypertension remains uncontrolled. His BP is 158/96 mm of Hg, and his BMI is 35. Physical examination is notable for a bruit in the right flank. Duplex Doppler ultrasonography reveals severe stenosis of the right renal artery due to atherosclerosis. Which of the following drugs is recommended for the management of this patient's hypertension?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with a patient having resistant hypertension, with right flank bruit and Doppler findings of stenosis describes a case of right-sided renal artery stenosis. Medical management of renal artery stenosis is achieved using ACE inhibitors.

Clinical presentation: hypertension before 30 years of age, resistant or malignant hypertension, abdominal or flank bruit

Renal artery stenosis is a relatively common finding in older patients with chronic essential hypertension. However, it is clinically significant (i.e. renovascular hypertension) only if the stenosis is greater than 75% in both renal arteries or 50% stenosis with post-stenotic dilatation.

There are two major causes of bilateral renal artery stenosis:

  • Atherosclerosis (most common) - It affects patients over the age of 45 years.
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia - Most often affects women under the age of 50 years.
Unilateral renal artery stenosis Bilateral renal artery stenosis

Unilateral atherosclerosis

Unilateral fibromuscular dysplasia

External compression (e.g pheochromocytoma)  

Stenosis of only kidney

Systemic vasculitis

Atheroembolic diseases  

The gold standard for diagnosing renal artery stenosis is renal angiography. Other modalities include duplex doppler ultrasonography, computed tomographic angiography (CTA), and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)

Management: Medical management must be first pursued before vascular repair, with ACE inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers. They may result in a modest rise in creatinine due to a slight reduction in GFR of the stenotic kidney, but studies have shown that the total GFR is maintained due to a compensatory increase in GFR in the contralateral kidney.

If sufficient control is not achieved with ACE inhibitors or ARBs, other antihypertensives preferably thiazides, long-acting calcium channel blockers, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, or beta-blockers can be added as necessary.

Vascular repair may not benefit patients with advanced renal insufficiency, long-standing hypertension, or diabetes mellitus. Vascular repair shows better results in cases of fibromuscular dysplasia possibly due to younger age, shorter duration of hypertension, and less systemic disease.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with hot flushes. She is on treatment for diabetes and hypertension. She also has a history of smoking and had an episode of myocardial infarction 7 months ago. Which of the following is a contraindication for hormone replacement therapy (HRT) in this patient's clinical history?
questions.solution:
History of myocardial infarction indicates an arterial thromboembolic event, which is a contraindication for hormone replacement therapy.

HRT can be initiated in patients with a history of hypertension, diabetes, or smoking, provided they are regularly monitored. 

Hormone replacement therapy in post-menopausal women is indicated for vasomotor symptoms, vaginal atrophy, and prevention of osteoporosis. HRT is prescribed under supervision with minimal effective dose and the shortest needed duration.

Indications of HRT:

  • Symptomatic women who have estrogen deficiency
  • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as osteoporosis and Alzheimer’s disease
  • Premature menopause, spontaneous or following surgery 
  • Menopause caused by radiotherapy and chemotherapy for cancer
  • Women demanding HRT as prophylaxis

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease (stroke, MI)
  • Liver dysfunction or gallbladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids, as fibroids may enlarge in size

questions.text:
A child with diarrhea and malnutrition is prescribed ORS. The mother wants to know about the alternatives to ORS. How would you advise her to prepare a home-based solution in 1 liter of water?

ORS - Oral rehydration solution

choices.text: Add 6 teaspoon sugar + 1 teaspoon table salt
Add 1 teaspoon sugar + 6 teaspoon table salt
Add 1 teaspoon sugar + 1 teaspoon table salt
Add 6 teaspoon sugar + 6 teaspoon table salt

questions.solution:
To prepare home-based ORS for diarrhea, one should mix 6 level teaspoons of sugar + 1 level teaspoon of table salt in 1 liter of water.

Oral rehydration solution (ORS): It is a solution designed to replace fluids and electrolytes in patients with diarrhea. The 1:1 molar ratio of glucose and sodium in the WHO ORS is based on the principle of glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption in the gut.

Component Standard ORS (mmol/L)
Glucose 75 (anhydrous) 
Sodium 75
Potassium 20
Chloride 65
Citrate  10
Osmolality 245

  


ReSoMal is oral rehydration salt or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centers for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains more glucose (125 mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45 mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS.

Other home-made fluids containing salt are also recommended to improve hydration in children. Salt of about 3 g/L needs to be added to fluids that do not contain salt- such as water in which cereal has been cooked (e.g. rice water), unsalted soup, yoghurt drinks, green coconut water, weak tea, etc.

Some fluids like drinks sweetened with sugar are potentially dangerous in patients with diarrhea as they can cause osmotic diarrhea and hypernatremia. Other examples include carbonated beverages, commercial fruit juices, and sweetened tea. Fluids with stimulant diuretic or purgative effects such as coffee, medicinal tea with infusions, etc. should also be avoided.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) ReSoMal (mmol/L)
Glucose  75 125
Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3
Copper  --- 0.045
Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) 245 300

questions.text: The given image shows the renal handling of glucose. What is the cause of the phenomenon indicated by the parts labeled with question marks in the curves below?

choices.text: All nephrons have the same renal threshold
All nephrons have different transport maximum

questions.solution:
The marked phenomenon in the image is called renal splay. It occurs because all nephrons have different transport maximums (Tm).

For most solutes secreted or reabsorbed, there is a maximum limit to the rate at which the solutes can be transported. This is called the transport maximum (Tm).

In a normal healthy adult, the Tm of glucose is about 375 mg/min. When the filtered load exceeds this value, the tubules will no longer be able to reabsorb glucose. 

The filtered glucose load beyond which glucose starts to appear in the urine is called the renal threshold for glucose. Ideally, Tm and the threshold must have equal values. All the glucose will be reabsorbed by the tubules until the filtration rate reaches 375 mg/min. But glucose appears in the urine before reaching Tm. 

This difference between the threshold and transport maximum is called the splay phenomenon. The physiology behind this phenomenon is that not all nephrons have the same Tm. This leads to the excretion of glucose by nephrons with a lower Tm.

The overall Tm of glucose in kidneys (375 mg/min) is reached only when all the nephrons have reached their respective Tm.

For example, when the plasma glucose concentration is 100 mg/dl and the filtered load (red curve) is around 125 mg/min (normal), no glucose appears in the urine (green curve). But, in patients with diabetes mellitus, the plasma glucose concentration is above 200 mg/min. This leads to a subsequent increase in the filtered load to around 250 mg/min and a small amount of glucose begins to present in the urine.

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presents with occasional chest pain, pain along the left arm, and ptosis. He also complains of unintentional weight loss for the past month. His chest X-ray reveals a mass at the left lung apex with the destruction of adjacent ribs. He underwent the imaging modality shown, which revealed a high uptake within the tumour. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old smoker presenting with occasional chest pain, pain along the left arm, ptosis and unintentional weight loss for the past month with a chest X-ray revealing a mass at the left lung apex with the destruction of adjacent ribs and the FDG PET-CT scan shown above revealing a high uptake within the tumour is suggestive of a Pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour). 

Pancoast’s tumour is a rare form of lung cancer that originates at the apex of the lung. It has a unique presentation due to the stellate ganglion, chest wall and brachial plexus involvement.

It can invade the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 commonly), resulting in a radicular distribution of pain along the ulnar nerve. Invasion of the stellate ganglion results in Horner’s syndrome which presents with ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, enophthalmos, and anhidrosis. Shoulder and chest pain on the same side can result from the invasion into the chest wall and the 1st and/or 2nd ribs. Local spread, if involving the trachea or esophagus can result in dyspnea or dysphagia. 

Investigations:

  • MRI > CT is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumour/ Pancoast tumour.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumour cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumours to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Management is summarized in the flowchart as shown below.

Other options:

Option A: Small cell lung carcinoma is a highly malignant tumour that has a strong link to cigarette smoking. Tumours may arise in major bronchi or in the periphery of the lung. The presence of neurosecretory granules and the expression of neuroendocrine markers, such as CD56 and chromogranin, indicate that the tumour is derived from neuroendocrine progenitor cells found in the lining of the bronchial epithelium.

Option B: Bronchial carcinoid tumours typically arise as central masses that grow into finger-like polypoid masses that frequently protrude into the bronchus lumen. They are associated with features of carcinoid syndrome like diarrhoea, flushing and wheezing. Biopsy would show clusters of neuroendocrine cells and positive chromogranin A staining.

Option D: Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour with glandular differentiation. It originates from the terminal bronchiole and is typically found in the periphery. Tumour cells frequently "crawl" along normal-appearing alveolar septa in a lepidic pattern of spread near the tumour's periphery. 

Note:

Common symptoms of lung carcinoma include a persistent cough, weight loss, dyspnea, and non-specific chest pain. But severe localized pain suggests chest wall invasion with the infiltration of an intercostal nerve. Invasion of the apical area may involve the brachial plexus and must rise the suspicion of Pancoast’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient presented with arthralgia and skin pigmentation. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly, arthropathy involving small joints, excessive skin pigmentation with characteristic slate-grey hue, and hypogonadism. What will be the best treatment for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to hemochromatosis, and the best treatment for this iron-overload state is phlebotomy. One 500-mL unit of blood contains 200–250 mg of iron. Iron removal can be accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL.

With repeated phlebotomy, the following changes occur:

  • Liver decreases in size
  • Liver function improves
  • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
  • Pigmentation of skin decreases
  • Cardiac failure may be reversed
  • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients
  • There is little or no effect of arthropathy and hypogonadism. In some cases, arthropathy may even progress, despite therapy.

The goal is to reduce the serum ferritin levels to 50–100 ng/mL. Once the goal is reached, the phlebotomies may be done at appropriate intervals (usually, 3-4 times a year), required to maintain the serum ferritin levels at that level. 

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Clinical manifestations are initially non-specific like lethargy, arthralgia, skin pigmentation, and features of diabetes mellitus. The liver is the first organ to be affected, resulting in hepatomegaly, ascites, and spider angiomas. Other systems are also affected, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, congestive cardiac failure, and testicular atrophy. 

Pathogenesis:

The mutated HFE gene on chromosome 6p causes abnormally low levels of hepcidin, which is a principal iron regulatory hormone. This, in turn, leads to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. The excessively absorbed iron is primarily deposited in the parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas; heart; joints; and endocrine organs.

Other features:

  • Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anemia and transfusions.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce restrictive cardiomyopathy but it is less common as compared to DCM.

Diagnosis: Clinical features, family history, and laboratory investigations directed at diagnosing an increase in total body iron stores using serum iron, transferrin saturation, and serum ferritin levels. Liver biopsy with measurement of the iron concentration and calculation of the hepatic iron index. MRI of the liver is also indicated.

Other options:

Option B- Deferoxamine is a chelating agent, which removes 10–20 mg of iron per day when given parenterally. It is used in cases of severe iron load or when phlebotomy is not well-tolerated.

Options A and D- Trientine and D-penicillamine are chelating agents that bind to copper and are used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A group of health workers is conducting a perinatal mortality audit at a hospital. Which of the following should they not take into account to calculate the perinatal mortality rate?

choices.text: Number of live births per year
Number of late neonatal deaths per year
Number of stillbirths over 1000 g per year
Number of early neonatal deaths per year

questions.solution:
Number of late neonatal deaths per year is not included in the perinatal mortality rate.

The perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is calculated using the following parameters during a particular time period:

  • Late fetal deaths or stillbirths >1000 g - correlates to 28 weeks of gestation
  • Early neonatal deaths - from birth to 7 days of life
  • Live births >1000 g

The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) refers to the rate of deaths within the first 28 days of life. It is calculated using the following parameters:

  • Early neonatal deaths
  • Late neonatal deaths - after 7th day but before 28th completed day of life

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male undergoes a diagnostic work-up for backache; his X-ray is given below. What is the most common ocular manifestation that you would expect to see in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows bamboo spine, which is seen in ankylosing spondylitis. The most common ocular condition in ankylosing spondylitis is anterior uveitis. It is also the most common extraarticular manifestation in ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints commonly seen in young males. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. The progressive inflammatory granulation tissue in the spine in the paravertebral connective tissue leads to the bamboo spine.

Other extra-articular manifestations of AS:

  • Ocular: Iritis, conjunctivitis (reactive arthritis)
  • Cardiovascular: Valvular heart disease, aortitis, heart block
  • Neurologic: C1-C2 subluxation, cauda equina syndrome
  • GIT: Colitis, inflammatory bowel disease
  • Respiratory: Restrictive lung disease, upper lobe fibrosis

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious in onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at the age of <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for more than three months 

Examination findings:

There is a loss of normal lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion. Other findings :

  • Positive Fleche's test - It is done to assess cervical spine involvement. The patient is asked to touch the wall with the back of the head without raising the chin.
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement such as the pump-handle test, pelvic compression test, and Fabre’s test.
  • Schober’s test: It is used to detect reduced flexion of the spine. The test involves marking two points—one 10 cm above and one 5 cm below the level of the lumbosacral junction of the patient. The patient is then asked to bend forward, and the distance between the two points is measured. This distance normally increases by ≥5 cm. An increase of <4 cm indicates reduced flexion.

In the image below, the distance increases by 5 cm which is normal.

questions.text: As a 1st year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify the facial nerve trunk with respect to a 'Conley's pointer'. What is this pointer related to?
questions.solution:
'Conley's pointer' is related to the tragus of external acoustic canal. 

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include the following:

  • Conley's pointer/tragal pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric- The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Mastoid process- Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
  • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process- The facial nerve lies superficial to it.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
  • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
  • Temporal branch

The given image points to the facial nerve (marked by arrow):

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who is on anti-retroviral therapy presents with complaints of diarrhea for three days. An infectious etiology is ruled out on work-up. Which of the following drugs is preferred to manage his diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This is a case of non-infectious diarrhea associated with antiretroviral therapy (ART). Crofelemer is indicated for non-infectious diarrhea associated with ART in HIV/AIDS.

Crofelemer has minimal systemic absorption. It acts by inhibiting the cyclic AMP-stimulated CFTR chloride channel and calcium-activated chloride channels on the luminal side of the intestine.

questions.text:
Match the following innate immunity receptors with the products that they detect:
Receptors Detects
A. RIG-like receptors  1. Fungal glycans
B. C-type lectin receptors 2. Microbial sugars
C. Mannose receptors 3. Viral nucleic acids 
D. NOD-like receptor 4. Necrotic cells
questions.solution:
The correct answer is A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

RIG-like receptors (RLRs), are present in the cytosol of a majority of cells and detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of the infected cells. These receptors also stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines.

Mannose receptors recognize microbial sugars which contain terminal mannose residues and induce phagocytosis of these microbes.

C-type lectin receptors (CLRs): Expressed on the plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells. Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

NOD-like receptors (NLRs) are present in the cytosol, which recognize uric acid and released ATP (products of necrotic cells), ion disturbances (like loss of K+), and a few microbial products.

questions.text: A diabetic patient reports that his index finger initially remains bent, but with further effort, it suddenly straightens with a snap. On examination, a tender nodule can be felt in front of the metacarpophalangeal joint. The suspected deformity is called _______.
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of the trigger finger, and it is caused by the involvement of the flexor tendon.

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect.

The nodule can be trapped behind the A1 pulley, leading to a locking of the finger in flexion. Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed.

Other options: 

Option A: Mallet finger/baseball finger is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the distal interphalangeal joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g. a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.

Option C: Bouchard nodes are the osteophytes or bony lumps present in the proximal interphalangeal joints. These are seen in patients with osteoarthritis. 

Option D: Dupuytren's contracture is proliferating fibroplasia involving palmar aponeurosis. It causes flexion deformity of one or more fingers as a result of abnormal thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis. It is more common in males, and the incidence is higher in patients with cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes, smoking, and AIDS.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: Which of the following patients is at an increased risk of developing malignancy?

choices.text: A 40-year-old man with sessile serrated polyps

questions.solution:
Patients with sessile serrated polyps are at an increased risk of developing malignancy.

Histologically, sessile serrated polyps appear like hyperplastic polyps, but a serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands and lateral growth is the differentiating feature. They lack cytological features of dysplasia.

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: A patient who is a known asthmatic on low-dose inhalational corticosteroids comes to the OPD with complaints of acute exacerbations. On this visit, theophylline is added to his treatment regimen and shows better symptom control. He returns after a few days with complaints of nausea, headache, gastric discomfort, and excessive micturition. Which of his side effects is not due to phosphodiesterase-4  inhibition?
questions.solution:
The diuretic effect of theophylline is due to the blockade of adenosine (A1) receptors. All the other symptoms are caused by the inhibition of PDE4.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that acts by:

  • Inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE). PDE3 inhibition causes relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle and PDE4 inhibition causes inhibition of the release of cytokines and chemokines which further leads to a decrease in immune cell migration and activation.
  • Blockade of adenosine receptors, which inhibits bronchoconstriction. However, blockade of A1 receptors in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT causes diuresis.
  • Activating enzyme histone deacetylase-2, which is responsible for its anti-inflammatory action

Adverse effects of theophylline are usually related to plasma concentration ( >15 mg/L). The most common side effects are headache, nausea, and vomiting, abdominal discomfort (due to inhibition of PDE4), and restlessness.

At high concentrations, cardiac arrhythmias may occur due to inhibition of cardiac PDE3 and antagonism of cardiac A1 receptors. At very high concentrations, seizures may occur due to central A1 receptor antagonism.

A targeted plasma concentration of 5-10mg/L is maintained to avoid adverse effects and drug interactions.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: The dead body in a case of ligature strangulation is brought for autopsy. A 15 kg ligature around the neck will occlude all the following structures, except ______.
questions.solution:
Vertebral arteries will not be occluded with 15 kg of tension. According to Brouardel's experiment, a minimum of 30 kg tension is required for their occlusion.

The estimation of the force required to occlude the neck structures was done by Brouardel. 

  • Brouardel’s experiments suggest that a ligature with a tension of 2 kg blocks the jugular return.
  • The force needed to close the carotid artery is 5 kg and the trachea was 15 kg.
  • A ligature with a tension of 30 kg is necessary to occlude the vertebral arteries.

Note: Schwarzacher repeated Brouardel’s experiments in an improved setting and reported that a tension of 3.5 kg was sufficient to occlude the carotid arteries and a tension of 16.6 kg, to occlude the vertebral arteries.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man developed nausea and jaundice over the past week. Laboratory investigations revealed an active hepatitis B infection. The pathological finding in the liver is as shown below. Which pair of caspases initiate the process behind this pathology?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman's bodies, and they represent apoptosis. This process is initiated by caspase 9 (Intrinsic pathway) and caspase 8 (Extrinsic pathway). (Remember: Caspase Eight (8) = Extrinsic pathway) 

Councilman's bodies are acidophil bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis. They are seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die, activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 

Mechanism of apoptosis: There are two distinct pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • There are several proteins in the mitochondria that can induce apoptosis. These include cytochrome c and some proteins that neutralize the endogenous inhibitors of apoptosis.
  • The permeability of the mitochondria is controlled by a family of proteins called the BCL 2 family, which act as sensors.
  • These sensors are activated when the cells are deprived of growth factors and other survival signals, are exposed to agents that damage the DNA, or accumulate a large number of misfolded proteins.
  • These activated sensors, in turn, activate the proapoptotic molecules like BAX and BAK, which form channels in the mitochondrial membrane, through which cytochrome c and other mitochondrial proteins escape into the cytosol and cause activation of caspase-9, which in turn leads to the activation of the caspase cascade and, eventually, apoptosis of the cell.
  • On the other hand, if all the growth factors and other survival signals are present, then they produce more antiapoptotic members of the BH1-4 family like the BCL2, MCL 1 and BCL-XL. These proteins limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

The death-receptor (extrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • Death receptors are surface molecules that are members of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor family like the TNF 1 and Fas (CD 95).
  • These receptors are expressed on the surface of many cells and can trigger apoptosis. In the cytoplasmic region, these receptors have a “death domain.”
  • Fas ligand (FasL) is a membrane protein expressed mainly on activated T-lymphocytes. Fas-FasL interactions are required for thymic medullary negative selection. Defective interactions also cause the autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. 
  • When these T-cells recognize Fas-expressing targets, Fas molecules are cross-linked by FasL and bind adaptor proteins via the death domain.
  • These, in turn, recruit and activate caspase-8 and caspase-10.
  • In many cell types, caspase-8 and caspase-10 may cleave and activate a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family called Bid, thus feeding into the mitochondrial pathway.
  • The combined activation of both pathways delivers a lethal blow to the cell.
  • Cellular proteins, notably, a caspase antagonist called FLIP, block the activation of caspases downstream of the death receptors. Interestingly, some viruses produce homologues of FLIP, and it is suggested that this is a mechanism that viruses use to keep infected cells alive.
  • The death receptor pathway is involved in the elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes and in the killing of target cells by some cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.

questions.text: You are assigned to calculate the human poverty index (HPI) of a village in India. Which of the following parameters will you not include?

choices.text: Percentage of children underweight for age
Probability at birth of not surviving to age 40
Percentage of the population not using an improved water source

questions.solution:
For developing countries, HPI-1 is used, where the adult illiteracy rate is included, not the literacy rate.

HPI-2 is used for developed countries.

Human poverty index (HPI) measures deprivation in basic dimensions of human development.

The following picture table shows the components of HPI-1 and HPI-2.

Note: The term HPI is now replaced with a multidimensional poverty index:

  Human poverty index for developing countries (HPI-1) Human poverty index for selected OECD countries (HPI-2) 
A long and healthy life  Probability at birth of not surviving to age 40 Probability at birth of not surviving to age 60
Knowledge Adult illiteracy rate Percentage of adults lacking functional literacy skills
A decent standard of living

Percentage of the population not using an improved water source 

Percentage of children underweight for age

Deprivation of a decent standard of living

 Percentage of people living below the poverty line 
Social exclusion Not included as a dimension Long-term unemployment rate

Range of HPI is from 0 to 100.

questions.text: A man with a history of chronic cough, weight loss, and low-grade fever presents with complaints of lower urinary tract infection. Urodynamic studies revealed reduced bladder volume. Urinalysis revealed pus cells, but urine culture was negative. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tuberculous cystitis. 

Tuberculous urinary infection is secondary to renal tuberculosis. Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone. Urinalysis reveals pus cells without organisms and urine culture is negative (sterile pyuria). 

The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucosal edema. 

Subsequently, tubercles may be seen and, in longstanding cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced. This is known as a thimble bladder.

The IV urogram below shows a thimble bladder, which is seen in tuberculous cystitis. 

The patient is usually started on anti-tubercular drugs, and they rapidly respond to treatment. If bladder volume is greatly reduced, bladder augmentation surgery is done to avoid the risk of upper tract damage due to high filling pressure and vesicoureteric reflux. Bladder augmentation is done by ileocystoplasty or cecocystoplasty. 

Other options: 

  • Interstitial cystitis is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer), seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis. Clinical features include severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection. In the cystoscopic examination, fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) are seen in the bladder mucosa

  • Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function. Macroscopically, it appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes called Michaelis–Gutmann bodies. 

  • Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from irritation of the bladder mucosa due to indwelling catheters. The urothelium is thrown into broad bulbous polypoid projections as a result of marked submucosal edema.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
