questions.text: An IT professional was found to have vitamin D deficiency during a routine health check-up. He purchased vitamin D 60,000 IU sachets over-the-counter and started consuming them every day. After two weeks, he presented with severe colicky pain over the renal angle. His vitamin D levels are found to be elevated (170 ng/mL). Which of the following medications will be helpful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts vitamin D toxicity, which has led to hypercalcemia and renal stones. Among the given options, calcitonin can be used for the treatment of this condition.

Vitamin D toxicity occurs due to excessive intake of vitamin D supplements, usually in amounts of >40,000–100,000 IU/day. The symptoms are mainly due to hypercalcemia. Laboratory investigations will show elevated serum vitamin D levels (>100 ng/mL) and calcium.

In such patients, vitamin D supplements should be discontinued immediately, along with restricted exposure to the sun and avoiding calcium supplements. Since vitamin D is stored in the body for a long time, the symptoms may persist for some days even after stopping the intake.

Calcitonin and bisphosphonates are used in cases of severe toxicity causing hypercalcemia. Some patients might require glucocorticoids, which lower plasma calcium levels by reducing calcium absorption from the intestines and increasing its urinary excretion. 

Other options

Option B- Aspirin is used in the management of niacin-induced flushing.

Options C and D- Trientine and zinc are copper chelators. They are mainly used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Malignancy-Related

    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related

    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases

questions.text: A veterinary surgeon presents with fever, muscle pain, joint pain, fatigue, and weight loss for the past few weeks. On further inquiry, he says that his fever persists for weeks before it resolves, only to be followed by a relapse. You obtain his blood sample and inoculate it on the medium shown below to isolate the suspected organism. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette along with the given image is the Castaneda biphasic medium is suggestive of brucellosis. It is caused by organisms belonging to the Brucella species.

Brucella are small, non-motile, aerobic, capnophilic coccobacilli. The most important species that are pathologic to humans are B. melitensis, B. suis, and B. abortus.

Brucellosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs, and other animals.

Once the infection is transmitted, these bacteria resist intracellular digestion and proliferate within the reticuloendothelial system for a long time, and become resistant to simple antimicrobial therapy.

Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever, (remitting and relapsing fever), arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. Central nervous system symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms. 

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis includes:

  • The polymerase chain reaction is the most sensitive and reliable method of detection. 
  • Culture: Castaneda method/ biphasic medium. The solid component is the agar slant, and the liquid is the broth. The medium is inoculated with the specimen and incubated for four days in an upright position. Serial subcultures can be obtained by slanting the broth over the agar periodically to inoculate new colonies. 
  • Serological methods for specific antibody detection.
  • Tests for animals and animal products include tests such as the milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests.
    • Milk ring test- A sample of milk is mixed well with hematoxylin-stained brucella antigen and incubated. If the sample contains antibodies to brucella antigens, agglutination occurs with the agglutinate rising to the top as a blue ring. If the sample does not contain antibodies to brucella antigens, the whole of the sample is uniformly stained blue. 

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with at least two agents for six weeks duration. The preferred combination is intramuscular streptomycin 0.75-1 g per day for two to three weeks along with doxycycline 100 mg BD for six weeks. 

Prevention of brucellosis is important by screening and abiding by safety standards in farms and dairy industries, and also by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. In order to determine the resectability status, a CECT abdomen is performed. Which of the following vessels is not included in Varadhachary-Katz criteria for the resectability of pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Inferior mesenteric artery is not included in Varadhachary-Katz criteria. This criteria considers the following arteries:

  • Superior mesenteric artery (SMA)
  • Common hepatic artery (CHA)
  • Superior mesenteric vein-portal vein confluence (SMV-PV)

Varadhachary-Katz criteria are used to determine the resectability of pancreatic cancer:

Criteria

Resectable

(if all are satisfied)

Borderline resectable

(if any one is satisfied)

Unresectable

(if any one is satisfied)
AJCC stage I/II III III
SMA Not affected Abutment Encasement
Celiac axis Not affected Abutment Encasement
CHA Not affected Abutment Encasement
SMV-PV Patent Short segment occlusion Long segment occlusion

 

Abutment and encasement describe the tumor-vessel relationship based on a CT scan:

  • Abutment- The tumor is inseparable from the vessel (contiguity) for ≤180° or ≤50% of the vessel circumference.
  • Encasement- The tumor is inseparable from the vessel for >180° or >50% of the vessel circumference.

questions.text: A primigravida presents in the 2nd trimester complaining that her slippers do not fit anymore. You note bilateral pitting edema up to the level of ankles. It later disappears with bed rest. Her pulse rate is 90/min, and her BP is 130/86 mmHg. She is found to have normal cardiac output and urine analysis.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of physiological edema, which is a normal finding during pregnancy. The most appropriate treatment for physiological edema is bed rest.

Physiological edema occurs due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities due to the pregnant uterus compressing the common iliac veins. The most appropriate treatment for this is bed rest.

Features of physiological edema in pregnancy are:

  • Ankle edema, commonly limited to the right leg
  • Not associated with any other features of preeclampsia (like BP>140/90 mmHg, proteinuria)
  • Disappears with rest
  • Absence of other cardiac, renal, and hematological abnormalities

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the OPD with complaints of dysphagia. She also says that her hands and feet turn cold and blue when she goes to visit her daughter who lives in a hill station. Her examination findings are as given in the image. What is the earliest cutaneous manifestation that can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a woman with mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, and loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers. The clinical history describes Raynaud's phenomenon (hands and feet turn cold and blue in cold climate) and hence, the probable diagnosis is systemic sclerosis. The earliest cutaneous manifestations in systemic sclerosis are non-pitting edema and puffiness of the fingers, hands, and face. 

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and digital ulceration
  • Most patients have dysphagia and GERD
  • Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

Antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis 
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Using the Modified Rodnan Skin Score (MRSS), the degree of skin sclerosis is scored from 0 to 3 by manual palpation at 17 different body sites. The maximum score that can be attained is 51. This method has been shown to correlate with skin biopsy thickness, disease severity, and long‐term outcome of the disease.

The scoring of each skin region is determined by skin thickness and tethering:
0 = Normal
1 = Possible thickening
2 = Unable to pinch the skin
3 = Unable to move the skin (which is fixed to deeper tissues)

This modified score does not include the assessment of the neck and back. If these areas are included, the maximum attainable score increases to 57.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

questions.text: A pregnant woman with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) has poor glycemic control despite being on insulin therapy. Her blood pressure is 138/92 mmHg. What is the appropriate gestational age for the delivery of her fetus?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the woman has poor glycemic control despite being on insulin and she also has high blood pressure. So, the most appropriate time for the delivery of the fetus would be 37 weeks. 

The timing for delivery in a pregnant woman with GDM would vary depending on the control of glucose levels and mode of treatment.

Glycemic control Gestational age
Well-controlled with diet 39-40 weeks
Well-controlled with insulin/oral agent 39 weeks-39 weeks + 6 days
Co-morbidity or suboptimal control Induction before 39 weeks
With poor glycemic control

Reasonable to deliver at 37-38 weeks + 6 days  

In extreme cases where all efforts for glycemic control such as hospitalization have failed, induction prior to 37 weeks (no clear-cut guideline )

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was diagnosed with pulmonary artery hypertension. He was prescribed an endothelin receptor antagonist for the management of the same. After starting the drug, he developed nasal congestion and pharyngitis. Which of the following drugs was prescribed?
questions.solution:
The drug prescribed is bosentan. 

The clinical scenario of the development of nasal congestion and pharyngitis after administration of an endothelin receptor antagonist given for the treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension suggests that the drug prescribed is bosentan.

  • ETA - This receptor is localized on the pulmonary artery smooth muscle cell. It is a G-protein coupled receptor and acts via the IP3-DAG pathway elevating cytosolic Ca2+ thus causing vasoconstriction.
  • ETB - This receptor is present on the pulmonary artery smooth muscle cell and endothelial cell. It is a G-protein coupled receptor and on activation, the ETB receptors on the endothelial cells increase the production of PGI2, NO and inhibit ET-1 production.

Endothelin receptor antagonists act by either non-selectively inhibiting both endothelin receptors or by selectively inhibiting ETA receptors only. The nonselective endothelin receptor antagonists are bosentan and macitentan. The selective endothelin receptor antagonists are ambrisentan and sitaxsentan. Sitaxsentan is the most selective ETA receptor antagonist. These drugs are predominantly used in the treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension.

Side effects:

  • Headache
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Nasal congestion/pharyngitis
  • Hepatotoxicity -  needs monitoring and contraindicated in patients with mild-moderate liver disease.
  • Teratogenic - contraindicated in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A- Epoprostenol is a synthetic PGI2, It acts by inhibiting myosin light chain kinase and activating K+ channels. It is the mainstay of treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension, particularly in advanced stages. The important side effects include myalgia, jaw pain, nausea, flushing, and systemic hypotension.

Option C- Inhaled NO acts by activation of soluble guanylyl cyclase → activates cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An important side effect is methemoglobinemia.

Option D- Sildenafil acts by competitive inhibition of phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE5). Important side effects are headache, flushing and blue-green vision.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male whose BMI is 32 is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat diabetes but not cause weight loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pioglitazone is used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus and can cause edema and weight gain, rather than weight loss. 

Thiazolidinediones include drugs like pioglitazone and rosiglitazone and act by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors-gamma (PPAR-γ). These receptors are expressed predominantly in adipose tissues and cause adipocyte differentiation. It also facilitates the uptake of fatty acids and lipid stores to adipose tissues.

They produce anti-glycemic action by increasing tissue sensitivity to insulin. They increase insulin-mediated glucose uptake in skeletal muscle. They also reduce hepatic glucose production and increase hepatic glucose uptake. These drugs require the presence of insulin for their action as anti-diabetic agents and hence cannot be used to treat type-1 diabetes mellitus.

These drugs are contraindicated in patients with moderate-to-severe heart failure and liver failure. They must be used with caution in patients with osteoporosis.

Other options:

Option A: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist that provides glycemic control and also facilitates weight loss.

Options B: Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor that also causes weight loss.

Option D: Metformin is a biguanide and is associated with weight loss, especially in obese patients.

questions.text: All the following organisms would test positive for the reaction shown in the image below, except ______.
questions.solution:
The image given shows a slide with a positive catalase test. All the organisms mentioned above test positive for this test, except Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Catalase test is demonstrated by placing a microbial colony in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The catalase enzyme degrades hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles. The test is particularly useful in the differentiation of staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative).

 

Catalase-positive organisms Catalase-negative organisms
  • Staphylococcus
  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio    
  • Nocardia
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella   
  • Enterobacteriaceae   
  • Listeria
  • Neisseria  
  • Corynebacterium
  • Yersinia
  • Streptococcus
  • Enterococcus
  • Lactobacillus

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for infertility. You decide to estimate her ovarian reserve. Which of the following can be evaluated on any day of the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), which is secreted by the granulosa cells, is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the cycle.

Tests for ovarian reserve: Ovarian reserve means the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. The other indicators include the following:

  • FSH - FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle) - High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted (FSH is highest in postmenopausal women). FSH (values >25 mIU/ml) levels are higher than normal in women with a reduced ovarian reserve and ovarian hypofunction. 
  • Serum estradiol values on day 3 of the cycle. Serum oestradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • LH - values <10 IU/L indicate poor reserve
  • Antral follicular count - counts less than 4–5 on days 2–5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B - values <40 pg/mL indicates poor reserve

Values and interpretation:

  • Normal value: 2–6.8 ng/mL
  • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
  • PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome: >10 ng/mL

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old daughter to the outpatient department with concerns about early breast development in the child. All of the following conditions could have caused precocious puberty in this child, except ________.
questions.solution:
All of the listed options present with precocious puberty, except Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with delayed puberty.

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the deletion of a part of the paternal chromosome 15. The clinical features include neonatal hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, dysmorphic facial features, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems.

Precocious puberty is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in females and 9 years in males. Precocious puberty with secondary sexual characteristics of the patient's own gender is termed isosexual, and that with secondary sexual characteristics of the opposite gender (such as virilization in girls) is termed contrasexual.

Isosexual precocious puberty can be categorized as follows:

  • Complete - This occurs due to the premature activation of the intact hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. The causes of complete isosexual precocious puberty, which is GNRH-dependent include the following:
    • Idiopathic true precocious puberty
    • Central nervous system disorders such as hypothalamic hamartomas, encephalitis, and brain abscess
  • Incomplete - This includes premature thelarche and premature adrenarche. The causes of incomplete isosexual precocious puberty are as follows:
    • GnRH-secreting tumors
    • Increased androgen secretion by adrenal or testis such as in congenital adrenal hyperplasia
    • Ovarian cysts and estrogen-secreting ovarian or adrenal neoplasms
    • McCune-Albright syndrome

Contrasexual precocial puberty can be seen in both males and females:

  • Feminization in males due to conditions such as adrenal neoplasms and chorioepithelioma
  • Virilization in females due to conditions such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, virilizing adrenal neoplasms, and iatrogenic exposure to androgens

questions.text: Who or which of the following is known as the ‘Father of Public Health’?
questions.solution:
Father of Public Health is the cholera disease, not a person.

Other options:

  • Tuberculosis is called the barometer of social welfare.
  • John Snow is called the father of modern epidemiology. He studied the epidemiology of cholera and established the role of polluted drinking water in the spread of cholera.
  • Louis Pasteur is the father of modern microbiology.

questions.text: A baby was brought with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. There were no neurological signs and no palpable mass. During her pregnancy, the mother did not have an elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a tuft of hair over the lower back in a baby, along with the absence of neurological signs, palpable mass, and serum alpha-fetoprotein within the normal range during pregnancy suggests a likely diagnosis of spinal bifida occulta. 

Spina bifida occulta refers to fusion defects of the posterior part of the vertebral body. There is no associated protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. These neonates are usually asymptomatic, without any neurological signs. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back. 

Elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein level during pregnancy suggests an open neural tube defect, such as meningocele, meningomyelocele, and encephalocele (Option A, B, and C).

Meningocele involves the midline protrusion of the meninges. A fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate is present in the lower back along the vertebral column. Meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering. Neurological dysfunction is more common in these open defects.

The image below shows (from left to right) spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele.

 

Encephalocele refers to the protrusion of intracranial tissue through a midline bony defect.

The two images below show babies with encephalocele, i.e. midline neural tube defects of the cranial end.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Abnormal MSAFP

Elevated levels

  • Underestimated gestational age
  • Multifetal gestations
  • Fetal death
  • Neural tube defects
  • Gastroschisis
  • Omphalocele
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Esophageal or intestinal obstruction
  • Liver necrosis
  • Renal anomalies
  • Cloacal exstrophy
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Congenital skin abnormality
  • Pilonidal cyst
  • Chorioangioma of placenta
  • Placenta intervillous thrombosis
  • Placental abruption
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Maternal hepatoma or teratoma
 Low levels 
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Trisomies 21 or 18
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Overestimated gestational age

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric department with severe pain in the hands and feet. On examination, corneal opacities and telangiectatic skin lesions on the thighs were observed. On further investigation, he is found to be deficient in α-galactosidase A enzyme. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism due to deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme. This enzyme deficiency leads to accumulations of neutral glycosphingolipids, primarily globotriaosylceramide, especially in the plasma and lysosomes of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, and renal podocytes.

Features of Fabry disease:

  • Angiokeratomas - telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area
  • Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating
  • Corneal and lenticular opacities
  • Painful acroparesthesias 
  • Fabry crises - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities
  • Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent Maltese cross

Arrhythmias, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and heart failure are some of the important cardiovascular manifestations. The most common valvular lesion is mitral insufficiency. Cardiac arrhythmias may result in transient ischemic attacks and stroke. Renal failure, characterized by proteinuria, isosthenuria, azotemia, and gradual deterioration of renal function, is seen. Renal failure, cardiac disease, or stroke are the major causes of mortality in patients with Fabry disease.

Below is the image of angiokeratomas distributed along the bathing trunk area.

Other options:

Option A- Niemann-Pick disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. The clinical features include a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option B- Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides, preferentially in the central nervous system. Affected children present with seizures, developmental delay, increased startle response, macrocephaly, and cherry-red spots in the eye. 

Option D- Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the reticuloendothelial system. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells, a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: Houston's valves are the structures present in which part of the digestive tract?
questions.solution:
Three transverse mucosal folds (also known as Houston's valves) are commonly present in the rectum.

The transverse mucosal folds are permanent and become very prominent on distension of the rectum.

  • The superior transverse fold - present at either side of the beginning of the rectum and may occasionally encircle the entire lumen.
  • The middle transverse fold - largest and constant fold present above the rectal ampulla. It projects from the anterior and right wall of the rectum.
  • The inferior transverse fold - most variable and found on the left side.

Apart from these, the rectal mucosa has several longitudinal folds, which disappear on distension of the rectum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of fatiguability that worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after rest, along with oculobulbar symptoms such as ptosis, dysarthria, and dysphagia. From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles.

It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or during late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Graves' disease, neuromyelitis optics, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increase transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine
  • Thymectomy
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin

Other options:

Option B:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the presynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction. It is due to the autoantibodies against the P/Q-type calcium channels at the motor nerve terminal which results in the impaired release of Ach from the presynaptic nerve terminal.

Patients present with proximal muscle weakness of the lower limbs, ptosis, and diplopia. However, symptoms might improve after brief exercise. Deep tendon reflexes are absent or reduced. They also experience autonomic dysfunction and present with dry mouth and impotence. It is most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer. 

Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows an incremental response at higher rates.

Treatment involves plasmapheresis, immunotherapy, and drugs such as 3,4-diaminopyridine (3,4-DAP) and pyridostigmine.

Option C:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is X-linked muscular dystrophy due to mutations in the dystrophin gene. It most commonly affects boys in their childhood. 

Patients initially present with proximal muscle weakness predominantly of the lower limbs. Calf muscle hypertrophy is a cardinal feature. Other features include mental retardation, cardiac failure, and myoglobinuria.

Elevated serum creatinine kinase levels and genetic testing are diagnostic of DMD.

Option D:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. It predominantly occurs in middle-aged women. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis.

Anti-nuclear antibodies, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE.

 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: As a medical officer, you have to calculate the secondary attack rate of an unknown respiratory infection in your village. Considering the incubation period of the disease to be one week, which of the following would you include in the denominator?

choices.text: Total number of close contacts both immunized and non-immunized
Total number of susceptible people along with the primary case
Total number of susceptible close contacts
Total number of close contacts developing the disease within 1 week

questions.solution:
Total number of susceptible close contacts is a part of the denominator of the secondary attack rate.

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that disease occurs among susceptible persons, following exposure to an infectious person within the range of the incubation period.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/ (Total number of susceptible close contacts).

The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease. The ones who are dead/ immunized/ not susceptible/ primary cases are excluded from the denominator.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of smoking 2 packs of cigarettes a day for the past 10 years developed emphysema. He is ready to quit smoking and is getting ready to enrol himself in a program. Which of the following options best describes the stage he is in?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given scenario has decided to quit smoking and is ready to take action for the same, and thus is in the preparation stage. 

Motivation enhancement therapy (MET) is a systematic intervention approach for bringing about change in the addictive behavior seen in people with substance use disorders. It is based on the principle of motivational psychology and aims to enable the patient to deal with his addiction by producing internally motivated change.

Individuals in the preparation/determination stage make decisions to change their habits and are ready to take action. They start to take small steps toward behavior change. In the given scenario, the patient has made a decision to quit smoking and is taking small steps by preparing himself to enroll in a program. 

Addictive behaviors do not change abruptly, and go through gradual stages. The stages of motivation enhancement therapy (MET) include:

Precontemplation - individuals in this stage are often unaware that their behavior (eg. alcohol abuse) is problematic or is producing negative consequences. 

Contemplation - individuals in this stage recognize their problems and begin to think about changing their behavior. They weigh the pros and cons of change. They may still feel ambivalent about changing their behavior. 

Preparation or determination - individuals in this stage make decisions to change their habits and are ready to take action. They start to take small steps toward behavior change.

Action - individuals in this stage change their behavior and intend to keep moving forward with this change in behavior

Maintenance - individuals in this stage sustain their change in behavior for a while and intend to maintain this change going forward. People work to prevent relapse to earlier stages.

Other intervention for dealing with addictive behavior in substance use disorders includes the use of pharmacological agents like nicotine or bupropion for tobacco, disulfiram for alcohol, and naltrexone for opioids.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had fever and cough for 1 week, following which he developed a severe earache, decreased hearing, and a feeling of stuffiness in his left ear. Otoscopy revealed a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. He was managed with antibiotics. On follow-up after 12 weeks, persistent effusion was noted, and it was managed with the procedure shown below. Identify the instrument used in the procedure.
questions.solution:
The case described with fever, earache, erythematous, and bulging tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM), which is treated by antibiotics and incision of the tympanic membrane using a myringotome (myringotomy).

Treatment is with antibiotics, and supportive therapy like nasal decongestants, antipyretics, ear toilet, and dry heat. Myringotomy is the incision of the tympanic membrane using a sharp myringotome, to evacuate pus. It is indicated in ASOM when:

  • The tympanic membrane is bulging with severe pain
  • Persistent conductive hearing loss despite antibiotics
  • Persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.
  • Complications like facial paralysis, labyrinthitis, or meningitis with bulging tympanic membrane arise.
  • Recurrent acute otitis media

ASOM is an acute inflammation of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. The disease usually follows a viral upper respiratory tract infection and occurs in the following stages:

1. Stage of tubal occlusion: Eustachian tube gets blocked with retraction of the tympanic membrane and effusion in the middle ear. However, fluid may not be clinically visible. Patients present with mild deafness and earache, but no fever. Tuning fork tests show conductive deafness.

2. Stage of presuppuration: Prolonged tubal occlusion leads to pyogenic infection of the tympanic cavity. The tympanic membrane becomes congested with a leash of blood vessels along the handle of the malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane (cart-wheel appearance). Tuning fork tests show conductive hearing loss. Patients present with throbbing earache, deafness, tinnitus, and fever.

3. Stage of suppuration: Formation of pus in the middle ear, with bulging tympanic membrane and loss of landmarks. A yellow spot may be seen where a rupture might occur. Tenderness may be elicited over the mastoid antrum. Patients present with severe earache, increasing deafness and fever of 102–103 °F, vomiting, and even convulsions.

4. Stage of resolution: The tympanic membrane ruptures with the release of pus and symptoms subside. A small perforation is seen in the anteroinferior quadrant of pars tensa. 

5. Stage of complications: Acute mastoiditis, subperiosteal abscess, facial paralysis, labyrinthitis, petrositis, extradural abscess, meningitis, brain abscess, or lateral sinus thrombophlebitis may develop.

Other options:

Option A: Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used in mastoid surgery for the removal of bony septa and granulations.

Option B: Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula are used for proof punctures (antral lavage). Puncture using the trocar is done in the inferior meatus because this site is easily accessible and safe.

Option D: MacEwen’s curette is used in mastoid surgery to explore the air cells using one end and to curette the intervening septa and granulations with the other.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: An autopsy was done on a burn victim. Which of the following is a reliable indicator that the victim was alive while the fire was in progress?

choices.text: Vital reaction in the burned area
Redness of the exposed skin surface

questions.solution:
Elevated levels of carbon monoxide in the circulating blood and carbon particles in the air passages and lungs are reliable indicators suggesting that the victim was alive while the fire was in progress.

The carbon monoxide concentration in blood depends on various factors like the concentration of carbon monoxide in the air, blood hemoglobin level, duration of exposure, etc. The presence of carbon particles and elevated Carboxy hemoglobin levels are absolute proof that the victim was alive when the fire occurred. Though there is no definite level that confirms the presence or absence of carboxyhemoglobin in the blood, a level of 10% is needed to confirm unless the person is a heavy smoker.

Related Pearl: Differences between antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.text: A man presents with a 0.3-cm ulcer on the nose. Histopathology examination of a biopsy specimen from the lesion is given below. How is this cancer different from the others?

choices.text: It is invasive with no metastasis.
It is invasive with early metastasis.
It neither invades nor does it metastasize.

questions.solution:
The given scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma, which is invasive with no/rare metastasis.

All tumors with invasive property (malignant tumors) may not necessarily metastasize. 

Examples of tumors with invasive properties but do not metastasize are:

  • Gliomas
  • Basal cell carcinomas of the skin

Both of these cancers invade early in their course, but rarely metastasize. Thus, it is evident then that the properties of invasion and metastasis are separable.

Gross pathology of BCC consists of:

  • Pearly nodule
  • Tortuous telangiectatic vessels
  • Rolled border
  • Surface becomes ulcerated, with raised and beaded edge with a central scab, often with a central depression or umbilication.
  • Bleeding on slight injury is a common sign

The image given below shows gross appearance of basal cell carcinoma. Note the ulcerative lesion with raised and beaded edges.

Histopathology of BCC:

  • Tumor cells resemble the basal epidermal layer.
  • Cells grow into the dermis as cords and islands of basophilic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.
  • The tumor cells are arranged radially with their long axes in parallel alignment, demonstrating peripheral palisading.
  • The stroma retracts away from the carcinoma creating clefts or separation artifacts.

The given below is the histopathology image of BCC:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman underwent ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis prior to a procedure. Her abdominal ultrasonogram incidentally showed mobile, echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows in the gall bladder. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Echogenic foci in the gall bladder that produce acoustic shadows on ultrasonography are suggestive of cholelithiasis or gallstones.

Gallbladder stones or cholelithiasis is the most common gallbladder disease. It is usually discovered incidentally and becomes symptomatic when the stones obstruct the cystic duct. In symptomatic cases, patients may experience dull or colicky right upper quadrant or epigastric pain radiating to the back.

Ultrasonography (USG) is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. These stones appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. USG allows measurement of the size of the gallbladder and the thickness of the wall, as well as the detection of stones or polyps. USG also helps assess inflammation around the gallbladder, the size of the common bile duct, and stones in the extrahepatic biliary tree. The sensitivity of USG for gallstones is >95%.

The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder.

 

Plain radiograph of the gallbladder may show radiopaque gallstones in only 10% of patients. Rarely, the center of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to the ‘Mercedes–Benz’ or ‘seagull’ sign.

Prophylactic cholecystectomy is not warranted in most asymptomatic patients. Patients with severe or recurrent symptoms have a higher rate of complications of the disease. Hence they should undergo elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Other options:

Option B: Gallbladder polyps appear as small echogenic non-shadowing foci that are adherent to the gallbladder wall. They are often seen in a non-dependent part. They can be differentiated from stones by the lack of mobility and shadow.

Option C: Porcelain gallbladder is an uncommon condition, where calcification is seen to follow the contour of the gallbladder wall. It can be seen on CT scans. On USG, it appears as a curvilinear echogenic focus along the entire gallbladder wall, with posterior shadowing.

Option D: Gallbladder mucocele is the result of chronic gallbladder obstruction, without superimposed infection. The gallbladder may be distended and fluid-filled, and the mucocele may present as a mass.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Gall Bladder

  • Gallbladder Ultrasound: Investigation of choice for detection of gall stones
  • Abdominal X-ray: Useful in 
    • Calcified gall stones
    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)
    • Indicated for confirmation of suspected acute cholecystitis
    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

Abbreviations:

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text: An elderly female presents with recurrent chalazion. The curettage specimen should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of _____.
questions.solution:
A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of sebaceous cell carcinoma.

A chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands (otherwise known as a tarsal/meibomian cyst). It is the most common lid swelling seen.

Patients present with painless swelling away from the lid margin. The upper eyelid is more commonly involved.

The image given below shows the chalazion.

Treatment of chalazion includes:

  • Conservative management for a very small, soft, and recent chalazion.
  • Incision and curettage is the more conventional method of managing a chalazion. The contents are curetted out using a chalazion scoop. 
  • Intralesional steroids for chalazion located near puncta to avoid the risk of surgical damage.

A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).

The image given below shows the Lambert’s chalazion clamp and Meyerhoefer chalazion scoop used in chalazion surgery.

Note:

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common carcinoma of the lacrimal gland.
  • Basal cell carcinoma constitutes 85–90% of all malignant epithelial eyelid tumors. It is locally malignant and most commonly involves the lower lid, followed by the medial canthus, upper lid, and outer canthus.

questions.text: All of the following changes in the patient's behavior suggest an increased risk of suicide, except ______.

choices.text: Patient recovering from a suicidal depression
Patient with a history of multiple suicidal attempts
Sudden peace of mind in patient with depression
Patients with depression having low energy state

questions.solution:
Patients with depression having a low energy state are at a relatively lower risk for suicide. 

Antidepressants like fluoxetine (serotonergic action) may increase the energy state of patients with suicidal depression. This permits the patient to act on preexisting suicidal impulses because they have more energy. Due to this possibility of an association between selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and suicidal attempts, the FDA has issued a black box warning regarding the use of SSRIs.

In patients recovering from suicidal depression as the depression lifts, the patients become ener­gized and, thus, are able to put their suicidal plans into action. This is known as paradoxical suicide.

Patients with a history of suicidal attempts in the past have a relatively high risk of attempting suicide. Patients with depression who suddenly appear with peacefulness should be suspected of having a secret decision to commit suicide.

questions.text: A physician performs the test shown in the given image. Which of the structures labeled in the image below is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The test performed is Froment's test, and the test is positive. Therefore, the affected structure is the ulnar nerve, which is marked as '3' in the above image.

Froment's sign: Due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of the thumb is lost. When asked to hold a card, the patient tries to hold it by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the card.

Ulnar nerve branches and supply: 

Superficial branch supplies the palmaris brevis and skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of the deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except the first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

Tests used in ulnar nerve injuries:

  • Positive Egawa's test - Due to the weakness of dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger are weak.
  • Positive book test or Froment's sign - Due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. When asked to hold a book, patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.
  • Card test - Inability to hold a card between the fingers due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions

Posterior cord (STARS)

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6-C8)

Axillary (C5,C6)

Radial (C5-T1)

Lower Subscapular (C5,C6)

 

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text: A salesman met with an accident that led to him eventually losing his right foot. He has been unable to walk after this incident, and so, he has been rendered unemployed. According to WHO criteria, which of the following events will be deemed as a "handicap?"

choices.text: The salesman meeting with an accident
The salesman losing his right foot
The salesman being unable to walk

questions.solution:
The salesman being rendered unemployed is termed as "handicap" according to WHO.

The correctly matched events with WHO definitions in relation to the given example are as follows:

Event Example
Disease/Disorder Accident
Impairment Loss of foot
Disability Cannot walk
Handicap Unemployed

The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological, or anatomical structure or function". e.g., loss of a foot. An initial impairment may cause a secondary impairment as well.

The WHO defines disability as ''any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being". Because of impairment, the affected person may be unable to carry out certain activities, and hence, the person is considered disabled.

According to the WHO, a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfillment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex, and social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages experienced by a person as a result of disability makes them handicapped.

questions.text: You are given the following x-ray in the viva session. Which of the following is the likely reason behind this abnormal appearance?
questions.solution:
Crew-cut or hair-on-end appearance on X-ray imaging of the skull is due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, which is seen in thalassemia.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to extramedullary hematopoiesis, which causes the widening of the diploic space, thereby causing the thickening of trabeculae. This results in the classical crew-cut or hair-on-end appearance on x-ray imaging of the skull. Extramedullary hematopoiesis also leads to hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged and distorted bony prominences over the face, leading to the characteristic chipmunk facies in thalassemia.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the dermatology department with lesions over the skin as shown below. On examination, the lesions were dry, scaly, and slightly shiny, with moderately diminished sensation. Which type of leprosy do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with dry scaly lesions and moderately diminished sensation, with the image showing moderately hypo-esthetic annular plaques which are punched-out, is suggestive of the borderline type of leprosy.

Borderline (BB) leprosy is the most immunologically unstable type. The characteristic lesions of BB leprosy are annular plaques with well-demarcated, punched-out inner margins and sloping outer margins. They appear as large plaques with islands of clinically normal skin within the center, giving rise to a Swiss cheese appearance.


Other options:

Option A: Pure neuritic leprosy (PNL) is a rare variant of leprosy. It is characterized by the isolated involvement of peripheral nerve trunks in the absence of skin lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following water-associated diseases is wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
Cholera is a water-borne disease.

Water-related diseases are classified as:

Category

Examples
Water-borne diseases

Caused by ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal feces, or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses

e.g.: Cholera, typhoid, amebic and bacillary dysentery, and other diarrheal diseases
Water-washed diseases

Caused by poor personal hygiene

e.g.: Scabies; trachoma; flea-, lice- and tick-borne diseases, in addition to the majority of water-borne diseases (which are also water-washed)
Water-based diseases

Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water

e.g.: Dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis, and some other helminths.

 
Water-related vector-borne diseases 

Caused by vectors that breed in water

e.g.: Dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever

questions.text:
In the given image, the marked parts of the pancreas are mainly supplied by which of the following arteries?
  1. Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery
  2. Arteria pancreatica magna
  3. Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery
questions.solution:
The structures marked in the image are the head and the uncinate process of the pancreas.

They are supplied by

  • Superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries - branches of the gastroduodenal artery from the celiac trunk
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries - branches of the superior mesenteric artery

The body and tail of the pancreas are mainly supplied by the branches of the splenic artery:

  • Dorsal pancreatic artery
  • Greater pancreatic artery (Arteria pancreatica magna)
  • Artery to the tail of the pancreas

questions.text: A diabetic patient with foci of infection was diagnosed with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). Which of the following is not included under the diagnostic criteria for SIRS?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia is not a part of SIRS criteria. 

SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (temperature >38°C) or hypothermia (temperature <36°C)
  • Tachypnea (>20 breaths/min) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) of less than 32 mm Hg
  • Tachycardia (>90 beats/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/L or <4 x 109/L or >10% Band forms

Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty department following a fall on an outstretched hand. He has pain, deformity, and swelling over his left elbow. The x-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the injuries and complications associated with this condition?

choices.text: Gunstock deformity due to cubitus valgus  is a complication.
Vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery.
Ulnar nerve  is most commonly injured in flexion type fracture.
Anterior interosseous nerve is most commonly injured in extension type fracture.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, and it is associated with cubitus varus deformity or gunstock deformity.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

  • Most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years.
  • Most common type of supracondylar fracture: Extension type > Flexion type
  • Most common mechanism of injury: Fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension
  • Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures

Gartland classification (in children):

  • Type I: Undisplaced
  • Type II: Displaced but posterior cortex is intact
  • Type III: Displaced but no intact posterior cortex and distal fragment could be either displaced:
    • Posteromedial
    • Posterolateral
  • Type IV: Complete loss of anterior and posterior periosteal hinge making it unstable in both flexion and extension

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture. Three-point bony landmarks in the elbow are the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.

Nerve injury:

  • Most common nerve to be injured in extension type - anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU)
  • Most common nerve to be injured in flexion type - Ulnar nerve.

Vessel injury:

  • Most common vessel to be injured - brachial artery.

On examination:

  • There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign).

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle (humeral-capitellar angle) can help in assessing the degree of medial angulation before reduction.

Complications:

  • Malunion - posteromedially displaced fracture tends to develop cubitus varus (gunstock deformity)
  • Nerve injury - usually neuropraxia, hence transient
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture and compartment syndrome 

Treatment of Supracondylar fracture:

  • Undisplaced fractures are immobilized at 90 degrees and neutral rotation with a cast and the arm is supported by a sling for 3 weeks.
  • Open fractures, severely displaced fractures, and fractures with vascular damage are fixed by open reduction and K-wire fixation.

Treatment of Cubitus Varus deformity includes:  

  • Lateral closed wedge osteotomy - French
  • Medial open wedge osteotomy - King's

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg (not <375) is an indication of mechanical ventilation.

Indications of mechanical ventilation:

Directly measured indices

  • Arterial oxygen tension <50 mmHg on room air
  • Arterial CO2 tension >50 mmHg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis

Derived indices

  • PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg
  • PA–aO2 gradient >350 mm Hg
  • Vd/Vt >0.6 (Ratio of physiologic dead space over tidal volume)

Clinical indices

  • Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

Mechanical indices

  • Tidal volume <5 mL/kg
  • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg
  • Maximum inspiratory force > −25 cm H2O

questions.text: You observe a patient being operated upon in the given position in the operation theatre. What could be the likely surgery being performed?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option D-Laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

The above image shows the reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly rotated to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder, which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A patient admitted to the medical intensive care unit is found to have non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis. Further investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mmol/L, low urinary ammonium ions, and a positive urine anion gap. The pH of the urine is found to be 5.7. No other substances were found to be abnormally excreted in the urine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has type 1 renal tubular acidosis. The points that favor the diagnosis are hypokalemia, non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, positive urine anion gap, low urine ammonium ions, and pH of the urine of more than 5.5.

Type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) occurs due to impaired acid excretion in the distal tubule. Patients will have hypokalemia, a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, positive urine anion gap, low urine [NH4+]), and high urine pH (pH > 5.5). Most patients also have hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria, so nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, and bone disease are common.

Type 2 renal tubular acidosis occurs due to impaired reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal tubule. In addition to hypokalemic metabolic acidosis, patients also have glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia (Fanconi syndrome). Since the acidification in the distal tubule is functioning normally, the pH of the urine is less than 5.5

Type 3 renal tubular acidosis has mixed features of both type 1 and type 2 RTA.

Type 4 renal tubular acidosis is common in patients with diabetes mellitus, tubulointerstitial disease, or chronic kidney disease. It occurs as a result of decreased aldosterone. The patients will have hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis along with hypertension.

(mEq/L)

(normalizes with alkalinization)

 Low

(Decreased further by alkalinization)

(correcting the hyperkalemia alone will improve the acidosis by increasing ammonium availability)

reabsorptive threshold.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis
