questions.text: A male patient presents with abdominal pain and a soft mobile swelling near the umbilicus, which moves in the direction shown in the image below. These findings are characteristic of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an abdominal swelling moving in a direction perpendicular to the line of attachment of the mesentery (Positive Tillaux sign) is characteristic of a mesenteric cyst.

Mesenteric cysts occur either in the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%) and can be classified as the following:

  • Chylolymphatic (most common type)
  • Enterogenous
  • Urogenital remnant
  • Dermoid

The most common presentation is that of a painless abdominal swelling with the characteristic physical signs: (Tillaux triad)

  • Fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus
  • Swelling moves freely in a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery (Tillaux sign) 
  • Presence of zone of resonance around the cyst

Other presentations include

  • Recurrent attacks of abdominal pain - due to temporary impaction of a food bolus in a segment of the bowel narrowed by the cyst
  • Vomiting
  • Acute abdominal complications, such as:
    • Torsion of the cyst
    • Rupture of the cyst
    • Hemorrhage into the cyst
    • Infection

Ultrasonography and CT scans are used to demonstrate mesenteric cysts. The treatment of mesenteric cysts is complete excision by enucleation, although bowel resection is frequently required to ensure that the remaining bowel is viable. If enucleation or resection is not possible, partial excision with marsupialization of the remaining cyst into the abdominal cavity is done.

questions.text: A carpenter presented with irritation and blurring of vision in both his eyes for 1 week. He gives a history of a wood chip penetrating into his right eye 3 weeks back. On evaluation, the visual acuity of the left eye was 6/12, while that of the right eye was light perception. Fundoscopic examination revealed Dalen-Fuchs nodules. Which of the following is the best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sympathetic ophthalmitis. The best step in the management of this patient is the enucleation of the right eye.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are granulomas located between the Bruch membrane and retinal pigmented epithelium; they are seen in Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome and sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are shown in the image below.

The exciting eye shows features of low-grade uveitis such as ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. The sympathizing eye is usually involved 4-8 weeks later. It has a prodromal stage with photophobia, ciliary congestion, and keratic precipitates. In the fully developed stage, symptoms of acute iridocyclitis supervene.

Steroids remain the basis of treatment. High-dose prednisolone or intravenous methylprednisolone is given to reduce inflammation. Enucleation of the exciting eye should be done when the exciting eye has a poor visual prognosis. Enucleation of the exciting eye is considered effective in preventing or reducing the severity of sympathetic ophthalmitis. Immunosuppressants like azathioprine, ciclosporin, and methotrexate can be given in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.

Other options:

Option A: In this case, the left eye will be the sympathizing eye and the right eye will be the exciting eye as there is a history of penetrating trauma to the right eye. Enucleation should be considered in the exciting eye with a poor visual prognosis. Therefore, enucleation of the left eye is not the answer.

Option C: Sympathetic ophthalmitis does not undergo spontaneous resolution as the exciting eye induces the inflammation unless treated with steroids or enucleated. So, treatment should be either with steroids prophylactically or enucleation of the exciting eye if there is poor visual prognosis.

Option D: Oral cyclosporine is indicated in resistant sympathetic ophthalmitis or as a steroid-sparing agent.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was admitted for bacterial pneumonia with a pleural effusion. The pleural fluid analysis revealed a specific gravity of 1.031 and contained a large number of polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which of the following best characterizes the pleural effusion in this patient?
questions.solution:
The specific gravity of 1.031 (>1.020) is suggestive of an exudate. The presence of a large number of neutrophils indicates a purulent exudate.

Purulent exudate is an inflammatory exudate rich in leukocytes, mostly neutrophils; the debris of the dead cells; and microbes.

Exudate:

  • Increased vascular permeability, caused by inflammatory mediators, may lead to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid called an exudate.
  • It has a high specific gravity of >1.020.
  • An exudate may be further classified into the following types:
    • Serous exudate: The exudative fluid does not contain microbes or leukocytes. Serous exudate is usually seen in spaces created by cell injury or into body cavities lined by pleura, pericardium, or peritoneum.
    • Fibrinous exudate: It occurs in inflammation associated with large vascular leaks and local procoagulant stimulus (Ex: caused by cancer cells). With a greater increase in vascular permeability, fibrinogen may pass out of the blood into the exudate. The fibrin formed is deposited in the extracellular space. A fibrinous exudate is characteristic of inflammation in the lining of body cavities, such as meninges, pericardium, and pleura.
    • Purulent exudate: It is an inflammatory exudate rich in leukocytes, mostly neutrophils; the debris of the dead cells, and microbes.

Transudate:

  • Transudate is extravascular fluid, which is essentially an ultrafiltrate of blood plasma. It results from increased fluid pressures or diminished colloid oncotic forces in the plasma, and not due to the increased vascular permeability.
  • It has low protein content and low nucleated-cell counts (less than 500 to 1000 per microliter) and low specific gravity (<1.012).
  • Noninflammatory edema and effusions (transudate) are common in many diseases, including heart failure, liver failure, renal disease, and severe nutritional disorders.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome 

Related Pearl: Causes of predominantly unilateral pleural effusion

Predominantly right-sided pleural effusion

Predominantly left-sided pleural effusion

Cirrhosis of the liver

(hepatic hydrothorax)

 Acute pancreatitis

Amebic liver abscess

 Aortic dissection
 Meig’s syndrome Esophageal rupture

Cardiac failure

( B/L>>right-sided)

Dressler’s syndrome

questions.text: A junior resident, during his first emergency room duty, comes across a patient with difficulty in breathing. Since he was not confident to do endotracheal intubation, he tries to secure the airway with the following device. All of the following are the advantages of using this device when compared with tracheal intubation, except that _____.

choices.text: It does not require neck mobility.
It is associated with decreased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration.
It does not require muscle relaxation.
There is no risk of endobronchial intubation.

questions.solution:
This given image is of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA). All of the options are the advantages of using this device when compared with tracheal intubation except that it is associated with a decreased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration. There is an increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration when compared with tracheal intubation.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Advantages and disadvantages of the laryngeal mask airway compared with tracheal intubation: 

Advantages:

  • Less invasive
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Less tooth and laryngeal trauma
  • Does not require muscle relaxation
  • Does not require neck mobility 
  • No risk of esophageal or endobronchial intubation

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

questions.text:
Match the different types of chromatography to their respective prototype images.

a. Size-exclusion chromatography

b. Affinity chromatography

c. Paper chromatography

d. Ion-exchange chromatography
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, and 4-a.

Image 1 shows paper chromatography, which works on the principle of polarity. The least polar molecule moves faster.

Image 2 shows ion-exchange chromatography. Here, proteins interact with the stationary phase by charge-charge interactions. Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) is best measured using ion-exchange chromatography.

Image 3 shows affinity chromatography, which works on the principle of specific ligand-binding behavior of proteins.

Image 4 shows size-exclusion chromatography, also known as gel filtration chromatography, separates the proteins based on their stokes radii. Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume occupied by a protein as it rapidly tumbles in free solution. Stokes radius is thus a function of both molecular mass and shape.

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented to the emergency department with left wrist pain following a fall. On examination, the patient was found to have swelling and tenderness at his left thumb base. His x-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the above image are suggestive of Bennett fracture.

Bennett fracture is an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the base of the first metacarpal from the rest of the first metacarpal. It is the most common fracture involving the base of the thumb. 

The fracture is oblique and extends into the carpometacarpal joint. The strong pull of the abductor pollicis longus tendon that remains attached to the shaft of the metacarpal makes the fracture very unstable. X-ray shows a small triangle fragment remained in contact with the medial edge of the trapezium.

Plaster is applied with a felt pad over the fracture, and the first metacarpal is held in abduction and extension by flexing the MCP joint. Surgical fixation is done by passing a K-wire across the metacarpal base unto the carpus. 

Other options:

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration. The fracture can be managed with closed reduction and k wiring or by open reduction and plate fixation.

While both Bennett and Rolando fractures are intra-articular fractures of the metacarpal base, the differentiating feature is that Rolando fracture is a comminuted fracture producing 3 parts, whereas Bennett fracture is a 2 piece fracture.

The X-ray shown below depicts a Rolando fracture.

 

Option C: Boxer fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal, as shown below.

 

Option D: Barton fracture is a split of the volar edge of the distal radius, as shown below.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a case of death due to bullet injuries. It showed linear fractures on the skull, as shown in the image below. Which of the following rules gives the sequence of the bullet injuries?
questions.solution:
The sequence of bullet injuries is given by Puppe’s rule.

Puppe’s rule: It is possible to determine the sequence of injuries in skull fractures caused by blunt injuries to the head because the second fracture ends at the point where a break in cohesion is already present.The fracture lines created by every other shot extend only up to the fractured lines produced by the previous shot without continuing over them. Even though this rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, it is of particular importance in gunshot wounds. 

Other options:

Option A- M'Naghten rule is a test to determine criminal responsibility and states that an accused person is not legally responsible if at the time of committing the crime, he/she was suffering from a defect of reason due to an abnormality of mind, which made him/her unaware of the nature and quality of the act he was doing or what he was doing was wrong. It comes under Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

Option C- Young's rule is used to calculate the dose of a drug for a child. It is calculated by multiplying the adult dose by the age in years and dividing the result by the sum of the child's age plus 12.

Option D- Durham's rule is a test to determine criminal responsibility and states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act is a product of mental disease (mental disorder) or mental defect (mental retardation). 

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

 18

-

Not liable

If done by accident or misfortune and without any criminal intention or knowledge in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means and with proper care and caution.

 20

82

A child under 7 years is not liable for the act.

21

83

Child of 7–12 years if not attained proper mental maturity is not liable for the act.

22

84  

McNaughten's rule: A person of unsound mind is not liable for the act.

23

85

A person who under involuntary intoxication has commited an act is not liable for the act.

24

86

A person who under voluntary intoxication commits an act is liable for the act.

questions.text: During an experiment, it was found that a skeletal muscle's latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period were 15 ms, 30 ms, and 60 ms, respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency.
questions.solution:
The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 33 per second.

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period (per second)

Therefore, tetanizing frequency = 1/30 per millisecond = 1/0.03 per second = 1000/30 per second = 33 per second.

With repeated stimulation, contraction occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred. This causes the individual responses to fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called tetanus (tetanic contraction). ​​​Tetanizing frequency is the minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.

Tetanus is of two types, complete tetanus, when no relaxation occurs between stimuli, and incomplete tetanus, when periods of incomplete relaxation occur between the summated stimuli. 

When there is a repeated stimulus to a muscle fiber before relaxation, it produces an additional contraction of the muscle. The second contraction adds to the first contraction and the total strength of contraction increases. This phenomenon is known as a summation of contractions.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with CKD is scheduled for surgery. Her serum creatinine level is 2.4 mg/dL and eGFR is 13. Which of the following opioids can be safely used in her?

CKD - Chronic kidney disease.
questions.solution:
The given lab values in a CKD patient are suggestive of renal failure and remifentanil can be safely used in renal failure patients.

Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases. The pharmacokinetics and the pharmacodynamics of remifentanil are not altered by renal dysfunction.

Option A: Pethidine is metabolized to norpethidine, the accumulation of which can lead to CNS excitatory effects (seizures).

Option C: High levels of alfentanil can lead to prolonged action.

Option D: Morphine is metabolized to morphine-6-glucuronide which can accumulate leading to respiratory depression.

Note: Fentanyl clearance is not altered by renal failure, but its plasma protein binding is decreased, which can alter the concentration of the free drug. Hence, fentanyl is the second drug of choice after remifentanil.

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, pain over the ribs, and confusion. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and increased serum creatinine level. The peripheral smear shows the finding given below. The international prognostic staging system for this disease is based on the levels of which of the following parameters?

choices.text: β2 glycoprotein and plasma light chains

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing a Mott cell suggest a probable diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The international prognostic staging system for multiple myeloma is based on levels of β2 microglobulin and albumin.

Mott cells are plasma cells with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies. They may be seen in African trypanosomiasis and multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia in which there is an unregulated proliferation of plasma cells. The proliferating cells stimulate osteoclastic activity and suppress osteoblastic activity, leading to the formation of multiple lytic bone lesions. These lesions can be seen on radiographs as 'punched out' lesions.  In some severe cases, patients may present with pathological fractures. 

Other features of multiple myeloma:

  • Acute renal failure in a dehydrated state
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia 
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes cause headache, exacerbation, or precipitation of heart failure, visual disturbances, ataxia, and vertigo
  • Bony damage leading to cord compression
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Sensory more than motor neuropathy associated with IgM directed against myelin-associated globulin

The single most important predictor for survival is serum β2-microglobulin. Serum β2-microglobulin, along with serum albumin, forms the basis of the International Staging System for multiple myeloma that predicts survival.

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

 

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Myeloma

Poor prognosis

Good prognosis

t(4;14), MAF translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20), del(17p), aneuploidy, hypodiploidy

Hyperdiploid, t(11;14), t(6;14), cyclin D1 or D3 positive

Elevated beta-2 microglobulin, lactate dehydrogenase, C- reactive protein, plasma-cell proliferation, or bone marrow infiltration

Plasmablastic morphology

Abnormalities by conventional cytogenetics

Plasma labelling index >3%

Serum creatinine level >2mg/dL

Bone marrow biopsy: Diffuse and prominent angiogenesis

Low serum albumin

questions.text: On noticing taurodontism in the postmortem reports of a body, you would suspect that the individual belongs to which of the following races?
questions.solution:
Taurodontism or bull tooth is most commonly associated with Mongoloid race. It is characterized by a wide and deep pulp cavity in molar teeth and fused and bent roots. 

Other common associations in Mongoloid teeth include enamel pearls, which are small nodules appearing on the tooth surface. This race is also frequently associated with shovel-shaped upper central incisors and a congenital absence of the third upper molar. 

Other options:

Negroid races are found to have large teeth, multiple cusps (up to 8) on their molars, and 2 lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars.

Caucasians have smaller lateral incisors than central incisors (seen especially in females), and long pointed canine roots. They also have small nodules on the lingual surface of their maxillary molars known as 'Carabelli's cusp', which are most commonly associated with Caucasian races.

questions.text: A patient who developed the following lesions over the body was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). In which subtype of AML is this finding usually seen?
questions.solution:
The given image shows leukemia cutis. It is seen in acute myeloid leukemia -myelomonocytic (AML-M4) and AML-M5 (M5a - monoblastic, M5b - monocytic). It refers to leukemic cells infiltrating the skin. 

Signs and symptoms related to the involvement of tissues other than the marrow are usually less striking in AML than in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). But tumors with monocytic differentiation (AML M4, M5) often infiltrate the skin (leukemia cutis) and the gingiva. This probably reflects the normal tendency of monocytes to extravasate into tissues.

questions.text: A patient undergoes reconstruction surgery after removal of a tumor from the right breast. Which of the following is incorrect about the flap used in the patient, which is shown in the image?

choices.text: It is a variant of the TRAM flap.
It is based on the deep inferior epigastric artery.
Increased risk of abdominal wall weakness.
No muscle is taken in this technique.

questions.solution:
The given image is of deep inferior epigastric artery perforator flap (DIEP). When DIEP is used, there is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness.

The DIEP flap is a variant of the transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap; it is based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. It is harvested using a microvascular technique, in which no muscle is taken and the perforating vessel is dissected out. As muscle is spared in DIEP, there is reduced risk in abdominal wall weakness and its associated complications.

Other flaps using autogenous tissue in breast reconstruction are TRAM flap and latissimus dorsi (LD) flap:

The TRAM flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM).

 

Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presents with recurrent bouts of vomiting and abdominal cramps over the past three hours. He gives a history of consumption of fried rice at a restaurant 5 hours back. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette showing food poisoning within 2 hours of consumption of fried rice/ Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (serotypes 1, 3, 5) food poisoning.

Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus: one involves the stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other is independent of it.

Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8–16 hours 1–5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

B. cereus produces lecithinase and ferments glucose but not mannitol. The presence of 1,00,000 or more bacteria per gram of stool is diagnostic. Anything less than that may be present as normal flora in the gut. Both types of illnesses are mild and self-limiting, requiring no specific treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Food poisoning by Clostridium perfringens is usually caused by the consumption of cold or warmed-up meat dishes. After an incubation period of 8-24 hours, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting set in. Isolating heat-resistant C. perfringens type A from feces and food is used for the diagnosis.

Option B: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is endemic in developing countries of the tropics, seen in all age groups. Its severity varies from mild watery diarrhea to a fatal disease indistinguishable from cholera. It has an incubation period of >16 hours. Demonstration of the enterotoxins is helpful to establish the diagnosis. It causes traveler's diarrhea in people from non-endemic areas visiting endemic areas.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin is responsible for staphylococcal food poisoning. It presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after 2–6 hours of consuming contaminated food. Meat, fish, milk, and milk products that are cooked and left at room temperature after contamination with Staphylococci, for a long enough time for the toxin to accumulate, are usually responsible. The source of infection is usually a food handler who is a carrier.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Tolcapone acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme. 

The addition of carbidopa to levodopa prevents peripheral decarboxylation of  levodopa. However, levodopa can now be methylated by catechol-O-methyl transferase and get inactivated. This is prevented by catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors tolcapone and entacapone. 

Parkinson's disease arises as a result of the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the striatum. Therefore the mainstay of treatment for this disease is to increase dopamine in this area.

Other options:

Option A- Amantadine is an antiviral agent. It is used in the prophylaxis and treatment of influenza A. It has antiparkinsonian activity. It alters dopamine release in the striatum, has anticholinergic properties, and blocks methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. It can be used in mild disease, dose-related fluctuations, and dyskinesia.

Option B- Rotigotine is a dopamine receptor agonist. It acts on D1 and D2 receptors, whereas ropinirole and pramipexole act on the D2 and D3 receptors.  The duration of action of the DA agonists (8–24 h) is often longer than that of levodopa (6–8 h). They are effective in the treatment of patients who have developed on/off phenomena.

Option D- Selegiline and rasagiline are selective monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitors. Dopamine in the striatum is predominantly metabolized by the MAO-B enzyme. Inhibiting this enzyme will increase dopamine concentration in these neurons. They selectively and irreversibly inactivate MAO-B.

Note:

Other drugs used in parkinsonism are:

Levodopa is a prodrug. It crosses the blood-brain barrier. Levodopa is converted to dopamine by decarboxylation in dopaminergic neurons in the striatum. It significantly improves the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

An adverse effect of levodopa is the wearing-off phenomenon. After administrating levodopa, there is improvement in the symptoms for a period of 1–2 h, but rigidity and akinesia return rapidly after the effect of the drug reduces. Increasing the dose and frequency of administration can improve this phenomenon, but the patients often develop dyskinesia and excessive abnormal involuntary movements.

In the later stages of the disease, patients may fluctuate rapidly between being “off,” having no beneficial effects from their medications, and being “on” having some beneficial effects but along with side effects.

Levodopa, if administered alone will undergo decarboxylation by the decarboxylases present in the intestinal mucosa and other peripheral sites. This will lead to decreased concentration of the drug reaching the brain. In order to prevent this levodopa is always given with carbidopa. Carbidopa inhibits peripheral decarboxylase enzymes.  

Muscarinic receptor antagonists are used as adjuncts to dopamine therapy. Eg. trihexyphenidyl and benztropine. Diphenhydramine, an antihistamine is also used.

Apomorphine acts on D4 and mildly on D2, D3, and D5 receptors. It also has adrenergic action. 

 

Related Pearl: Medical treatment of Parkinson's disease

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient was referred to you with features of pituitary adenoma and testicular tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you notice that the patient has a history of parathyroid adenoma. His chromosomal studies show a mutation in the CDKN1B gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CDKN1B gene : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1b gene
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of pituitary adenoma, parathyroid adenoma, testicular tumor, and a mutation in the CDKN1B gene is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4 (MEN 4).

MEN 4 is an autosomal dominant endocrine tumor syndrome. It occurs due to the germline mutation in the CDKN1B gene in chromosome 12.

MEN 4 often presents with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, or neuroendocrine cervical cancer with adrenal or renal tumors. 

The clinical presentation in MEN 4 is almost similar to that of MEN1. The difference between MEN1 and MEN4 is in the germline mutation, where MEN 1 occurs due to the mutation of the MEN1 gene.

MEN is a group of autosomal dominant disorders characterized by tumors involving two or more endocrine glands. Depending on the chromosomal location of germline mutation, they are divided into four major forms: MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), and MEN 4. MEN 1 is the most common among the four types. 

Other Options:

Option B: MEN 3 is also known as MEN 2B. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, and marfanoid features. In contrast with MEN2A, parathyroid hyperplasia is not seen in MEN 2B.

Option C: MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma.

Option D: MEN 1 is also known as Wermer's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene. It is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer. She presented a few weeks later with complaints of swelling around the incision site. The finding is as shown below. What is the 1st line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows the development of a seroma. It is initially treated with aspiration. A seroma that reaccumulates after at least two aspirations is evacuated by opening the incision and packing the wound with saline-moistened gauze. It is then allowed to heal with secondary intention.

Seroma is a collection of fluid in a surgically created cavity, which results from the transection of vessels and lymphatics. It presents as a localized, well-circumscribed swelling with discomfort. The fluid is clear, yellow, and viscous. Closed suction drains that obliterate the space between the pectoralis major and skin flap are placed to prevent seromas. 

Risk factors:

  1. Large skin flaps
  2. Mesh usage
  3. Premature drain removal
  4. Use of electrocautery
  5. Vigorous shoulder exercises post-procedure

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea. He is a chronic smoker. On evaluation, a chest x-ray revealed a mass in his right lung and a biopsy of the mass revealed the following picture. Blood examination revealed leukocytosis with no tumor markers. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is large cell carcinoma of the lung.

The given clinical features, with the absence of tumor markers, leukocytosis, and the histopathological image showing large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate cytoplasm point to the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumor. Typical cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer are absent. This type of lung cancer does not express any of the tumor markers associated with adenocarcinoma (TTF-1, napsin A) or squamous cell carcinoma (p40, p63). On microscopy, the features described above are observed.

Tumor-related leukocytosis is commonly seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with large cell carcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option A - Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor. Histopathological examination shows various patterns, including acinar, papillary, lepidic, micropapillary, and solid. A histopathological image of adenocarcinoma of the lung showing glandular differentiation is given below:


Option B - Small cell carcinomas are highly malignant tumors with a strong association with cigarette smoking. Histopathological examination shows relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin in a salt-and-pepper pattern, and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.

Azzopardi effect is the basophilic staining of vessel walls due to DNA residue deposited from necrotic tumor cells, as seen below:


Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor associated with smoking. Histopathological examination is characterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization is seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is a high mitotic activity in poorly differentiated tumors.

The image given below shows squamous pearls seen in squamous cell carcinomas.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with a fracture of the pelvis sustained as a result of a road traffic accident. There was urinary retention and blood at the urethral meatus. Vermooten sign was present on per rectal examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with pelvic fracture, blood at the urethral meatus and a positive Vermooten sign are suggestive of a rupture of the membranous urethra. Vermooten sign refers to the presence of high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination.

Rupture Membranous urethra Bulbar urethra
Cause Fracture of the pelvis Blow to the perineum (fall-astride injury-straddle injury)
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Perineal bruising and hematoma (butterfly shaped)
Investigation Retrograde urethrogram  Retrograde urethrogram

 

In both cases, the initial management should be the insertion of a suprapubic catheter. Passing a catheter blindly per urethra is not advised as this can convert a partial tear into a complete tear. 

However, delayed urethroplasty is the definitive management for a complete urethral tear.

questions.text: You observe that the arms of an infant extend spontaneously when the senior resident tries to elicit the following reflex by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. All the following options regarding this reflex are true, except ______.

choices.text: This reflex is  a prerequisite to walking.
This reflex starts to appear by 7–8 months of age.
This reflex disappears by 18 months of postnatal period.

questions.solution:
The reflex being elicited in the given scenario is the parachute reflex, and this reflex remains throughout life.

The parachute reflex can be evoked by holding the infant's trunk and then suddenly lowering it as if it were falling. This will cause the infant's arms to extend in order to break the fall. Thus, it is a prerequisite for walking. The onset of this reflex is at 7-8 months of age; it fully develops by 10-11 months and persists for life. 

The parachute reflex is a primitive reflex. Primitive reflexes appear and disappear at specific times during a child's development. Any persistence or absence of these reflexes is significant for central nervous system dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

 
Reflex
Onset
Fully developed 
Duration
Palmar grasp
28 weeks of gestation
32 weeks of gestation
2-3 months postnatal
Rooting
32 weeks of gestation
36 weeks of gestation
Less prominent after 1 month postnatal
Moro
28-32 weeks of gestation
37 weeks of gestation
5-6 months postnatal
Tonic neck
35 weeks of gestation
1 month postnatal
3-4 months postnatal
Parachute
7-8 months postnatal
10-11 months postnatal
Remains throughout life

 

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient with no significant past medical history presented with palpitations and associated dizziness for one month. She also complains of mild fever, fatigue, and breathlessness that occurs on sitting upright but is relieved on lying down. On examination, cyanosis is noted. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic "plop" is heard. Echocardiogram shows the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with platypnea (breathlessness on sitting upright), cyanosis, fever, mid-diastolic "plop", and an echocardiogram featuring a mass in the left atrium is suggestive of an atrial myxoma.

Myxomas are the most common type of primary cardiac tumor in adults.
  • They occur at all ages, but mostly in the 3rd to 6th decades of life.
  • They show a female predilection.

Atrial myxoma is most commonly located in the left atrium.

  • The region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum is the favored site of origin.
  • Mobile tumors exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets.
  • They can be sporadic (90%) or familial with an autosomal dominant trait.
Features Sporadic Type Myxoma Familial Type Myxoma
Incidence Single Multiple
Postoperative recurrence  NIL Present
Most common site Left atria  Ventricular 
Age   Younger age
  • The familial myxomas usually occur as part of a syndrome known as Carney complex, which includes the following:
    • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
    • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
    • Endocrine overactivity - (primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly)

Presentation:

  • Sudden in onset; positional in nature owing to the effect of gravity (platypnea- breathlessness on sitting upright)
  • Presents with obstructive signs and symptoms mimicking valvular heart diseases (palpitation, dizziness)
  • Embolic phenomenon: Embolization of tumor thrombi leading to stroke, MI, pulmonary embolism, DIC, etc.
  • Constitutional symptoms: Fever, weight loss, cachexia, malaise, arthralgia, rash, digital clubbing, Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Characteristic mid-diastolic "tumor plop" with loud S1 at the apex is heard on auscultation
  • Laboratory reports: Anemia, polycythemia, leukocytosis, elevated ESR and CRP, thrombocytopenia, thrombocytosis

Transesophageal/Transthoracic echocardiography is the diagnostic investigation. CT/MRI angiography can also be done.

Treatment: Surgical excision using cardiopulmonary bypass 

The image below shows a picture of an atrial cardiac myxoma arising from the region of the fossa ovalis and extending to the mitral valve orifice

Histopathology: Myxomas are composed of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. Peculiar vessel-like or gland-like structures are characteristically seen. Hemorrhage and mononuclear inflammation can be present

The image below shows abundant amorphous extracellular matrix containing scattered multinucleate myxoma cells in various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option B: Fibromas are most common in children. They are usually single and ventricular in location. They are often calcified and tend to grow and cause arrhythmias and obstructive symptoms and should be completely resected when possible.

Option C: Rhabdomyomas are the most common cardiac tumors in infants and children and usually occur in the ventricles. They are hamartomatous growths, and the majority are multiple and are strongly associated with tuberous sclerosis. These tumors have a tendency to regress completely or partially; only tumors that cause obstruction require surgical resection.

Option D: Infective endocarditis is characterized by vegetation, which is a mass of platelets, fibrin, microorganisms, and scant inflammatory cells. On gross examination, the vegetations in infective endocarditis appear as large irregular masses on the valve cusps that extend into the chordae tendinae. Infection most commonly involves heart valves but may also occur on the low-pressure side of a ventricular septal defect, on mural endocardium damaged by aberrant jets of blood or foreign bodies, or on intracardiac devices themselves. The most common clinical manifestation is fever with a new-onset murmur.

questions.text: Following a flood, there is an outbreak of fever. Water samples from various sources are being studied for pathogens. The bacteria shown in the given image was isolated as a potential cause of disease. Which of the following animals is the most important reservoir of these organisms?
questions.solution:
The electron micrograph shows the spirochete, Leptospira interrogans, which causes the water-borne disease, leptospirosis. Rats are the most important reservoir. 

Transmission of leptospires may follow direct contact with urine, blood, or tissue from an infected animal or exposure to environmental contamination.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and bone pain. She had undergone total parathyroidectomy and heterotopic autotransplantation for the same complaints 8 months ago. A sestamibi scan was done and found to be normal. A Casanova test was done and was found to be positive. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent hyperparathyroidism. A positive Casanova test indicates that it could be due to recurrence in the neck or graft (graft hyperplasia).

The Casanova test involves selective venous sampling for PTH levels from neck veins and brachial veins. If PTH from the brachial venous sample is >20 times that of the neck vein sample, graft hyperplasia is confirmed.

Persistent parathyroid is defined as hypercalcemia that fails to resolve after parathyroidectomy i.e. within 6 weeks of surgery. Recurrent parathyroid is hyperparathyroidism that occurs after an intervening period of at least 6 months of biochemically documented normocalcemia.

Causes of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism include:

  • Ectopic parathyroid
  • Unrecognized hyperplasia - graft site hyperplasia
  • Missed adenoma in normal position
  • Incomplete resection
  • Familial hyperparathyroidism
  • MEN-1 syndrome

The image below summarizes the management protocol for a case of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism.

*FHH stands for Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia.

questions.text: The drug authorities are conducting a search for drugs and seize a bag labeled "liquid gold". What are the contents of the bag?
questions.solution:
The term 'liquid gold' refers to the urine of amphetamine addicts, which is collected and sold as around 40% of amphetamine is excreted unchanged in urine. 

Methamphetamine is also colloquially referred to as 'ice', 'crystal', 'chalk', and 'meth'. It used to be known as 'speed' or 'go'. It can be taken by ingestion, intravenous injection, inhalation, or nasal insufflation. It enhances the release and inhibits the reuptake of catecholamines at the presynaptic terminals.

Amphetamine intoxication is suspected in cases presenting with agitation, mydriasis, diaphoresis, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hyperthermia, similar to cocaine intoxication. Mental status may be normal or severely agitated and paranoid.

Advanced tooth decay, or meth mouth, is commonly seen in habitual methamphetamine abusers. It may be multifactorial and due to poor oral hygiene, dry mouth, consumption of high-carbohydrate carbonated beverages, jaw clenching, and tooth grinding.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about iodine-based contrast media?

choices.text: They do not interfere with the clotting times.
Iohexol is an ionic iodine-based contrast.
They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.
They are used in magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.solution:
Iodine-based contrast media are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media:

Iodine provides the radio-opacity, while the other compounds act as carriers of iodine. They are commonly used in angiography and computed tomography. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media are iothalamate and iohexol, respectively.

Related Pearl: Classification of iodinated contrast medias:

Subtypes  Monomer Dimer Monomer Dimer

Iodine: particle ratio 3:2 6:2 or 3:1 3:1 6:1
Examples

questions.text: You are an intern evaluating a newborn. The newborn has acute respiratory distress and cyanosis that is relieved with crying. He has feeding difficulty. A laryngeal mirror placed under the nostrils reveals an absence of fogging and a suction catheter cannot be passed through either nostril. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with respiratory distress and cyanosis that is relieved by crying, feeding difficulty, who has an absence of fogging, and in whom a suction catheter cannot be passed through either nostril is likely to have bilateral choanal atresia. 

Choanal atresia is a congenital condition in which the nasal choana is occluded by soft tissue, bone, or both. It is due to failed recanalization during development. It is part of CHARGE syndrome characterized by coloboma, heart disease, atresia choanae, growth, and mental retardation, genital hypoplasia, and ear anomalies. 

It can be unilateral or bilateral. Unilateral choanal atresia is more common and some patients with this condition are undiagnosed until adulthood. Patients with bilateral atresia present with respiratory obstruction. This is because newborns are obligate nose breathers and cannot breathe from the mouth. 

Evaluation of newborns with choanal atresia involves the following: 

  • Placing a laryngeal mirror under the nostrils to look for fogging
  • Inserting a suction catheter through each nostril and oral cavity to look for patency
  • Inserting a flexible nasal endoscope
  • CT scan to delineate the extent of the malformation and differentiating from other causes of nasal obstruction

Unilateral choanal atresia does not require immediate correction. Surgery can be performed when the child has reached school-age provided they are monitored for breathing issues.

Bilateral choanal atresia should be treated immediately with endotracheal intubation or a McGovern nipple (an intraoral nipple with a large opening secured in the mouth with ties around the occiput). This is followed by perforation of the atresia plate.

Other options: 

Option A - Turbinate hypertrophy is seen in conditions like chronic rhinitis or hypertrophic rhinitis. It occurs due to recurrent nasal infections and chronic irritation. It is unlikely to be seen in newborns. 

Option B - Antrochonal polyps arise from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. It is seen in children and young adults and may occur due to nasal allergy with a sinus infection. It is visible as a globular mass on posterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy.

Option C - Deviated nasal septum can occur due to errors in development or trauma. It would also present with nasal obstruction. However, acute respiratory distress with cyanosis is unlikely to be present. 

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: Which is the classification system used for the fracture shown in the x-ray given below?
questions.solution:
The given image is of the fracture of the proximal humerus. The most widely accepted classification is the Neer classification, which involves 4 major segments in injuries:

  • Head of humerus
  • Greater tuberosity
  • Lesser tuberosity
  • Shaft of humerus

Neer classiﬁcation distinguishes between the number of displaced fragments, with displacement deﬁned as greater than 45 degrees of angulation or 1 cm of separation.

Other options

Option A: The Schatzker classification is a method of classifying tibial plateau fractures.

Option B: The Ideberg classification is a method of classification of intra-articular glenoid fossa fractures.

Option D: The Gartland classification is a method of classification of supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady comes to a cervical cancer screening camp for routine screening. A Pap smear was done and the image of the slide  is shown below. What cells are visualized on the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a low-grade squamous epithelial lesion (LSIL) with visualization of typical koilocytes.

Koilocytes are identified as cells with a perinuclear clearing (halo cells) and irregular nuclei. They are epithelial cells that develop after human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. They disappear as dysplasia advances.

Dysplasias and Cells-

Grade of dysplasia

Histopathological features
Mild Dysplasia
(CIN I)

Undifferentiated cells are confined to the lower 1/3rd of epithelium.

Atypical cells of undetermined significance (ASCUS) may be seen 

Intermediate cells may show mild dysplasia- irregular outlines with enlarged cells
Moderate Dysplasia
(CIN-II)

Undifferentiated cells are seen in the lower 50-75% of the epithelium.

Intermediate cells with moderate nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia, irregular chromatin, and multiple nuclei

Severe Dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ
(CIN-III)

Entire thickness is replaced with abnormal cells. Stratification is lost.

Basement membrane is intact.

Abrupt histological change from normal to abnormal zones. 

Cells are mostly parabasal with increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio.

Mitotic figures are seen in addition to CIN-II changes. 

Invasive Cancer 

 Tadpole cells are seen 

 Mild dysplasia is seen with infections like HPV and trichomoniasis and is reversible on treatment.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: During a labor posting, you happen to witness the management of a patient with difficult delivery for which the senior resident performs the maneuver shown in the image below. Name the condition for which this maneuver is performed.
questions.solution:
The image depicts McRoberts maneuver, which is performed in case of shoulder dystocia

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, postdatism, prior history, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.

Turtle sign is positive: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. The baby's cheeks bulge out, resembling a turtle pulling its head back into its shell. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing the delivery of the remainder of the baby.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia is as follows: 

  • First line: 
    • McRoberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of the thigh)
  • Second line:
    • Woods corkscrew maneuver (Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion) 
  • Third line:
    • Zavanelli maneuver (Push the head back and do a cesarean)
    • Cleidotomy (#clavicle of the baby)
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of the mother)

Other maneuvers: Rubin, gaskin (mother on all four limbs), Hubbard, Barnum maneuver.

The image below illustrates the McRoberts maneuver.

 

The image below illustrates cleidotomy being performed: 

 

The image below illustrates Zavanelli maneuver. Here, the fetal head is rotated to the direct occiput anterior position and pushed back into the uterus so that the fetus can be delivered by cesarean section. The cardinal movements of labor are reversed. 

Note:

  • In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli maneuver.
  • Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

questions.text: A patient with diagnosed peptic ulcer disease develops sudden intense abdominal pain and distension. A plain supine x-ray of his abdomen is shown below. What is the characteristic sign seen in the given x-ray?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray image are suggestive of pneumoperitoneum, and the characteristic sign seen in the x-ray is Rigler's sign or double-wall sign. The inner mucosal and outer serosal layers of the bowel wall are enhanced due to the presence of air on both sides of the bowel lumen. 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Radiological signs include:

  • Bowel related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament related signs
    • Football sign -the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch.
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline. Seen on chest X-ray.

Other options:

Option A - The spinnaker-sail sign (or angel wing sign) is characteristic of a pneumomediastinum in neonates. Both the lobes of the thymus are lifted and displaced laterally due to the air in the mediastinum. A wedge-shaped opacity is created extending into the superior mediastinum. 

Option B - Cupola sign is also seen in pneumoperitoneum. It refers to the gas accumulated under the diaphragm in the midline underneath the central tendon. It is seen in supine films of abdominal x-ray. 

Option D - Stepladder sign (or concertina effect) is seen in small intestinal obstruction. It represents the gas-fluid distended loops stacked upon each other, best appreciated in erect abdomen x-ray.

questions.text: A young woman presented with complaints of dysphagia, recurrent abdominal pain associated with nausea, feeling of 'hardness' over the left hypochondrium for the past 2 years. She reports that she is constantly worried about her symptoms. She has had multiple hospital visits, where detailed workups were not able to find any cause of her symptoms. She looks anxious with irritable affect. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the scenario, the presence of one or more somatic symptoms for more than 6 months in the absence of an organic cause is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder.

Somatic symptoms and related disorders group in DSM-5:

  • Somatic symptom disorder (somatoform disorder)
  • Illness anxiety disorder
  • Functional neurological symptom disorder (conversion disorder)
  • Factitious disorder (Munchausen syndrome)

Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months.

It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. It is associated with poor insight. Patients believe that they have a serious disease that has not yet been detected and they can­not be persuaded otherwise. Their convictions persist despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the alleged disease over time, and reassurances from doctors.

DSM-5 criteria for the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder: 

  • One or more somatic symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life.
  • Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the somatic symptoms or associ­ated health concerns as manifested by at least one of the following:
    • Disproportionate and persistent thoughts about the seriousness of one’s symptoms.
    • Persistently high level of anxiety about health or symptoms.
    • Excessive time and energy are devoted to these symptoms or health concerns.
  • Although a single somatic symptom may not be continuously present, the state of be­ing symptomatic is persistent.
  • The belief cannot have the intensity of a delusion, as seen in a delusional disorder, and cannot be restricted to distress about appearance, as seen in a body dysmorphic disorder.

The disorder follows an episodic course separated by long qui­escent periods. Exacerbations of somatic symptoms are associated with psychosocial stressors.

Patients with somatic symptom disorder usually resist psychi­atric treatment. Management involves:

  • Group psychotherapy - provides social support and interaction, helping to reduce anxiety
  • Other psychotherapy - insight-ori­ented psychotherapy, behavior therapy, cognitive therapy, and hypnosis, may be useful
  • Regularly scheduled physical examinations - to reassure patients that they are being taken care of
  • Invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedures should only be under­ taken, however, when objective evidence is present.
  • The clinician should refrain from treating equivocal or incidental physical examination findings.
  • Pharmacotherapy is used for treating somatic symptom disorder only when a patient has an underlying anxiety disorder or depressive disorder.

Other options:

Option A: Illness anxiety disorder deals with the fear of having a disease rather than a concern about many symptoms. Patients with illness anxiety disorder primarily concerned about being sick

Option B: Delusional disorder beliefs occur in schizo­phrenia and other psychotic disorders. They deal with bizarre, idiosyncratic delusions along with the presence of other psychotic symptoms.

Option C: Factitious disorder refers to the intentional falsification or inducement of symptoms with the goal to assume the sick role. 

Related Pearl: Classification of somatic symptom disorders: DSM-5 vs ICD-10

DSM-5

(Somatic symptom and related disorders)

 ICD-10

(Somatoform disorders)
Somatic symptom disorder

Somatization disorder

Undifferentiated somatoform disorder

Persistent somatoform pain disorder
Conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder) Dissociative (conversion) disorder
Illness anxiety disorder Hypochondriacal disorder
Factitious disorder  
Somatoform disorder NEC

Somatoform autonomic dysfunction

Other somatoform disorders

Neurasthenia (neurotic
disorders category)

Related Pearl: Somatoform Disorder

Somatoform Disorder

Key features of somatic symptom and related disorders

Somatic symptom disorder

Excessive anxiety and preoccupation with ≥1 unexplained symptom

Illness anxiety disorder

(hypochondriasis)

Fear of having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms and consistently negative evaluations

Conversion disorder

Malingering

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis revealed twin gestation, as shown in the image below. This type of twin gestation results if the division of the inner cell mass occurs:
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. If the division of the inner cell mass occurs within 3 days of fertilization, it results in this type of twin gestation. 

Placental chorionicity is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. A thick septum between the two gestational sacs is present in dichorionic twins.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

Twinning and Time of division:

Time of division Type of twin
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

 

Lambda sign:

Seen in craniosynostosis

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about normal human immunoglobulin (NHIG)?

choices.text: All live vaccines can be given simultaneously with NHIG.
They are used against measles and hepatitis A.
There should be a low IgA concentration in NHIG preparations.
Each NHIG fraction is obtained from at least 1,000 donors.

questions.solution:
Live vaccines should generally be avoided for 12 weeks following an injection of normal human immunoglobulin (Ig). If a live vaccine has already been administered, the injection of normal human Ig should be delayed for 2 weeks.

NHIG is an antibody-rich fraction that is usually obtained from a pool of at least 1,000 donors. AN NHIG preparation must contain at least 90% intact IgG and minimal IgG aggregates with low IgA concentration. NHIG is commonly used to prevent measles and hepatitis A infections.

Specific human immunoglobulins are made from the plasma of patients who have recently recovered from an infection or are obtained from individuals who have been immunized against a specific infection. These preparations have a high antibody content against an individual infection and provide immediate protection.

questions.text: The image given below shows an eyeball with a refractive error. All the following fundal changes can be seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image given above shows parallel rays of light converging at a point in front of the retina. Hence, the refractive error is myopia. All the fundal changes mentioned above can be seen in myopia, except cattle track appearance.

Cattle truck appearance is seen in branch retinal artery occlusion (not myopia).

Pathological/degenerative myopia is characterized by progressive anteroposterior elongation of the scleral envelope associated with secondary ocular changes due to mechanical stretching of the involved tissues.

Clinically patients present with defective vision, floating black opacities (muscae volitantes), and difficulty with night vision. Examination of the fundus reveals the following changes:

  • Optic disc:
    • Temporal myopic crescent
  • Retina and choroid:
    • Lacquer cracks are fine irregular yellow lines crisscrossing at the posterior pole, due to ruptures in the Bruch membrane.
    • Subretinal coin hemorrhages develop from lacquer cracks.
    • Fuchs spot: It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion at the macula which develops after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed.
    • A pale tessellated (tigroid) appearance of the fundus is seen due to diffuse attenuation of the RPE with large choroidal vessels.
    • Lattice degeneration
  • Vitreous: Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) appears as Weiss' reflex.
  • Posterior staphyloma.

The image given below shows fundal changes seen in pathological myopia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

Related Pearl: Grading of Myopia

American Optometric Association (AOA) Grading of Myopia:

  • Low myopia, when the error is < –3D.
  • Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.
  • High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

questions.text: An Indian tourist who has come to Jamaica consumes a local unripe fruit. Following its consumption, he develops severe vomiting, confusion, and hypoglycemia. Which of the following metabolic pathways may have been inhibited on consumption of this fruit?
questions.solution:
Beta oxidation of fatty acid is inhibited on the consumption of an unripe ackee fruit, which has the toxins hypoglycin A and B.

Ackee fruit grows on the Blighia sapida tree, a common ingredient in West African and Jamaican cuisine. Unripe ackee fruit contains the heat-stable toxins hypoglycin A and B. Hypoglycin inactivates medium- and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, inhibiting β-oxidation and causing hypoglycemia.

The resulting clinical syndrome, which is characterized by severe vomiting and hypoglycemia, is called Jamaican vomiting sickness. 

Given below is the image of the Ackee fruit:

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is planning a trek to Mount Everest. His family physician advises him to start taking oral acetazolamide as prophylaxis against acute mountain sickness. This drug inhibits the enzyme 'X'. Which of the following micronutrients is required for the activity of 'X'?
questions.solution:
The drug acetazolamide acts by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. Zinc is important for the functioning of this enzyme. 

Zinc is an important micronutrient that is an essential part of several metalloenzymes such as carbonic anhydrase, alcohol dehydrogenase, superoxide dismutase, and alkaline phosphatase.

Zinc helps to stabilize the intermediates formed during the reactions involving these enzymes. In addition, zinc forms a polynucleotide-binding structure called 'zinc fingers'. These zinc fingers function as transcription factors as well as DNA/RNA-binding proteins. Scientists are hoping to use zinc fingers in gene therapy because of their very specific binding sites on DNA and RNA. 

Other options:

Option (B) - Selenium is a known component of enzymes such as deiodinase and glutathione peroxidase.

Option (C) - Manganese can also be found in metalloenzymes like isocitrate dehydrogenase, arginase, and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase.

Option (D) - Copper is also a component of several important metalloenzymes such as lysyl oxidase, cytochrome oxidase, tyrosinase, and dopamine-beta-hydroxylase.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old alcoholic presents to your OPD with fissuring of the lips, cracking at angles of the mouth, red eyes, and oily scaly rash on the scalp. Among the following co-factors of enzyme complexes, which one is most affected?

NAD: Nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide

TPP: Thiamine pyrophosphate

FAD: Flavin-adenine-dinucleotide
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency. FAD and FMN are the coenzymes of riboflavin; hence, the most co-factor affected in this scenario is FAD.

Riboflavin, or vitamin B2, deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, and corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Other options:

Option A: NAD+ is the coenzyme of vitamin B3 (nicotinic acid, niacin)

Option B: TPP is the coenzyme of vitamin B1 (thiamine)

Option D: Coenzyme A is the coenzyme of vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid)

questions.text:
The image given below shows the mechanism of a component of the immune system's first line of defense against infection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the release of these substances from the cell?

SLE- Systemic lupus erythematosus

choices.text: It results in the loss of nucleus.
It is effective only against bacteria.
It is implicated in the pathogenesis of  SLE.

questions.solution:
The gif shows fibrous neutrophilic extracellular traps (NETs) released from a neutrophil. NETs are mainly effective against bacteria and fungi.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are the meshwork of nuclear chromatin of neutrophils. The loss of nuclei leads to the death of the neutrophils. They concentrate on antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to fight against bacteria and fungi (not viruses). They are detected in the blood during sepsis. They are produced by neutrophils in response to

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

Note: The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
